RATING: 6
Very interesting, very different than MTG, and very hard to get a grasp on the rules. This has a massive barrier to entry to learn the game, even if you have played tons of MTG like me. Sometimes the element of the unknown for the runner is too high, but it doesn't ruin the game.

(As of 05/06/14 I still haven't played face to face with a real person, and this will allow for a full opinion of the game.)

RATING: 10
Possibly the best game ever. I'm a board gamer. I love board games. I love Euro games with lots of fiddly bits, I love simple fun family games, I love abstract games. I'm not a huge fan of dungeon crawlers, luck based games or coops.

This game though; it's amazing in it's complexity and amazing in it's flavor. I love the asymmetry and can never make up my mind which I prefer to play, runner or corp.

If I had to choose one game to play forever it would be Netrunner.

Edit: My opinions on the LCG model have changed for the time being and collecting cards to construct decks isn't as appealing to me as pulling out a box with everything I need inside. So for now, dropped from a 9 to a 7.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Core x3 + all expansions owned

I never played the original Netrunner and I initially ignored this upon it's release despite a large following in my local group.  Curiosity got the best of me and I asked to play one game just to see what it was all about.  Now here I am over 50 play later and I can't get enough.  I enjoy the LCG delivery system for the game much more than when I used to play MtG and I feel as though you get A LOT of game for your money with this one.

Ok, so after playing in a couple tournaments for this game so far I have come to the conclusion that this is a great and really fun game that has a horrible tournament structure.  The amount of luck in this game really makes it difficult to come up with a fair way of playing a tournament structure that doesn't take up a prohibitively large amount of time to play.  As the corp you can get horribly unlucky with your draw and mulligan being full of agendas.  As the runner you can luck in to a ton of points early and just coast.  Winning the first game is a huge advantage going in to the second game if it goes to time.  I'm not sold on the tournament structure overall, but this is still a great game for casual and league play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After A: NR did so well in Geek Madness a couple of years ago I decided to give it a try. There are a couple of really nice things about the game. First of all the extremely asymmetric game play makes it so that the corp player and the runner play by their own set of rules. Second is the way the corp uses hidden information to try to control the runner, while the runner tries to predict what the corp is doing. These two elements not only create a compelling dynamic with regard to player interaction but are the foundation for the themes the game is exploring.

Unfortunately it's an LCG. This undermines player interaction by putting too much focus on analyzing a constantly evolving card set. And what you get in the starter set just isn't good enough when compared to similar games. The fact that the game is built around being endlessly expandable means the base set comes with a whole lot of extra rules baggage you only need if you are going to do a lot of deck building.

If you want a two player pseudo CCG without having to play the "meta" game get FFG's brilliant [thing=147154]Blue Moon Legends[/thing]. While asymmetric, it doesn't have the extreme asymmetry of A: NR. But it does have all the mind games and player interaction, without the rules overhead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game will never tell you to "Use this card to remove a green card from in front of another player", or anything so literal. It is so steeped in theme. There is probably a good strategic card game here, but my brain doesn't work this way.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The theme is extremely strong (so much so that the lingo is difficult to navigate at first), the gameplay is surprisingly fast, the options are deep, and the artwork is evocative of the setting. Not exactly a pick-up-and-play card game, Netrunner is a strategic battle between two players with asymmetric abilities and decks. 

One player is the runner, hacking into servers to sabotage corporate agendas. They are doing everything it takes to create a high-functioning rig that will enable them to crack through any firewalls and survive long enough to have taken down a sketchy and uber-powerful company.

The other player is the wealthy corporation, specializing in gaining assets, launching programs, and establishing agendas. The corporation knows that there are hackers looking to take them down, so they must attempt to set up several servers in order to create revenue and progress in their tech. They can even set up traps and strong firewalls for unsuspecting runners. 

The beauty of Netrunner is in its smooth card play and convincing lore. The feel is so grandiose and ingrained in the functions of the game that nothing feels shoehorned, but only natural considering the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I really like it, same designer as Magic
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Android Netrunner has quite an interesting theme and all the jargon used in the game adds to the atmosphere (although I have to say that it makes learning the game a lot harder). Fog of war is also nicely executed with the corporation player playing his defenses face down. Figuring out the best combos from your cards is fun as well.

After a few plays the bad stuff kicks in, though. It is extremely boring to play the corporation. You are basically just sitting there waiting for the runner player to attack or waiting for the scoring cards to appear. I guess it says enough if you use the word "wait" twice in a sentence. Moreover, the rulebook is as bad as you can expect from Fantasy Flight Games. It is absolutely useless if you are trying to find some important rules. All rules having a big impact on the game play (the maximum Memory Units the Runner has at his disposal, for example) should be at least bolded or made stand out from the rest of the text. But no. Now everything is scattered all over the rulebook and some rules cannot be even found under the title explicitly referring to them making it impossible to find the piece of information you need quickly. 

I definitely cannot understand how this is so popular of a game. Yes, I can see that there a good qualities to it but to me it felt unexciting and shallow. Oh, I know that some (or most) people don't agree with the shallow part, but if it takes tens of plays to see the depth, I won't be doing it. The few plays I have under my belt were enough to convince me against of buying this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
+Good depth of play without having an overwhelming number of choices.
+Plays quick.
+Numerous strategies in the base game alone seem to all be viable.

=Game has a certain degree of luck, which can balance out a disparity in player skill. The better player will still win more often than not, however.

-Core set doesn't come with 3 copies of every card.
-Click trackers have no spot for 0 clicks spent (very minor gripe).

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
So, I finally played a game of Netrunner after watching my friends play it during lunch at work for several weeks.  The watching for weeks ended up being pretty good for learning the game, since I was able to dive in and start playing with only a few questions (and some minor rules reading as I had been reading the rules on and off while they played for those previous weeks).

The game was fun.  I played a corporation, Haas-Bioroid, and I don't remember what hacker my opponent played.  We were only using the standard decks - no expansions and nothing fancy.  Due to some great luck, within the first two turns the hacker had already gained two agendas - worth 4 points.  But then I got enough ice on the table to block a good many of his moves.  

I scored an agenda for 3 points, and thwarted his efforts when he made a run on my hand - I was holding two cards, they were the same, and they were worthless - a great hand to frustrate him.  Any cards I drew I played, keeping those two at hand for wasting his moves.  He did make a successful run against a secondary server to gain another agenda, putting him at 6 points to my 3.  Unfortunately, we ran out of time and I conceded the game to him. 

For a card game where I built what amounted to a secure server farm, the game was surprisingly fun.  I did make a few stupid moves, but it was my first time playing, next time will be better (indeed, I handily won my next two games using this deck).  As for understanding the terms, I've played the RPG Shadowrun for years, and I've read Philip K. Dick, so there was nothing here that I hadn't encountered before.

The card art is nice.  The symbols on the cards are easy enough to read and identify.  I like the theme too.  But this is a game I would never own.  Chalk it up to playing Magic for years... I'm burned out on card games, even living card games where I don't have to constantly update to new cards.  But if someone brings this to the table, I won't turn it away.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I never could get into Magic, and always felt confused/frustrated at the mechanics. Android: Netrunner scratches the itch that Magic could not, and I LOVE it.

Pros:
- Replayability: you can play as several different corporations or runners, each with styles of offense and defense. If one doesn't suit your personality, try another!
- Depth: Holy moses. The level of depth here is great! There are an infinite number of combinations you can get in your hand, and you're never sure what your opponent will do next. Runners can surprise you with enhanced runs you didn't expect. Corps can lay traps that entice runners to their doom. It is a game of feints, bluffs, and aggression, and it works phenomenally.
- Flair: This game is BEAUTIFUL. The artwork and construction are top-notch, and they really help sell you on the theme. You FEEL like a corp or runner in a sci-fi Shadowrun-type world, and it's a blast.
- LCG: You can buy the base set and be good to go. No Magic-style constant purchasing of new cards. What you get in the box is all you need to enjoy the game, as it should be.

Cons:
- Learning Curve: The key to enjoying this game is investing the time to understand it. Newbies will be wary and overwhelmed. Coax them through it step by step, and watch some YouTube videos illustrating how the game works. Once they see a few rounds, they'll get it. The rulebook is acceptable, but not fantastic. YouTube will fill in the gaps. Still, this is not Carcasonne or Love Letter. I've played A:NR many times, and I still find myself looking up rules.

I highly recommend it, if you can invest the time to get through the initial rule-shock.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2 player asymmetrical living card game. It's deadly and tense, and evolves every month.

Otherwise a very solid game and what i like most about it is the asymmetrical setup. I like the deck building mechanic and most things other people love about the game too. But the expansion madness is a big minus.

RATING: 7
A very cool and pretty unique theme with great looking cards.  One player plays the evil corporation trying to implement agendas and the other player plays a "runner" -- sort a computer hacker -- who tries to invade the servers, break through the defenses, and steal the agendas.  Not really a good guy in this.  Fun system and very hip.  Being a living card game instead of a collectible card game increases this rating by about 6 points.

RATING: 7
Android Netrunner is a game that did the impossible in my mind. It made me say there was a card game that surpassed Magic the Gathering for me even when I was trying to keep Magic as my top card game. It's asymmetrical play is totally unique as of now for such games and the Poker element of bluff and bait is much more involved than any other card game, meaning looking at your opponent and his body tendencies are a element of play too.  
Downside is it is harder to learn than the other card games as to the asymmetrical factions and cost long run for a successful LCG game like Netrunner can become expensive to keep up with the competitive curve and buy all the new cards.

RATING: 9

The game itself is set in a future digital universe, where hackers, called runners are trying to steal precious data from the Corporation's servers. The game rules are quite different for the two sides, which dillutes the sometimes monotonous gameflow of LCG-s. The artwork is one of the best I have seen. It is surely a must have game.

RATING: 8
Asymmetrical, smart, tense, funny, thematic... There are very few downsides to ANR, and most of them (like the ever-expanding card pool) are blessings in disguise.  Even just the core set has a ton of potential for deckbuilding, but chances are this game will sink its hooks into you and you will want to buy at least a few data packs.  If you don't have a partner in mind, look around your local area for a play group.

Highly recommended for any fan of L/CCGs, cyberpunk, 2-player card games, bluffing, or asymmetry. 

NOTE: I am now looking to sell off my entire ANR collection, current through Order & Chaos. Organized in two binders.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I am attracted to the look and feel of this game. I loved NEUROMANCER and am drawn to both conceptions of 'living' in cyberspace and the tension between the goals of corporations and those of hackers. Although the FFG aesthetic is a bit cartoonish, it still carries enough of the tropes of cyberpunk for me to want to invest in the game. 

Unfortunately, the mechanics kill it for me. As a system, I think the underlying action-point structure nicely marries some of the aesthetics of the genre. It's balanced enough as you feel like you have options but aren't sure if you are being efficient enough until you know what your opponent is trying to do. Unfortunately, instead of making a complete game, you have to continually buy cards from FFG to keep up with the metagame. 

The overall dynamic means the game plays you. If you play this at the competitive level you must continually pay to play decks that give you a chance. If you play this casually you will eventually fall into rote strategies in known matchups. I don't see a meaningful difference between the meta-dynamics of this game and Collectable Card Games. Intellectually, you are chasing your tail, and financially, you are a sucker.  

I don't think you should buy this game. As someone who played A LOT of tournament [thing=463][/thing] and [thing=13293][/thing], the LCG model destroys games by making them cost several hundred dollars and an arms race played out as a series of 'take that' deck construction surprises. 

I'D RATHER WE PLAYED: [thing=43022][/thing]. You pay upfront for a complete game and can master a character over time. The relationship between bluffing and valuation is more fluid and personal to the players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Vote for pure hatred of all things LCG / CCG. And because its top ten ranking is a ridiculous fanboy byproduct... I will never understand how this, Mage Knight, or Eclipse are top 10. The other seven games, I can see why people would rank them highly (and I only like half of them at best). And even Eclipse and Mage Knight, I can almost see it in that fuzzy magic-eye puzzle sort of way, if I turn my head upside-down and squint really hard. Are people just ranking it based on how much money game stores are making off of it?

RATING: N/A
2 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I wanted to like, heck even love Android Netrunner. The core game is so completely unbalanced, there are entire websites dedicated to unscrewing it. The game's base core gameplay is probably fun if the corporation had any power whatsoever. 

I tried this game between two worlds-topping decks and the Runner wins every time due to horrific action economy and infinite ability to break ice with little trouble. Corps have no time to score hardly ever even if you try to force a window. Coming from someone who plays top level in MtG and other TCGs, this is ridiculous. I checked data someone compiled on over 44,000 games in the Netrunner scene and Runners win 10% more games than Corps even controlling for skill (pitted against each other at high skill, and pitted each high skill faction separately against the average pool. Exactly the same results each time). This is only mitigated by 5% if the Corp has 3x of a certain card in their deck. Which they must actually draw to get that 5% extra failure rate instead of 10%. 

This is completely unacceptable bullshit and no one should play it. On top of this, Netrunner plays like a by-the-numbers game with barely any depth (i.e. the most intricate game of solitaire ever). I love bluffing games so this turned me on to it immediately. However, there is zero bluffing in Netrunner. To bluff, it requires multiple actions on the part of the Corp. To run, it usually requires the same or LESS from the Runner. Meaning you can't run their resources out unless you get purely lucky with card draw.

RATING: 5
Great for a LCG. Fantastic art, asymmetrical play (pro !), good factional theming, everything's great. Deckbuilding is moderately annoying. There are limited moneymaking cards, so one sees the same ones over and over. 

I do not like the DM versus player feel of the game. Runner is like a blind adventurer versus a gamemaster with an unknown power level. 

Many of our games were: runner saves up money for, probably, too long of a time. Makes a run. Picks the wrong server, gets pwned very hard, concedes. 

Me and some of my friends may just have the wrong personalities for this game. We've all played MtG, EPIC, Star Realms, the Star Wars TCG, and plenty of other card games.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Update 8/7/2015: Score increased due to increased card variety. The anti-climatic commentary was addressed by cards in the first cycle.  

12/26/2013: Fun little game, but more often than not it plays a bit anti-climatically. The core design flaw is a lack of "instant" cards, so unexpected swings rarely happen (i.e. you can see a success or failure from a great distance, so a lot of the tension goes out of the game). 

Thematically, it's a 10. Rating is solely based on play with the core. 

...

My rating has gone up since I originally purchased the core, in part due to the additions from the first two cycles (at the time of this writing we're three card packs into the second cycle, with the second box set on the horizon). 

Even if the cards didn't open the door to a multiplicity of strategic options, the game gets a boost due to its speed of play. It really lends itself well to an organic sense of play development--sessions are fast enough that one can readily tweak between sessions.

My girlfriend and I have taken to tweaking often, and playing only to our personal meta. After making a major change, we play a few sessions with our new decks, then switch to see if the other can do better, if it seems to be a poor design, or worse.

RATING: 9
Netrunner is a great game, though plagued by a few systemic issues - mostly that people hivemind really hard on the meta, and that it can have extremely high variance (though I'm not sure how it compares to Magic: the Gathering's variance which can be pretty nasty sometimes).  It's got solid mechanics, fantastic theme, and good gameplay that doesn't take too long - a winning combination right there.  On the other hand, I haven't had quite as much time for deckbuilding recently...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2

Just initially exploring this, and with just the premade decks, but it's a very fun, if somewhat complex, game of bluffing and gamesmanship.

There's certainly card draw luck, and there may not be quite so much bluffing on the Corp's side of things (advanced items will ... *frequently* ... be agendas), but it's very fun on both sides, whether trying to get the right ICE in place on the right servers, trying to plug all the leaks that come about, or as the Runner, getting a rig set up (see? I'm using game terminology!) with just the right breakers and cash to bust in on a server you think might have something.

The rules are terrible and make it really hard, I feel, to truly understand the flow and the various timing matters (when certain things can be rezzed or not).

Oh, wait, FFG.

RATING: 9
I used to have this as an 8, just because it was tough to find people to play it with. This game is hateful towards new players. My first several plays of this game ended in what I'd call "Cheesy" ways. I straight up die to Neural Katana, my opponent loses because I draw agendas off the top, and so on...

Once you understand the card pool, and are able to more accurately assess the risks of certain actions like running unprepared, or leaving a server unprotected, these "Cheesy" wins can very nearly vanish... but for a new player they can make the game seem pointless.

That's what kept this from a 9 for so long. I put in the time to understand the card pool, so now I think I "get" the game. Your mileage may vary.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Small backstory about my history with card gaming.  Back in 1994, I started playing Magic: The Gathering.  I played that on and off until about 2002 or so.  It was fun, I played competitively for a while and had some high value cards/decks (Moxen, Lotus, etc).  Shortly after that, I picked up the Star Wars CCG from Decipher (which I collected feverishly and qu.  This game was far more complex, but way more fun. I liked that the two sides (Light side and Dark side) played differently and would go after different objectives.  Fast forward to now.  Netrunner comes out, offers a very asymmetric playstyle and completely eliminates the collectible aspect of card gaming (which was always a thorn in my side, especially the older I get... I just can't keep up with the card singles market).  I love the cyberpunk theme, it's fairly easy to teach, and it's (relatively) inexpensive to keep up with the game!  One of these days I may even start showing up at tournements!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.33
At first I was skeptical I didn't like the graphics compared to the old version. I was scared how different factions will influence the game. But after checking 2 different runners and 2 different corp decks, I'm really impressed. It is still same old Netrunner, that I was loving to play 15 years ago.

For minus:

- I still prefer the old art
- Cyberpunk 2020 theme is much more interesting then Android one

Pluses:

- Different factions for Runner and Corp
- Deck creation and influence
- Small tweaks making the game more fluent to play

For now it's 9/10, but it may increase. I'm still exploring only base set.

Update after 4 games

Score goes up to 9.33. 

I've played with, or against all factions. The game play is great, the factions are way different . I like this game more and more. Core set is enough for casual players, especially that all factions seems to be balanced.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'll leave my prior review and comments below; however, ANR has taken a turn for the worst in the most recent cycle and the community and meta has become stagnant and toxic in the face of the MWL. That being said I would not reduce my rating except for this simple issue: ANR now gets to a point it feels either the corp or the runner hits a critical mass and cannot be stopped. Gone are the days you had to pick and choose when you put an agenda down or made a run making the game less of a risk and more of a surety once you hit a certain point.

I love this game. It plays uniquely to many card games like magic due to the asymmetrical roles of the corporation and runners. In addition it has a very strategic and almost Eurogame feel due to the reliance on economic power to fund or defend runs. The game has a thriving and helpful community as well that extends to card and board gamers. Also since its a living card game constant changes are created in the meta through new cards and IDs.

The biggest downside to the game is the initial buy in for new players since the game has been out for 3 years and releases quarterly data packs. This can be imposing and does keep some players from getting the game. That being said with 1 core set and maybe 2-3 datapacks ($60 total) you can and will have success in most local groups. This is at its core a game of skill and bluffs. The best cards and the best deck will get you nowhere without it and many unorthodox decks win tournaments when properly piloted.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played 2X at Origins.

Starting my rating at a 6 and it likely will go up as I get to understand the nuances of the Corp/Runner better, along with getting into the card drafting mechanism.  

Update 7/3/2013:  Played 3 games as the runner and now starting to get a feel for the game. Moving up to a 7 (probably will be an 8 after I play a few more games).

RATING: 10
I was a fan of the original CCG Netrunner.  This game kept the core of the original, but added several balancing touches (non-blind traces being a big one).  I personally like the addition of the identities, and the cleanup of the card design (and the update to the art).  It's an asymmetrical, non-randomly collectible card game with elements of bluffing, risk taking, and just great gameplay.  Couldn't ask for more out of a game.

RATING: 9
Great, great, great.  Took a base game I already loved and revitalized the market for it in a better-produced package.  Easily the most successful "FFG treatment" of a property that I've ever seen.  I have fun playing it, building it, reading and talking about it.  To that end, it's probably my favorite "solo" game too. Really took a dive in terms of meta management, various forms of defiance. Worst of all, probably, is the refusal to work a "living core" definition into rotations. Gotta drop from a 10 to a 9.

RATING: 9.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I never played the original Netrunner, and then played this with a friend who was much more excited to try it than I was.  I actually hated my first game - a lot of unintuitive mechanics and jargon, and a overall feeling of helplessness from some terrible rules explanation.

Then, I was reading the rules afterward: "What, you mean scoring agendas doesn't clear the server of all cards, including ICE? And I can install ICE on an empty server?"  (Like I said, really bad rules explanation)

Then actually went out and bought it, having hated my first game.  Love it, it really is a great game once you play it right.  Still got a pretty high learning barrier, but overcoming that, you'll find an asymmetric card game that is highly strategic and shockingly well balanced.  Playable out of the box with only one set with workable prebuilt decks and sensible card distribution (though I want more Corporate Troubleshooters...), which is better than diving in to deck building right away.

RATING: 9
1/28/17 - I'm finally getting some repeated play in, and this game is a lot of fun.  I'm playing with someone who is going up the learning curve the at the same time and it's a much more enjoyable experience than learning against someone who has a few hundred plays more experience than you do.

1/24/13 - I do like the asymmetrical aspect, and I do like the theme.  Right now I just know enough to be dangerous, mostly too myself.

Rating may go up with more plays.  There's certainly a lot here, but two player card games may not be my thing.  We will see.

Cards are thin.  Sleeving them is the first thing that I did to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
So much good stuff.  Love the freedom provided by the click system.  Love the ability to "make runs" on the opponent's hand, deck, and discard pile--simultaneously fishing for points while also gaining information.  Love the seamless integration of theme with gameplay. Love deckbuilding!  Brings me back to my MtG days (for a fraction of the price.)

While I do enjoy the mindgames involved with ICE/agendas, I'm a bit fearful that they will feel too random after multiple plays ("oops I lost a coinflip, I guess I lost the game.")  I need more plays under my belt to see if this is an actual problem.

Not looking to get into competitive play, due to the price factor.  A bit disappointed to see how overpowered some of the expansion cards are.  Still, I think the core set can provide a lot of entertainment with friendly play.

RATING: 8
Great asymmetrical game. A little too many tokens and bafmodads for my taste but the core game play is pretty damn fantastic. Suffers from cards being unplayable via restrictive card costs just like MTG. So many cards that would have great implications for a game but can't be used in any form of competitive deck. Oh wells, nothing is perfect but still one of the best card based games out there.

Marking this down to an 8 because while I think it is a great game, it never hits the table. You have to have players invested in this game to find it enjoyable. The pre-cons are just not strong enough.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Cyberpunk. This is the game that does it best, and seeing as cyberpunk is *the* best, well, what does that say about this game?

Cyberpunk has always been about asymmetry, about flexibility and inventiveness versus sheer resources and power. While that can sometimes turn on its head in this game, the core mechanics emphasize the material imbalance between the sides quite splendidly.

I am certainly going to subscribe to this LCG.

RATING: 9
Incredibly good card game. Would expect nothing less from Richard Garfield... but frankly I wasn't prepared for how stressful each game of this would be.

The art on the cards is nothing short of amazing. 

As a corp, figuring out ways to bait the runner into heading for honeypot remote servers is nothing short of the fun of being a cylon in BSG.

As a runner, striking the balance between caution and speed is a great acrobatic act.

Ugh, I doooon't want to buy another card game. Someone stop me.

RATING: 10
What an amazing game! Get over the initially WTF lexicon (which actually makes it even more thematic) and a true gaming joy is unlocked. The theming is omnipresent, engrossing and bound inextricably to the mechanics, the asymmetrical player experience is so refreshing and intriguing, the artwork is amazing, the cards/combos are interesting and extremely varied, the deck building is brilliant and there are very different strategies to victory. MTG is a truly great game (once you have got a decent card pool..) but I ditched all my cards once I discovered Android:Netrunner. I can't recommend this enough.

RATING: 8
Vajon mit tudhat ez a játék, útban a dobogó felé? Nagy várakozással ültem le, és nem csalódtam! A téma és a felépítés is nagyon egyedi, teljesen mást tud a két oldal. A cégnek szoftvereket kell telepíteni és bevédeni, a hackernek meg fell kell törni a cég dolgait. Nem látom még át a játékot, de tömérdek taktikai lehetőség látszik első pillantásra is, és már most is látom, mennyire izgalmas tud lenni: vajon győzelmi pontot szerzek, vagy tűzfalba futok? Főleg a cégnek hatalmas szabadsága van, rengeteg féle stratégia kínálkozik. A hacker szerepe talán egy kicsit egyértelműbb. A nyelvfüggőség nem vészes, a kártyákon elég sok szöveg csak körítés, a lényeg gyakran csak 1-2 szó. A szabály fél óra alatt elmondható, és egy parti is lemegy kb. ugyanennyi idő alatt. Egyetlen bajom a játékkal, hogy havonta kijön hozzá egy kieg, ebben valószínűleg nem kívánok elmerülni, az alapban is van több cégpakli és több hackerpakli, de az biztos, hogy a kiegekkel szinte végtelen lesz a variálhatóság. A játék amúgy is elég drága a tartalomhoz képest.
---
Engem idegesít a játékban az, amikor egy sima kártyahúzáson dől el 3 pont. Ha kihúzza a kezemből, esetleg meg is nyerte az egészet, ha nem húzza ki, én nyerek... Ha a húzópaklimból húzza ki, az még röhejesebb. Oké tudom, be kell védeni magam, de ez nem mindig olyan egyszerű:) És azt is elismerem, hogy egy ilyen rövid játéknál ennyi belefér.
---
A sok hibája ellenére is kezd beszippantani... Érik, hogy az első 6 kieget megveszem. Zseniális ez a játék, de még 100 parti után is amatőr mazsola leszek szerintem:(

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
LCGs are not board games, they're a racketeering scheme.  For that it deserves a '1' rating.  

Any 'game' that allows you to BUY your way to an advantage over your opponent is cheating, pure and simple.  Imagine playing chess where your opponent gets to buy an extra knight or bishop at the start of the game. Or a boxing match where one guy gets to be 20 pounds heavier and wear brass knuckles under his gloves.  That's what LCGs do.

That said, the idea is a good one (hence the 5 rating).  They just need to make it a static 'game' where each player 'builds' their deck at the start of the game, with the components inside THAT game box.  Do this and the game warrants an 7.5 or 8 rating.  

 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I didn't play the original Netrunner, but of course felt the desire to discover what made that game so great and hyped.
This remake is pretty close to the original, they say, with only some deckbuilding rules (stolen from Reiner Knizia's Blue Moon) added to remove the problems the old versiod had (I heard).

The game is quite intriguing, balanced even if very asymmetrical, and I can see it originating a very good tournament scene.

The design is clever, while not very innovative (it's almost 20-years old, after all...): it's a game of action efficency, where the players can unmake what the opponent has done, and the most efficient chain of plays will win.
The mechanic represents in a fine manner some sort of Gibsonesque cyberpunk world (a futuristic world as seen by an 80s writer, quite vintage), while the artwork and card layout wonderfully convey the mind towards the exact same imaginary.

After a few dozen plays, I can surely say this is my favorite customizable card game ever. A masterpiece.
I currently find myself continuously thinking about deck tweaking and strategies. Can't play it enough...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Card distribution inside Fantasy Flight LCGs core sets is starting to piss me off, but Netrunner is so good I had to buy a second set for deck building purposes.
Is it really necessary? For casual play one set may be enough, but if you play a card game without building decks, why do you play? With these games, half the fun comes before actually playing!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial Impression: For a card game, this is wonderfully asymmetrical. It has a great Shadowrun-esque cyberpunk theme where the console cowboy is running a Corp's systems in order to steal valuable data. The players' decks are customizable and I suspect half the fun is coming up with the "optimal" deck for your playstyle.

10 Plays: This game definitely has the "one more game" appeal, as the duel between corp and hacker can be short. Knowing the capabilities of your deck are essential, as is knowing the preferences of your opponent's deck. There's definitely depth to this game that I haven't even begun to explore.

20 Plays: I'm beginning to experiment with constructing my own decks. I'm finding deck tweaking a challenge as I don't have regular opponents. Still, it's interesting to see the ramifications of the tweaks. I've taken to playing a solitaire variant in order to test my decks. I've observed that datapacks are not a necessity for casual play. That's a good thing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

FAVORITE TWO PLAYER HEAVY WEIGHT CUSTOMIZABLE CARD GAME

2 Players / 45 Min / Weight: 3.34
Type: Customizable

Really well designed asymmetrical 2 player card game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The asymmetrical mechanics of this game are very well thought out. The out-of-the-box depth and subtlety of the game play make Android: Netrunner one that you want to play over and over. There's always something to figure out, always a strategy to develop. The components are of the highest quality. The artwork, while much of it is recycled from other Fantasy Flight Games titles in the Android universe, is high quality and genre-appropriate. That goes a long way in selling the universe in which the action of this game takes place. FFG does a great job of supporting the game through rules updates and clarifications where appropriate. A:NR is a living card game (LCG), and as such, FFG has the opportunity to further expand on the base concepts presented here. They have done so with the first seven expansions (Data Packs), and I expect that they will continue to do so with future expansions. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Scratches my MTG itch.  Fantastic game.  Lots of depth.  I also have a group of players who like to play it as much as I do which, itself is a positive feedback loop earning this a 10.

RATING: 6
Ok as a game, but the barrier to entry for new players is excessively high from both a gameplay and cash perspective. The fact you need three core sets to even be remotely competitive with a seasoned player is ludicrous. The LCG model is fine but there needs to be considerable design changes from makers of these games so that new players feel welcome and engaged. Look at Smash Up - you can compete with any player using any expansion just with the core set. Netrunner, by way of contrast asks for £90 on three copies of the same box just for single copies of San San grid. Nope. Sold it and won't go back.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I played some [thing=463]Magic[/thing] in the past and was not sure if a game with just 2 factions (although multiple "characters" per faction) can offer a similar variety. Especially since [thing=463]MtG[/thing] adds new abilities to the game each year (season?).

But man, I'm really impressed with this game! Your play-style not only changes depending on the hacker (runner) you play, but also depending on the MegaCorp you're running against.

Additionally I really like the theme of hackers and technics and stuff - a theme that we rarely see in board games.

Being a software engineer myself, the flavour text is the icing on the cake. It made me chuckle on various occasions (and my wife was immediately terrified as the hacker :D)

RATING: 9
UPDATE - [2.26.17] Top tier game.  Deep and engaging deck building.  Asymmetrical game of hide and seek between the Mega Corps. and the plucky Runners.  My favorite 1 v 1 deck building LCG.

[10.10.16] Updated Netrunner Collection List

[1.15.16] Netrunner Collection:

- Core Set
- Creation & Control
- Honor & Profit
- Order & Chaos
- Data & Destiny
- Genesis Cycle 6 of 6 Data Packs
- Spin Cycle: 2 of 6 Data Packs (OM, TC)
- Lunar Cycle 2 of 6 Data Packs (tSP, FC)
- San San Cycle 1 of 6 Data Packs (tV)
- Flashpoint Cycle 2 of 6 Data Packs (23s, BM) 

LIKES - Android universe.  Awesome asymmetry.  Challenging deck building.  Variety in factions for both the Runner and Corp. sides.  Bluffing.  Dripping in theme.  

DISLIKES - Non-gamers, non-deck builders may have a difficult game grasping rules and strategies.  

WHY A 9.5 RATING BASED ON BGG RATING DEFS? - This is an "outstanding" game.  Will I "always" want to play it - time will tell.  That is why I can't give it a 10.  I love deck building games.  I love bluffing in games where you are playing your opponent, and not JUST the game mechanics.  Great depth of strategy.  Great theme.  This game is fun fun fun.

RATING: 7.3
The jargon is annoying but not a deal breaker as it doesnt take that long to know what everything is and the card pool is not that large in the core set so you will quickly learn what it all means.  Lots of positives, decent amount of theme, deck construction options, good amount of cards and factions in the core set, different from other dueling, faction based card games, bluffing, tension etc.....but at the end of the day there is a lot of luck e.g. run on A rather than B, oh your were successful... run on the deck...oh you got an agenda.  Doesnt grab me in the way lots of other 2 player games do but going to give it a few more tries

RATING: 8
Netrunner is a tremendously interesting asymmetrical card game. The corporation and the runner both have constant meaningful choices to make, and the rules they play by are almost completely different.
I just wish it wasn't an LCG - the core mechanic is fantastic, and I would be totally fine with Netrunner as a standalone, non-deckbuilding game.
I'm usually up for a draft, and I have my cards arranged in a draft-ready set.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If you're prepared to forgive a cyberpunk theme that has aged poorly alongside the rise of the real Internet, there's a fascinating two-player game waiting for you here.  One player takes the role of the corporation, the other the role of a determined hacker, and though each has very different goals and methods of achieving them, the game is quite well balanced.

Regardless of which side you're on, risk management is the key to victory.  Move too conservatively and you'll get pwned by a player willing to take some chances.  Be too aggressive and you'll get clocked by a player who can sucker you into wasting resources on fights you can't (or don't want to!) win.

It's not perfect.  The mechanic of drawing from a single undifferentiated deck can make things awfully swingy; an unlucky corp player who doesn't pull enough good defensive programs really can't do much, and a few lucky fishing expeditions by the hacker can win the game.  And the deck-building aspect is too limited to be satisfying (at least out of the box -- I'm hoping expansions will correct that).  Even so, this one's a keeper, well worth checking out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A near perfect game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
C
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
There is not much I don't like about this game. I love the theme, I love the asymmetrical play, I love the bluffing and the artwork is great too. The android universe has been close to my heart ever since I played the boardgame. Reprinting and setting Netrunner, a game I've been eager to get into for ages, in this universe is like a dream coming true.

The added factions also help the game by limiting deckbuilding and thereby keeping overpowered combos to a minimum. Everything comes at a price when building your deck. Also the actual playing of the game is more important than the deckbuilding. This really is a game of skill. Unlike other games a bad player with a good deck will have a hard time against a good player with a bad deck. This is mostly because you play your opponent and not your deck. Bluffing, risk management and resource management are very prominent. And games are never dull because the game rewards risks. Playing passively will almost always mean you lose.

The core set is enough to get you started and will give you a ton of replayability. The expansions are great to add more variation and deckbuilding options. The only thing I'm not crazy about is the LCG format. I'd much rather have a big expansion once a year or something like that. But the game is so good I'm willing to let this one go.

Gameplay: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::star:
Fun/Social: :star::star::star::star::star:
Components: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Rules: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
-> games-kir Paul.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game feels finely tuned. Every decision is important.  The asymmetric nature forces each player to have unique strategies rather than trying to have the optimum strategy.  This game implements the secret unit deployment mechanic in a unique yet elegant way which coupled with the tension of limited resources intensifies the importance of each action.

RATING: 10
Probably the best card game ever designed and while the LCG model has its problems, they have yet to screw it up, even if I personally would like them to slow down the release schedule.

Overall, this is my favourite game of alltime and a game that I deeply regret not being able to play more often.

You can play it out of the box as it is and have loads of fun, but it becomes truly awesome when you start to build your own decks.

---

As of 2016, this has dropped to my #2 game due to it not being played enough and me falling behind with the much too hectic release schedule. A shame.

RATING: 7
Six plays through with my brother and we feel like we're getting the hang of everything now.  I'm still feeling like, at this point, the order in which I draw cards has a lot more to do with the outcome than my decisions.  We both expect that to change as we start building decks (which we haven't done yet) and get a better feel for the strengths and weaknesses of everything.  I've rated this a 7.5 so far, but I expect that to go up as we get into deck-building and more plays of the game.

I've already bumped this to an 8.  The more we play, the better it gets.  We can already feel ourselves getting pulled in a bit and ready for expansions to spice things up.  This easily has the potential to go a bit higher, but we'll see how it goes.

I've since pushed this back down to a 7 because I can't see getting into this too much.  It's really good stuff and a game I won't embrace as much as so many have.

RATING: 10
Outstanding. Always want to play.

You can't really judge just how good this game is until you have had repeated plays and started getting into constructing your own decks.

Putting together a runner and a corp deck, working out the synergies between cards, agonising over what to leave out. Then meeting up with your mate and going head-to-head not knowing what they are going to throw at you. Bluffs, deception, suspicion, nasty surprises, twists and turns, and heaps of tension.

You don't need to have a massive pool of cards. The 1.1.1.1 format is great way to play.

RATING: 9
Wonderful game. Extremely tense with beautifully designed game mechanics. The balancing of this game is out of this world. Some cards feel so overpowered, until you realize that there is an easy counter against them. 

The game takes 20-90 minutes to play, which is perfect for quick gaming sessions. Finished in 30 minutes? Let's play again! 

Not only is this one of the best games I know in terms of game mechanics, it is also extremely thematic. When playing a game of Netrunner I am feeling like a corporation that tries to protect its agendas with everything they have to offer, while my opponent tries to hack into my systems, exploiting every little mistake I make. 

Last but not least, the artwork in this game is astounding. I would hang each of these images on my wall if they were poster sized. 

Highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Whenever a game is dripping with theme - that is, whenever its rules fit with the theme and make so much sense their thematic inspiration or explanation can be easily found - it arouses my interest, no matter how it actually plays: but if it even happens to have good mechanics too, then I know it’s bound to rock.

Android Netrunner is such a game: it combines a solid theme (actually one I’m not really interested in: cyberpunk has never been my cup of tea but still) with thematically befitting cards and rules insomuch that playing it really feels like trying to hack (or prevent that attack) a corporate server in a cyberpunk setting.

Certainly not the stuff my dreams are made of, nonetheless a challenge the game develops with thematic richness and some allure too: way to go for a collectable/livng card game!

RATING: 9
There's not much I can say about Netrunner that hasn't already been said. I got into the original Netrunner when it was still being published, and although it was arguably broken (e.g. the Kati Jones of the time didn't have a "once per turn" limit), it still was a fascinating and at the time completely unique game.

What FFG has managed to do with it since the reboot has been extraordinary, particularly with the introduction of factions to develop unique playstyles and help balance the game. They also managed to give some much needed love to their Android universe, which I hope continues to be developed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Gave this a shot with a friend over the weekend. Overall, interesting, but not really the sort of game I like to play. The theme falls away pretty quickly while playing this and you just want to know what a card does. I think the game information could be displayed with a little more attention to intuitive understanding and a bit less cyber-jargon. I'm sure if I owned a copy and read the rules, I'd be a bit more charitable on these points. It seems that until you can get into the rhythm of play for your particular side, you can be at the mercy of the cards for the first two or three turns. I like that the base game comes with four corporations and three hackers to compete against one another.

Update: Have played a few more times and I really don't care for it. As a game, my problems are what I've already stated and I'll add a strictly personal one: I really can't get into the theme. Oh, I understand it's hackers and business networks playing a deadly game of cat-and-mouse with one another, but there's no one to root for, hiss at, or identify with. It's one of the few really thematic games I've played where the "story" leaves me asking, "So what?"

RATING: N/A
2P, Hard, Short, Fun-competitive, guessing, puzzle, bluffing

Corporation vs Hacker in dystopian theme. Theme implemented perfectly in cards. A lot of terminology that makes the game seem more complex than it is. Only as complex as you make your deck. 
THE BEST competitive card game. Asymmetrical: Runner has limited knowledge and corporation can bluff and punish. Wtf moments everywhere, opponent will hate you. Limitless potential for different playstyles.

01/02/17
Okay there are so many IDs to play. I think it'll be good to write down what I would actually enjoy playing and would most likely want to play on this information page.

RUNNER MINI-FACTION: I thoroughly enjoy playing the Apex Spyware using Spy Camera, Reaver, Chop Bot, and Wasteland to help Apex draw cards and earn income.  In addition, with the introduction of Black Orchestra and MK Ultra, Apex does not mind having these two ice-breakers installed face-down and then uses them as fodder for Chop Bot to draw a card or remove a tag or to have Heartbeat using them to cancel damage.  I have to be careful with Ark Lockdown though.  However, I don't think the Corp will play this card just to remove a single breaker.

There are potential to make variations in this deck such as replacing R&D Interface with The Turning Wheel and Rumour Mill with Employee Strike.  Also, there can be so much that this deck can do once its card draw and income generation engine is set up.

ADAM RUN SOMETIMES - My next choice will be Adam Run Sometimes.  With Finding the Truth as one of the directive, Adam can start off without the severe limitation of having his hand reduced by two from Safety First as this will make him quite vulnerable to the many 'kill' deck around.

SUNNY - Unfortunately is too slow for me and will most probably defeated by prison deck.

CRIMINAL FACTION
ANDROMEDA - Two decks I most likely like to play is Andromeda Takeshi's Castle.  However, I am not sure whether I am comfortable with the deck build that does not incorporate Inside Job and Same Old Thing.  It seems to me that this deck is build mostly to counter NBN's traces.

Though the other option of playing Andromeda is playing a Stealth Andro deck using The Supplier but this will goes contrary to the Criminal playstyle which should be more aggro rather than taking time to build.

GEIST - Siege Engine Geist is a puzzle to me and I am not sure how he stands up against the current meta especially when going against Jinteki prison deck like Potato, Meatball and Alcatraz where these decks play very little else.  Most often this deck will have 1 Same Old Thing and 1 Levy.  So if these two cards are 'sniped', then it would most often be GG for Geist.  Maybe I should I put 2 Same Old Thing instead of 1.

Nevertheless, I think this deck will still be enjoyable with a gradual build-up and occasional offensive playstyle.

LEELA - I think I would reserve in playing Leela deck on jinteki.net where I prefer the Breakerless Job-Cross-Hook-Apocalypse deck.  It is often fun to play this deck as most players did not expect that it has no ice breakers.

For other Leela build, I may have to most likely experiment them first to see whether I like it.

So I think the three ID for criminal I would be focusing on playing will be Andromeda, Geist, and Leela.  Ian, Ken, Fisk, and Silhoutte seems "meh" to me.  But I think Ian can still be fun but I would have to take time to see what build I like to play or how to construct a deck with his ID.

ANARCH FACTION

SHAPER FACTION
ELLE "SMOKE" SCOVAK - A more straightforward deck that use Stealth programme.  I will build one before Quorum and another after Quorum where the latter I will include Sifr and Aaron Maroon.

HAYLEY PITCHFORK

EXILE AND THE PROFESSOR - I probably don't get Exile and the Professor and even with latter having the deck called the Sorcerer Supreme, I feel some reluctance to play it physically.  It requires you to remember what programmes you have.  To play Professor competently, you need to be able to remember your programme suite well enough to know what are those programmes that you should tutor.

HAYLEY DRYPER DECK - For some reasons I am not a fan of this Shaper Deck you require to take time to set up.  However, I can see the potential of this deck when the Runner can drop a Rumour Mill and the make Keyhole Dig multiple time using Hyperdriver. Most likely I will play this on J.net instead on physical space.

WEYLAND
BLUE SUN - I often like to play Blue Sun and you have to think of the option of which Ice to take back into your hand and gain credits and when you should actually take it back.  With the availability of Consulting Visit,  for the total cost of 3, it becomes easier for Blue Sun to tutor for Oversight AI andplay it to rez an expensive Ice.

However, I must always remember that I cannot/would not be able to use Consulting Visit and Boom! together in  one single turn due to both cards require an additional click to play.  Nevertheless, I need to be aware that I can still play Midseason Replacement especially when the Runner is low on credit and I have Boom! in my hand especially now many Runners don't include Plascrete Carapace.

Nevertheless, the era of Blue Sun may come to an end with the availability of Sifr.  Also, with Aaron Maroon from the Quorum datapack, players will have to carefully calculate how many tags they can land/place on the Runner unless Aaron can be first trashed.

JINTEKI
POTENTIAL UNLEASHED - I like the Prison Potatoes and Meatball deck and seems there are several variants for such deck.  The keycards will often be Breaker Bay (which I have to share with the HB deck), Hostile Takeover, Hokusai Grid, Friends in High Places, Ark Lockdown, Shock!, Bio-Ethics Committee and Jacskson Howard.

There seems to be two kind of Prison deck.  One that use the Medical Health Clinic where Runner would often not trashed but PU does not mind the Runner have more cards in hand who use Medical Health Clinic as the objective is just to 'snipe' as many cards as possible from cards and trash the top card from the stacks to cripple the Runner.

The other variant of Prison Deck will be Alcatraz that use Replicating Perfection ID but with more option for ice consideration.  This should utilise Excalibur.

PALANA - Another ID I like to play is Jimmy John Fast Food that the Grail Ice and operate to build up fast and score quickly behind an or some Ice.  It requires Caprice and Batty but due to the threat of Rumor Mill, there is a need for this ID to include some current like Cerebral Static.

NOTE: I haven't had the the chance to play Jinteki PU physically.

NBN
MAKING NEWS - I want to play the Tracing the Doors deck.  However, without the current cards from Quorum I may have to adjust the build to include some other Agendas and Ice.  This deck is so 'bloody' annoying when pitted against non-trace competitive Runner ID as it often mess up your economy and making you poor from doing much things.

NEW ANGELES SOL - I like playing SoL but not sure how will it fare against the current meta especially when the new rule limit only the use of one Astroscript.

CONTROL THE MESSAGE - For some reasons, the decks using control the message fails to appeal to me.  Maybe I have yet to find the right ID.

SPARK - I will most likely like to play Spark Agency as the second NBN ID for casual play as the game is fun (but to some degree less annoying as compared to Making News Tracing the Door).  Will play this against newbies of who may be using core set decks.

HAAS-BIORIOD
HB: ENGINEERING THE FUTURE - I like to play Sandvich which primarily leverage on HB drip economy asset and Sandburg to increase the strengths of its Ice.  This deck will use NEXT Bronze, NEXT Silver, and Architect.  It may use Vanilla.  NEXT Gold is not advisable to include due to the threat of Sifr. Supported by Friends In High Places, this deck can bring back Ice which has been trashed by Runners.  With the later introduction of Sifr, I may want to put 1 Lotus Field.  Also a Turing will be good a include to protect the remote server.

HB: ARCHITECTS OF TOMORROW - I want to play Architect of Tomorrow because it very unique and it leverages on the set of Ice that are of Bioroid subtypes.

SUMMARY - THE ID I WANT TO PLAY
CRIMINAL: Andromeda, Geist, Leela (on J.net)
SHAPER: Smoke Stealth Deck, Hayley Pitchfork
MINI FACTION: APEX, Adam, forget Sunny

HAAS-BIOROID: HB:Etf Sandvich (a.k.a Friendscoat), HB AoT - Fallingwater
JINTEKI: Potential Unleashed - Prison Potatoes and Meatballs, Palana Fast Food, Replicating Perfection - Alcatraz
NBN: Making News - Tracing the Door, New Angeles SoL (on J.net), Spark for casual fun play
Weyland - Blue Sun, Gargarin (on J.net)

RATING: 6
While I appreciate the mechanics of this game, it feels a bit cat and mouse for me. One player (the cat/Corp) tries to trick the other player (the mouse/Runner) over and over again. Perhaps all decks don't feel this way, but I'm not overly interested in finding out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.75
An entertaining LCG that rewards clever play and gives the player a lot of options. Decent artwork and thematic play. A little hard to teach. Most games so far was very tense.

There are a few problems with A:NR:
 - Agenda distribution is highly random and may dictate how a game plays out
 - Ice often dictates Corp play, so you're very draw dependent in general.
 - As the runner you will require certain tools for certain situations, which makes you very draw dependent as well.

You can make your deck more reliable, but the core game decks clearly lack a certain stability and only with a lot more cards you get a decent reliable outcome, that allows for clearly strategic play. With 2 Cores and some extra cards it's already very good!

2pl
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Really enjoyed the first game. Second game left me feeling very defeated (but I was playing an experienced player!); I was the runner against the corporation. I'm sure I'd love it with more plays but the time investment of deck-building doesn't appeal to me. Also - $$$ for the expansion decks. Not as bad as CCG, but still a little bit of a turn-off to me. Love the theme and the art!

Edit: Something I have learned about myself: competitive deck building in this sort of directly confrontational mode is not really for me. Maybe it's the fact that, despite it being an LCG, the "serious" players still dump $$$ on this (2 cores, 2 of this Data Pack, 5 of these others) to get duplicates of the "best cards" to put into their deck. And I don't usually feel like I can go up against that.

Lowered to 5.5
Lowered to 4.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An amazing game. The mechanics are quite simple, but offer a good depth of strategy. Unlike some other card games, your chances of winning have less to do with 'drawing your power or combo cards", and more to do with how you play what you have. Since the Corp side plays their cards face down, the Runner has to guess / deduce where and when he needs to run. This opens the game up to a level of bluffing and mind games you don't see in many other games. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
El sistema es muy bueno, sólido, asimétrico y con una intensidad alta. Ambos jugadores están continuamente pensando en cuál será el siguiente movimiento del oponente.
PROBLEMA: Necesita las expansiones, así como tres copias de cada uno para tener las cartas buenas en el build.

NOTA: NOTABLE

RATING: 7.5
A good asymmetrical constructed-deck card game. Very thematic, with interesting choices every turn. The sides play very differently: the Corp is about bluffing and misdirection, while the Runner is about finding tools and reading the Corp player.

Suffers from the usual problem of such games: it's hard to find opponents with the same level of commitment. If you are more serious, you don't see much challenge; if your opponent is more serious, you can get stomped without having much fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I'd been holding off on rating this until I got a decent number of plays of this version under my belt.  With Area 42 (Aug 24) and TCEP (LaborDay weekend) finished, I have now played every OOB faction at least once (and a few many more times than once) and can finally drop in a comment.

This is now my 'go-to' 2 player game.  OOB this title is phenomenal and every person I've showed it to has been interested in playing more.  The experience is spectacular with the provided starter decks and even with the same faction v faction matchups, they didn't always play the same based on the shuffle.

I'll have more of an opinion on constructed play once I've had a chance to do so.

RATING: 9
07/24/2015: First play. The dense terminology and ruleset would normally be a turnoff, but about halfway through something started clicking and I could tell I would enjoy the game. Still don't really understand the rules and wouldn't be able to truly 'play' a game yet, but I definitely want to play again. 

I liked the truly asymmetrical aspect of the game, and the cards while a hodgepodge of types and abilities, seemed to fit well together due to the strong theme of the game. Dense but fun. Don't think I would enjoy too many expansions, there seems to be enough here even in just a base set... but I'm generally not an 'expansions' guy.

Update 09/04: bumped from 7.5 to 8 after getting 4 more plays in. Still very much in learning mode. 

Update 10/14: Up to 10 plays now. I love this game.

Update 10/17: Bumping to 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fantastic card game!

Because you have your actions and credit pool to juggle, it feels like there's more control in Netrunner than there is in Magic (I am by no means an experienced Magic player). I actually found Netrunner much easier to learn because it operates more like a board game than a CCG.

Love the variety, the asymmetry, the theme, the art...I literally can't imagine a better 'collectible' game to get into.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
2 | 60 min | 14+ | Richard Garfield, Lukas Litzsinger
Simply fantastic game. I love the theme, the game mechanisms, the asymmetric gameplay, the artwork... Not sure how far I will go with this since it is a CCG, but so far I am having a blast. The possibility of playing it online (OCTGN) is the ice on the cake.
--------------------------------
(August 2014) I never put any thoughts into it, but given the amount of time I have spent playing Netrunner, building decks, listening to podcasts, watching videos and generally  reading about the game, Netrunner has no doubt become my favorite game, even if that means less time for playing other games.
--------------------------------
(March 2016) The year began with so much work that my plays decreased dramatically and eventually stopped altogether. After missing 3 or 4 datapacks, I lacked the force of will to get myself back up to date and stopped buying and playing the game altogether. My decision to quit the game was also helped by the personnel changes in the design team and my dislike for the direction the meta was heading to. I still keep all my cards and might play again, but competitive play is unlikely to be an option for me at this point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is the perfect drug to wean you off of MtG once you realize you've spent more money than you should have on it. It ticks the boxes for me for a great card/deckbuilder game, rich in theme, and more or less very well balanced. The fact that it's a living card game and not a collectible card game is what puts it over the top for me. At a rate of one data pack a month (at it's fastest expansion release) this is more than reasonable an upkeep cost if you've migrated from Magic. One of my favorite games ever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
When I received some of the Jinteki cards were missing. Fortunately FFG sent me an entire other set of corporation cards which was pretty cool.

While I knew I had to wait, I picked up another corporation and tried to play it. The rulebook is rather difficult to get through, if you don't have someone who already knows how to play to teach you I wouldn't recommend picking this one up unless you are experienced in games of this nature and at sifting through rulebooks. My recommendation would be to watch the how to play videos online if you can't find a teacher.  

After all of the hard work to learn my wife wasn't really interested, it was too complex for her. So it went up for auction, away it went...

RATING: 10
Very rare to give such an easy 10/10.
The game's asymmetric nature coupled with well-themed pre-constructed decks helped in getting this established, as neither my GF nor me are experts on TCGs/LCGs.

At the same time, the expansion packs were cheap enough to coax us into buying while offering enough "temptation" to start looking into the customization process.

Finally found a game which works really well to be played between us two. And slowly evolving "my" deck adds a lot to it.

It's really surprising how well it balances, despite the sides being so different. And even the factions playing so different.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I'm still not sold on this, and I can't figure out why. I'm a huge fan of the Game of Thrones and Lord of the Rings LCGs, and I thought this would be a no-brainer. Ranked among the top games of all time? It's gotta be good, right?

Well, it's only okay. I far prefer being the runner, because as the corp I feel you don't have a whole lot to do on your turn. Half the time as the corp I feel like I'm either placing ICE over nothing, or laying down stupid cards that don't help me, while the runner simply goes after anything I haven't protected yet (I should mention that I am not good at the game yet and have still only played this a handful of times using the core set). I just feel like too much relies on luck. We'll keep trying.

UPDATE: 10 plays in. I am starting to hate this game. We built our own decks, using the first expansion and chapter packs, fought it out over a half-hour, and the end came as suddenly and as unexpectedly as the first time we played. We might as well just be flipping a coin. What psychosis has possessed the boardgaming world that has deemed this anything other than the most mediocre of games? I just don't get it.

UPDATE: 20 plays in. I like it a lot more than I did, especially after playing the Android board game and reading some of the Mel Odom novels. Ironically, I now prefer playing the corp! The core scoring mechanism still feels arbitrary, and one lucky draw can abruptly and anticlimactically end an otherwise intense, long game (not to mention some games can last 2 turns where others can last 20). It's hard to shake the feeling that this is just an epic version of Go Fish! with lots of bells and whistles attached.

RATING: 8.5
This is my first game in the LCG format.  I really like it.

The hidden information in this game keeps both sides feeling super tense for the whole match.  The runner thinks the corp has some awesome flatlining ice, while the corp knows his dinky ice can't hold back the runner and doesn't know what to do with all the in-hand agendas.  The back-and-forth is super exciting.

That said, the hidden info can also make the game feel a little random.  If the runner happens to find two agendas in a row on the deck, or pulls the one agenda in your hand on his first try it gets frustrating.  Still, very fun.

RATING: 10
Outstanding.  Best LCG/CCG game on the market.  I know there are plenty of people that bash on this game but I see it as genious.  It combines five aspects together in great synergy.

Bluffing
Asymmetrical gameplay
Actions as resource
Deck contruction
Theme

Originally a MTG player, I switched to board and self contained games to reduce cost when I returned to the hobby.  LCG became an option when it came out and it has grown to include several games.  I have played LotR, GoT, W:I, and Netrunner.  Though all of these are decent, only Netrunner shines as an absolutely solid competitive game. Netrunner is not only the best of the LCG set, it is better than any CCG I have played.  It works and it works very well.  That isn't to say it's for everyone.  However, for what I have been looking for in a card game, this game exceeds my expectations and I hope to continue playing for many years.

Update (Oct 2014) Been nearly two years since I started playing this game and I still love it as much as I did when I wrote my original assessment.  This stands as the only game I play regularly in the midst of my collection.  For those getting into the hobby.  Start with a basic set, expand to one of the deluxe sets and then pick up 2 to 6 packs.  You can create a strong competitive deck for less than 100 dollars.  If you have no interest in playing competitively, just pick up the core.  The first cycle of six packs expands the core set for more variety without making any significant changes if you decide to expand.

RATING: 8
I started playing A:NR in mid-2017, five years later after the release. The community is full of warm-hearted people that would really teach the newbies to master the game. Going to the mechanic, I really like how this game is done asymmetrically. One side would be the runner and the other would be the corp. The runner will steal and the corp will defend and advance their agendas. I got the theme and it chills me because I think we are actually in such age! Back to the game, this game is done in LCG after back then it was developed as TCG. The fact that it is converted is the only reason I decided to try. LCG means no more burning money for booster only to find that one copy of the rare card you need. LCG means everything is there, provided for you to play. You only need to be creative and intelligent enough to build a deck that can win you the way. Just like the other card games, FFG sometimes released cards that would tip the balance a bit off, but in the end, they will regulate it to keep the game expands and enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Although I wasn't a fan of the "classic" version of the game, that was back in the day that I was playing the Middle Earth CCG all the time, and in comparison to that game, Netrunner is pretty tame. The new edition I think has benefitted from the thematic graft to the Android universe, so it shares some backstory with Infiltration (a pretty good game). It's pretty generic, but much better than the lame Rex backstory, and it's enough to get your hands around.

I mentioned to a friend that Netrunner felt "retro", which he found confusing at the time. Having played it some more, that feeling has crystalized - Netrunner is, at the end of the day, just a game of "action attrition". Everything you do costs actions directly or indirectly (credits are just actions with a flexible exchange rate). It's a question of using your actions more effectively than your opponent. There just aren't a lot of tactics or synergies, only a touch of bluffing, no real card efficiency. Very little of the extra spice that gives games with a similar fundamental engine (like Jambo or Blue Moon) their gameplay bite. Just get the most bang out of your actions and hope you get cards in a good order. Maybe deck-building will flesh out the game space (it pains me to give FFG credit for simply not making a hash of the deck-building rules, but there you go: the deck-building rules, ripped off from Blue Moon, seem sensible).

The thematic material also feels a bit retro, with the tech feeling mostly 80's-era futurist vintage sprinkled with a few more modern ideas.

Regardless, there is enough here that if the William Gibson/Cyberpunk theme appeals to you, I think the game can draw you in. It definitely feels like the almost two-decades old design that it is, but that's not terrible.

Last thing, like all FFG games, a lot of really bad choices were made in the graphic design and the typically atrocious rulebook. At this point it's just sort of sad. But, FFG has done worse.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great little game.  The factions are neat and flavorful, the gameplay is fun and tense with a lot of bluffing and psychological games in addition to the core strategy.  

Because of the ability to take resources or cards at any time, and the fact that resources are non-renewable, it's much less susceptible to totally one-sided games than something like Magic.

RATING: 9
Really unique game. The most asymmetrical game I have ever played. That said, it is also extremely balanced. My biggest issue is finding friends that are into this kind of game. If your friends are not, or have never been, into CCG's they may not like this kind of game. Even though it's not a CCG per-say, you still need to pre-build decks to be competitive and if friends do not like to do this or are bad at it, it may not be so fun crushing their faces over and over.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Maybe one of the "coolest" games ever made. The tactile feel of the tokens and card play, the stylish art, the whip-smart mechanics, the cyberpunk theme. The massive amounts of cyber jargon can be a bit of a barrier to entry but it really adds to the "cool" factor once you get it all down.

Everything about this game is awesome. I love how it's basically two completely different games that two people play against each other. The bluffing is amazing, and the game is brilliantly designed to give you many fun choices to make in every hand. All the factions use completely different playstyles which is great for replay value.

The LCG distribution model is great, so much better than having to buy random boosters. But you really don't need to buy the data packs, there's PLENTY of game in the base set.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I tried to like the game, since one of our gamers loved it but at best I was indifferent to it. I'd play it, but I would have sooner played the other FFG LCGs in the order LOTR, then Game of Thrones then Call of Cthulhu and then Netrunner

RATING: 8.4
Fantastic card game that is wholly unique.  The clever cat and mouse game between Runner and Corp is visceral as the Runner goes head to head against the Corps defenses, often-times not knowing what he will run into.

The starter is well balanced, varied, and offers tons of replayability using only the preconstructed decks.  The deck building rules offer so many options that I don't know how anyone could possibly find this game getting stale anytime soon.

----------------------------------------

Update - I was very into Netrunner for a long period of time in the earlier period of its lifecycle.  I still have a great fondness for the mechanisms but the release cycle ground me out and beat me down.  Can't keep up with this behemoth and had to ditch it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
I can see why this is so popular. The theme really comes through, the corp and runner feel totally different, and there's a healthy cloud of fear pervading the entire experience. Some games you play with your head, like chess. Other games you play with your gut, like poker. Netrunner strikes a perfect balance between the two.

That said, here are the cons:
- I'm not a fan of the setting. Cyberpunk is creepy.
- LCG's are expensive
- The deck-building seems a little flawed to me. A runner has to balance out their deck to break every possible type of ice, or risk matching up against an opponent who is impossible to beat. However, Corps don't necessarily have to load up on every type of ice, and might just focus on one or two types. That means that a lot of cards in the runner's deck may end up serving no purpose. I hate drawing useless cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
