=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I’m sure this game gets better with repeated plays, but I’m rarely playing with just one other player. And when I am, I would much rather play Summoner Wars or similar card games! So even though I’m sure the game is okay, it’s just not something I personally want to dive into and explore – and even if I did, I still wouldn’t understand why it’s number 4 here on BGG, that seems way too high!

My only play was against a very experienced player who played with a sneaky corporation deck (can’t remember the name), so I knew before the game started that I would lose and that it would only be a learning game to see what the fuss was about. I’m just happy that I actually got 2 agenda points! But that was also partly because the corporation player’s first three scored agendas were the ones which give you the token which can permanently stop a run from the runner… Which is a huge benefit to the corporation! My opponent did state that he had been quite lucky with his cards, so that’s somewhat encouraging despite the fact that I got smashed 2-8! Still, even though the better player will win, I think there is a pretty big problem with the luck of the draw. It seemed pretty important to get the card which gives you 2 coins for each action instead of your basic 1, and I didn’t get that card until late in the game. Some cards are just important to get rather early to get an engine going. The luck of how your deck is shuffled also shows when you’re trying to make a run on the deck and you might reveal an agenda and score it or an ice and take some damage… Oh, and when you take damage the corp randomly discards some of your cards which might screw you or don’t have an impact at all…

It’s more like you are playing your opponent than the game itself; not sure if I like this. There is a lot of bluffing etc., which I’m not very keen on. I normally like bluffing in games, but not the way it works in this game as this is a more “serious” game than the bluffing you’re doing in games like Cash n Guns etc. (not that you can compare the two games at all but it’s just to explain why I wasn’t enamored with the element that you’re trying to figure out if your opponent is bluffing or not; it can be extremely costly if your guess is incorrect)!

I think the way the corp puts out his ice cards was quite cool as well as the various types of ice. And of course, the fact that he could be bluffing added to the tension (and I was probably way too defensive minded as a new and inexperienced player; I should have made more runs earlier). I love asymmetrical games, and next time I’m playing it (because I will – though that will probably be the last time), I’m going to play the corporation whose playing style I think I’m going to like the most. Oh, the theme and artwork seemed very bland and definitely didn’t help to improve my opinion about the game.
I would imagine that I would like the creation of your personal deck, but as I have stated I just don’t have the time to play this extensively, which I think it requires in order to shine. It definitely seems to reward repeated plays! However, as it stands, I think Garfield is one of the most overrated designers ever (Android, MtG and King of Tokyo all have ratings of less than 5).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Rated 7 after one play, but heck, that's a stab in the dark given the nature of the game. For a first play, I'm very intrigued. I love the asymmetrical roles, and though I played the runner, I suspect I'd have even more fun playing the corporation.

So why the low rating? I spent a heck of a time just preparing to teach and play the game, and even still, my first play involved a number of checks in the rulebook. The terminology of clicks, servers, assets, net damage, rezzing... yeesh. It's a lot to remember. There's plenty going on in the game, and it's hard to keep track.

Update: traded it away. I really like the game, but I just didn't have a partner to play this with me, and given the opportunity, I'd play A Game of Thrones the card game over this. It' rock solid though and I could get back into it with the right opportunity.

Ahh... but with familiarity... if I can find someone to stick through this with me, I think we're going to unearth a heck of a game.

Update: Five plays now, all with the same runner/corp combo, and I'm becoming a believer in this game. The potential cat and mouse between the two assymetrical positions, the bluffing, the flavor of the cards... this is really engaging once you get past the learning curve.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've long been a fan of the original Netrunner.  On the up-side the developers seem to have learned a bit (and only a bit) from the original.  Here things like Urban Renewal have been toned down into Scorched Earth while aspects of the rare Proteus expansion are now common in play.  More importantly, cash flow seems tighten for the Corp (except when playing the Anarch runner idents) which leads to a more balanced contests.

My only concern is that the influence budget concept constrains deck building too much, but only time will tell.

Unfortunately, as I log more plays, my initial wariness of the identities/influence concept seems to be bearing out, dropping A:N's rating.  The HB Corp and the Anarch identity have issues.  I have yet to see deckbuilding correct these issues and hopefully future expansions will improve these two identities.

As typical of FFG releases, the rulebook is awful and there are ergonomic foibles aplenty.  The ICE cards don't seem to "flip" in any sort of intuitive way - i.e. when you flip them to their rez'ed side they're always upside down / backwards etc.  Despite the copious and generally clear rulebook their are dangling concepts: does play of a "held" token cost an action for example.  When read by a beginner, the rulebook is downright awful.  Why is it that this excellent game has never been able to be decently presented/described? Basic matters of play, such as how ICE is approached and what happens if your breakers are not strong enough are both verbose, and at the same time incomplete (covered in two decoupled sections).  The cards while often beautiful have dubious ergonomic choices.  Faction symbols and other values being placed in different locations as an example.  Finally, the franchise continues to use weird an often conflicting terms. that I'd have expected a republished version to have corrected.  I mean, let's call an "action" an "action" already!

The brightest thing FFG could have done was watch people teach Netrunner to their newbie friends.  People have been translating Netrunner's horrid rulebook and poor card ergonomics for over a decade ... they still have to.

At any rate, it's Netrunner, one of my OOP 10's, and the best CCG of all time.  It is great to see it back in play with a wide audience.  Netrunner is *so* good that it can survive the "FFG treatment".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
One of the most brilliant, well designed, tuned, wonderful beasts of a game out there.

Netrunner has more player interaction than any other game I've played. Almost every game is a joy to play even if I am losing.

FFG's reboot of Garfield's classic the pinnacle of collectible games. If you want a game to tinker with, obsess over and show off your strange and powerful creations with friends... This is the game. This is it. I entreat you, I implore you. Get into the game before the cardpool becomes too daunting to fathom from the outside.

This game embodies our hobby like no other game can.

RATING: 1
A very nice assymetrical living card game with lots of theme. Demands a lot of skill and time to construct your deck and now the tricks of the trade. That makes this game very uninteresting to me but I can see that others would really love it.
One player is a computer hacker and the other the executive board of a megacorporation.
The hackers goal is to steal information from the corporation without getting caught by the private security companies emplyed by the corporations while the corporations has to protect their servers and advance their agendas so that they can earn more money and market shares.
The theme of the game really gives the feel of a Gibsonian cyberpunk world, along with the terminology.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I appreciate the asymmetrical nature of the game, the trade off in powers and costs, the theme, and the overall intent behind the design. So what's the problem?

It's two fold. 

First, there's not enough game actions to truly realize satisfying card plays because you have to spend too many of your actions dealing with the need for credits. The resulting experience is metaphorically like buying a ticket to a really fun amusement park that has tons of rides - but then you're told you only have 20 minutes to experience what you can before you have to leave. 

Some may enjoy this and describe it as "tense". To me, I feel tension from genuinely perplexing choices. The poker/bluffing element does offer a bit of that, but not enough to make up for the game's faults - at least not for me.

Second, sadly, I believe Netrunner is yet another example of where the deck building is really the source of fun for people. The games themselves are just instances of verifying or refuting the decisions made outside of the game in assembling the decks. That's not fun for me. I want a game where my opponent and I can take pre-made decks and still have fun in the game because of the circumstantial decisions provided by the game's mechanics. Netrunner simply doesn't have enough in that department. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Netrunner is a great game that I got rid of. Why? I just can't get into deckbuilding. I played with the premade faction decks, which was very fun. Spending hours agonizing over building your own is unfortunately not my cup of tea, which is a shame, because I can easily see the draw of this wonderfully tense, thematic, asymmetric game.

RATING: 9

RATING: 1
I am giving this a 1 - not because it's a bad game or not well designed.  It's because I am trying to offset the irrational curve that is set by fan-based popularity vs. true and actual ratings.  Be my guest to investigate, but no other game on the charts has the same number of users rating it both 8 and 10.  You will also notice that every other game has a bell curve distribution where as this game does not.  Proves my view that this game is rated where it is not because of objective reviews, but of fan-based wet dreams being satisfied in theme.  The game is not all that.  It's OK for what it is.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
In general, based on limited experience with both this and the original game I can say that it's a game that I can appreciate more than enjoy. The hidden information element of the game here is not implemented in a way that I find entirely satisfying. I love anything cyberpunk related, and the concept of asymmetrical play is always interesting, but I dislike the cat and mouse type gameplay of this one.

For those who aren't familiar with the basic concept, Netrunner is an asymmetrical game where one player represents a corporation, trying to protect their data from the other player who represents a hacker. The game structure is based on the corp erecting defences that can protect their agendas while the hacker tries their best to break through and steal them.

The LCG format is an interesting one for this game because many purists of the old game swore by totally random starter decks. I never cared for that as a format for serious games like this mainly because it seemed like it was eliminating a lot of potential long term depth for the sake of what? Not eliminating the silly unlimited copies of any card rule? Thankfully, FFG seems to have focused on the constructed concerns by instituting a 3-of rule and splitting the cards out into factions; thereby forcing each player to have some inherent weaknesses. 

The major downside I see with this game early is that for those who are inexperienced with the CCG/LCG format deck construction can be a bit overwhelming, and packaging the game like this means that it is not particularly approachable whereas a more staid, pre-constructed route would be moreso. 

That said, I do understand why the game was packaged this way: it creates more overhead and work for the player, but it also means the game has much more potential longevity and interest. Bravo to Wizards for licensing out this old game in any case, it has a lot of fans and I know that many people are very happy to have it available like this. Of course, none of that changes the fact that I am not particularly crazy about the gameplay of this one and generally prefer to avoid playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Pros: Unique theme and mechanics, exceptional asymmetric play, captures thrilling "cat-mouse" tension throughout the tempo of the game.

Cons: Growing entry cost, bouts of meta "staleness" (only applicable to competitive play)

I've played Netrunner on a regular basis for about three years now, and it remains my "main" competitive card game. It brings so much uniqueness and depth to the table that it may be my favorite game over all, card or otherwise. It captures a thrilling tempo of cyberpunk cat and mouse as one player attempts to discover all the corporations dirty secrets through swift "hacking", and the corporation frantically attempts to address their vulnerabilities while simultaneously either advancing their nefarious hidden agendas, or simply trying to kill the hacker.

Searching for something negative to say, the entry cost of owning the game in its entirety has become large, though remains cheaper than playing Magic: The Gathering competitively. Additionally, players at a competitive level will note months-long bouts of meta "staleness," when particularly strong cards are released, which the developers are slow to address via a competitive play restricted list.

Still, this is reaching into the nuts and bolts to find the bad. My overall experience has been overwhelming positive, and it is why Netrunner is the only game I have consistently played on a weekly basis for years.

RATING: 7
This game is really interesting. I've only played as a runner, but I enjoyed it a lot. The different kinds of ice add some randomness (it's pretty difficult to prepare against them, so you have to be ready for any contingencies), but this feels like a very tactical game. I'm not sure I want to invest in it, but I like the LCG model and like how the credit system allows you to exercise control over its flow (no such thing as getting creditscrewed or creditflooded).

Not getting played enough, sadly. Sold at Spiel 2016.

RATING: 10
I absolutely love this game. I love that you play the deck, rather than building a deck and having the deck play itself.  The bluffing mechanisms and gameplay really shine. There are a multitude of choices on your turn, and you never feel like you lose this game because of a bad draw.  You feel like the other player out-witted you, and things would have gone differently if you had played better.

It's been four months since release and we're above 80 plays (making it our most played game, ever) with no signs of slowing down.  This is my favorite game of all-time, bar none.

RATING: 5
Update:
I'm not quite sure how to rate this anymore. I liked the base game, without custom deckbuilding, but then I went and bought a few expansion decks, and I see that you really have to do deckbuilding, and I feel like the life is sucked out of me. I have to do a solo game of build-my-deck before playing the game against another person. I don't like playing solo games, and I don't like deck-building. I tried just taking one faction, including expansions, and mixing in the neutrals, and it's just not that interesting anymore. To be fair, this is really a problem with me and the whole category of games that require/encourage deck-building as a solo activity prior to playing against a human (e.g. Mage Wars). Maybe I'll go see if there are standard decks or something (still work to build them, and annoying when switching factions, ugh), but for now I rate it like a 7 while I'm actually playing, and like a 3 for deck-building. So average to a 5 I guess.
-----
Preliminary rating. Seems pretty fun so far, but from just the base game, I don't see what all the hype is about. I'll order up a few expansion packs, but I'm not a big fan of deck construction, so I'm not sure if this will help. I'm hoping there's an option to just like shuffle a bunch of stuff together or something. We'll see.

RATING: N/A
After only [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/play/details/13664658]one game[/url], only having seen a small fraction of the cards and not having read the rules myself (albeit having had a thorough explanation, thanks [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/user/Sarix87]Sarix87[/url]!), I don't feel qualified to rate this game yet.
Suffice it to say that I see the potential to really like it if I were to put in the time and energy to really get to know it.
However, the frequency with which new expansion packs are published - once per month - turns me off. It looks too time consuming to stay up to date (not to mention quite expensive as well). I want to play a game like this completely or not at all. Limiting myself to certain expansions doesn't seem attractive to me as it would severely limit my ability to find opponents (of course I would only want to play against people who accept the same expansion limitation then). Not being up to date would even limit my ability to just discuss the game with others, something which I enjoy in games a lot as well.
Who knows, maybe I'll change my mind about Android: Netrunner sometime, maybe in case the steady stream of expansions slows down before they reach several thousand different cards... :-/

RATING: 9
A cool cyberpunk, purely adversarial, living card game.  I have played a few number of games as a runner and a corporation and the experience is exhilarating.  Renegade hackers tricking out their rigs, getting juiced up on Diesel energy drinks, and making runs at Corporate baddies hiding behind harassing, annoying, or downright deadly ICE to crack open their plans hiding in their pristine servers.  Corporations trying to set devious traps or sending their goons out to beat up a tagged hacker while they pursue their nefarious objectives.  I love the hidden information aspect of the game and the mechanic is quite clean.  And what's not to love about a game that can see you suffer from brain damage (complete with a little brain counter for keeping track of it).  I really like this one!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is a RIDE!  Love this game and the asymetrical, deep, deep play!  Long live LCGs and this is the BEST!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
There is a decent and intriguing system at work here, but overall it feels a bit passive and a bit much like a waiting game.  Often times you sit there, unable to make your more, or grinning across the table collecting money as the corp.  I was hoping it would be a little faster paced or more intense.  Could be an opponent problem (overly conservative opponent).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I think its an amazing game- has everything I want out of a card game; Bluffing, targeted removal, resource management, options to use cards on your opponents turn. Really all the things I want out of a great game.

The theme is gorgeous, and as a fan of cyberpunk- I am absolutely in love. 

The game is just as balanced as any other card game, lots of back and forth. 

I am a fan of the LCG model- $15 a month is nothing to a CCG player. Organized play and competitive environment is the only real reason I ever pay to play CCGs...so the fact that A:NR has that scores it very high for me.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I grew up reading cyberpunk SF by William Gibson (Neuromancer, Johnny Mnemonic, Burning Chrome) and Neal Stephenson (Snow Crash, The Diamond Age), so I love the theme of this game! The rules are more complicated than they need to be, and they can be surprisingly difficult to learn. It doesn't help that Fantasy Flight's rule book is poorly structured and way too vague, and the card text isn't any better. But gameplay is deep and worth the effort. I find the draw mechanism to be a little too luck-based than I would prefer, and deck customization isn't as easy as Star Wars: The Card Game. Playing as the Corporation is passive and may not appeal to players who prefer more active gameplay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is the best game for matching mechanics to theme.

RATING: 9.5
Storage Solution:

Wooden box organizer and dividers (unsleeved version). http://www.thebrokentoken.com/unsleeved-card-game-organizer/

I created my own tokens with Bottle Cap Pendants (clicks, MU, reoccurring credits):  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00AFRWINA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Tokens in bead caddy. Just barely peaks out from the box when laid on its side. If only the version I had came with an extra lid. http://www.darice.com/store/details/catalog/wholesale-jewelry-organizers-storage/1125-53

Note: all the flavor text that comes with the expansions. https://gist.github.com/DeMarko/9235193

Potential TODO: Print factions on dividers via https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zq2O66QGCwg

===

Rating History:

As of Mar '16 (57 plays) - 9.5. Redoing rating and upgrading to 9.5 because it's one of my favorite games still. Not a 10 because of the FAQ that needs to go along with the game. Also fixing the balance with the NAPD Most Wanted List in official tournaments.

As of Jan '15 (41 plays) - 8. This is my and my wife's goto 1v1 game of choice. I only play this game with my wife. I tried introducing it to my X-Wing friend (ex-magic player), and he thought it was too random. I don't play in any leagues or anything like that. I also eventually bought the the first and second cycle of data packs. All of these factors affect how I rate this game. I guess without the data packs, I would rate this game a 6.5.

Things I enjoy about this game: Spending the time building a deck. Feeling sneaky and playing agressively as a Runner accessing cards. Feeling scared and playing defensively as the Corp with not enough ice or money to rez them.

Things I don't enjoy about this game: Teaching the vocabulary. It's a lot of jargon that does make you sound like a hacker in the end, but it's a lot to teach. The feeling that I need to get more data packs (although with the new tournament rotation, I may only need to focus on Deluxe Expansions). My wife thinks we have enough cards, but I'm sort of a completionist. And I don't like it when the shuffle don't go my way.

Games we'd rather play than this: My wife and I love co-ops, so we'd rather play 2-player Pandemic or Sherlock Holmes. For 1v1 games, My wife and I would prabably rather play What's My Word. My buddy and I would be playing X-Wing Miniatures Game instead. I don't own or have any interest in owning any other CCG or LCG, so NetRunner would be my only game for that. 

Rating as of Jul '14 - 7.5. Would've been an 8, but I don't normally see myself recommending this game since I don't play maybe 1-on-1 games except with my wife. I do recommend this game all the time to her, but I can't want to play this everyday with her.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Largely got out of CCGs in the 90s, after playing M:tG since Beta. The collectable/money sink aspect put me off. As a result I also don't look at card games much at all, probably uncalled for but there you go. 

So when my son brought over a copy of Android: Netrunner, I was not that enthused. It's a "Living Card Game", meaning that cards are not sold randomly, but there are regular releases of new cards. Hmmmmmm...

After playing it for a few weeks now, with only the base set (self contained, enough cards for multiple decks, for about $40), I'm smitten. Early, but I give this game a "10" because it is such a marvelous design. 

It is truly asymmetrical, each side (it's 2 player) has literally different rules. The interaction is constant; the "Runner" attacks, the "Corporation" defends. Unless the Corporation unleashes a counter attack, and the hunter becomes the hunted. Unless he's smart, and it's just bait to see what the Corp can do so he can launch another "run" (attack) with better knowledge. Unless...

I could go on, but instead just look online for reviews. There's a reason people go gaga over this game, it really is that good!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I think this is a great game.  Because of the asymmetric game design, you basically have to learn the rules twice.  But it's worth it to have an asymmetric game that actually works and is enjoyable.

In an odd way, it reminds of Maria:  the players are not similarly situated, but none has the advantage.

RATING: 10
Not a huge fan of card games so I kind of overlooked this one.

I've played 10-12 virtual games on Octagon just with the core set and I value this a fantastic game. 
Superb asymmetric play with lots of tense moment, great variety in faction strategy and theme is drippin from every pore.
Most of the time I'm having a blast, sometimes ANR makes me want to rage quit but thats my arch-enemy, Mr Randomness

RATING: 6
Netrunner is an assymmetric game where both roles (corporation and runner) play very differently. There is a big bluffing element as the corporation builds up hidden defences and tries to score while the runner is building up his rig and attacking the servers. Surprisingly, the base set seems to offer seven decent decks that will offer a lot of playtime for casual players. In the end I still sold this, because the LCG format is a deal breaker for me.

I'm sure the game is balanced for this, but it's too big of a difference for me.

RATING: 6
The game - 9/10. I love the gameplay, the theme, the asymmetry and the feel.

The rate at which FFG is releasing new data packs - 3/10.
I bought a few and realised that they are releasing new stuff WAY too fast for me. To keep up with the new cards to be able to play in tournaments etc. would basically mean making Netrunner your second job. I don't want that.
Playing casually is difficult because active players want to keep up with the data packs.

tl;dr: Great game, the LCG system is not for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is probably my #1 favorite card game. There is so much involved in the game and there are so many ways to build your deck and different ways to play to win. You can build decks with multiple strategies and both can work to win you a game. 

I think I like the asymmetrical nature of the game most. It makes you have to learn to play both sides in order to really get good at it. 

Update: I've dropped my rating on this game. While I really like it, I don't play it much anymore. Not as many people in my group play it and there is too much prepwork needed to build a deck that works well with all the cards.

RATING: 10

If I were to dump all my other games and play only one, this would be it.

RATING: 6
As a previous MTG player, I liked the concept and art of Android: Netrunner.  The LCG model appealed to prevent pay to win feelings.  I never really enjoyed the game that much after a couple of tourneys and friendlies I sold this one on. Too asymmetric for me, not enough interaction. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
With just the core set alone there's so much variety and game to get out of the box.  With an ever expanding cardbase and a super competitive culture, it can feel overwhelming, but if you have someone to start with who's a newbie too, you can grow into it together and go as deep as you choose.  You don't need to go very deep for the game to feel very large in terms of possiblities.  The actual mechanics are really fun, very tense, and usually things workout so that you feel like you playing a balanced head to head.  Sometimes however the corp can get screwed, and with a low total of 7 agenda points needed to win, things can change very dramatically in one quick move of skill or good fortune.  Ultimately it doesn't feel as purely strategic as say, Magic did to me many years ago when I used to play it, but i'm sure many would argue with me on that one!

RATING: 6
1v1 card game similar to Magic: The Gathering (same designer), yet doesn't suffer from the collectible aspect or the "land problem" its predecessor did. 
Both sides play very different from each other, and the game seems pretty solid so far.
Rating lowered a bit, as I'm just never very excited to play this. I have zero desire to construct my own deck(s), and I'm fairly indifferent about the game itself.
My 6 rating is on the gameplay itself. If I had to rate it based on both deck construction and gameplay, then I'd drop it to a 5 max.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Only giving this game a 5 because it is complex enough to intrigue me. I only own the base game, so I am only going to rate that. Having quite a bit of MTG or the Star Wars LCC etc, I was naturally interested in A:NR - and this also probably heavily influences my rather mediocre rating of this game.

After about 12-15 games, I just feel like there is so little direct interaction in this game which drags it out a very long time if the runner stays passive. And even though bluffing and a certain amount of luck in games are great, it seemed to me that there were way too many games won by lucky draws after hq/R&D runs or the runner trying to tap the wrong of 2 seemingly equal servers.

This probably gets better when you have more cards thus more options to build more synergistic decks, but the base game didn't convince me. It's actually noticably long when you play carefully and down to guessing if you play it risky.

This is to be taken with a grain of salt, of course - i am judging this (probably unfairly) through thr eyes of a person that loves mtg. Maybe I've not given NR the attention it deserves, maybe I'd just need to invest in a few expansions to get more of what I want... But to be honest, Netrunner didn't intrigue me enough to do so.

It's by no means a bad game. I'm just writing this because I am really surprised how much hype it gets.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Brilliant card game that benefits greatly from the LCG format. The asymmetrical structure and the extremely well thought out mechanics makes this a deep and strategic experience on a level that few card games can compare to.

It's still understandable that it never reached where Magic went, because it's not as accessible and lacks some of the adolescent "cool factor" that drives the whole Magic experience.

Overall, it's still the superior game.

RATING: 9
Extremely fun game, difficult to learn on your own. Youtube videos were extremely helpful, as well as the subreddit. There is so much strategy involved, you can play aggressive and try to flat line the runner as the corporation, or run nonstop to get the corp to run out of credits; or you can play a slow game and try to deck the corp as a runner, and try to set up traps, and score agendas as the corp. Fun Fun game, I'm just starting to scratch the surface of the meta, and I only have the starter set. 

Worth the effort in learning the game!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pretty cool two-player, assymetric card game with one player as the "hacker" and the other as the "corporation". Includes a limited deck building aspect where cards are worth points, and you're only allowed a certain number of points, so it avoids the spend-to-win situation of [i]Magic: The Gathering[/i], but you can still tailor your decks somewhat.

Update: I would stop at the end of the Genesis Cycle, i.e. the Core set plus the first six expansions. Creation and Control, and the Spin Cycle, wreck the game with ridiculous recursion and economy for the Runner. See my comments on Creation and Control.

I've also dropped my rating a bit because of the major imbalance they've introduced. On top of that, there are simply too many rules/timing questions now, so much so that they had to update their "anatomy of a run" to ridiculous levels of detail, and there are still tons of rules questions on the forums. Not fun.

Update 2: Sold. Too many cards too fast, too many obviously inferior cards, and too much arms escalation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun game as long as you have someone to play with casually. The competitive nature and constantly shifting meta makes it hard to play with someone random. Either you need to teach it to someone to play with you (and teaching the game is a real chore), or you end up playing against someone who has meticulously optimized their deck and play style.

RATING: 10
3x Core Set
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The classic 1996 CCG Netrunner has been reborn! Players assume the roles of either the corporation or runners (hackers). As the corporation, your main goal is to advance Agendas while playing poker-face deceit and bolstering defences to thwart off the constant "runs" of the hackers. As the runners, your main goal is simply to make "runs" at the corporations servers, bypassing securities and eventually retrieving valuable Agendas. 

A great remake with plenty of player interaction with high tensions. Highly recommended for sci-fi fans!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
UPDATE - really dislike what FFG have done with the rotation - dropped out of buying at the point rotation kicks in - another seedy money play by FFG. Game rating still an 8.5 but rating dropped to reflect the management of the game.

Mechanically I think this is the best of FFG's LCG card games - it shows it's external design heritage by being a much more elegant and less clunky design than they typically come up with in-house. The draw deck, hand and discard piles being 'servers' in the same way as the servers that you deploy to is very clever. 

It also feels much more natural as a game. i.e. there are definite sides (runner or corp) to which you belong, competing against each other, rather than something like the 'Cthulhu' LCG, where you are competing for 'stories' - what does that really mean? So really good in terms of gameplay.

- The usual FFG base game ploy of releasing some cards with less than 3 copies, thus requiring the purchase of more than one base set, to enable proper deck-building. I accept FFG's rationale of having some cards in the base set with less than 3 copies to allow a greater variety of cards to be included, but their refusal to release some form of supplementary pack, to bump the limited release cards up to 3 copies, just smacks of crude/naked profiteering.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Players represent either a corporation, or a computer hacker, trying to control Agendas to score them as victory points.  Smooth playing two player card game, where each player plays from their own deck, but is trying to score Agenda cards that exist only in the corporation deck.  Players take turns spending a limited amount of actions ("clicks") to get an economy up and running, equipment deployed, and resources stocked up.  The heart of the game is the "run", where the hacker player attempts to access cards on the corporation side of the table.  The hacker uses assets to aid in the run, while the corporation defends their holdings with "ICE" software cards.  Terrific, tense, but very playable game - well designed, some good, interesting assymetry between the two sides.  Really enjoying this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

includes: [b]2 Core Sets,[/b] [b]What Lies Ahead,[/b] [b]Trace Amount,[/b]  [b]Cyber Exodus,[/b] [b]A Study in Static,[/b] [b]Future Proof,[/b] [b]Order & Chaos[/b]

RATING: 9
This game just blows my mind.  I have no idea how it could get any better.  You always feel like you're one turn away from winning AND losing.  Every turn is insanely tense.  Every game results in players talking about what they did, why they did it, and what they should have done differently.  There's not much more rewarding in a 2-player card game than stealing an agenda.  There's not much more that sucks when the runner steals one from you as the Corporation.  Sweat out every turn.  Stare your opponent down.  Good luck.  Buy this now.  Buy this now.  Buy this now.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The good news is that FFG has kept 95% of the original design intact.   Minor changes to traces, some keywords revised, slightly more Agenda points required in the deck.   Corp and Runner faction identites have been added, and after many plays I'm convinced that they add a valuable element to the metagame, along with the influence and deck-building rules.  Really good work there, FFG.

The bad news is that the starter box is extremely watered down.  For $25 you can get this, which has 7 starter decks in it.  The problem is that the cards are duplicated so frequently that after one play, you've pretty much seen all there is to see with a particular deck.  The decks feel totally incomplete (and they are). For the same price, you can get two 60-card original decks on eBay and get 120 unique cards, all of which have more "oomph" than these FFG cards.   Those WOTC decks have 30+ plays in them, easily.  Easily.  So the FFG version of the game is going to require constant and substantial expansion to get up to the level of what the original game can still give you.  The FFG Netrunner is going to be a very expensive game if you commit to it.   I'll keep up with it for a while, but I don't know that I would recommend this version to a new player unless they are willing to spend $100+....errr...  $200+.

The value in the FFG box is a 6.  The game design itself is a 9, however, and probably a 10 in it's fully fleshed-out form.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

Although they have tried to fix these things with the new core set i feel that i won't return to playing netrunner until they pull the game back to the core parts of what made the game so good to play in the first place!!!

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I want to love this game. The asymmetry between Corp and Runner is intriguing, and the game of bluff and misdirection is spot-on. It's perfect for the theme - when playing the Corp, you feel scheme-y and sneaky as you place your traps and lure the Runner into traps; when playing the Runner, getting past the various obstacles feels like you're outsmarting the massive opponent, against all odds, hacking through their every defense.

I, unfortunately, cannot play - I need an opponent of somewhat equal skill. When introduce it to someone new, I need to act as a teacher and guide - walking them through the game's complex systems. Afterwards, they'll generally be impressed with the game, but we'll never get around to playing again. On the other end, I went to a Android: Netrunner night at my local game store and was thoroughly trounced - and, to make it worse, mocked by arrogant opponents for my poor choice of cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A card game masterpiece! Easy to learn, hard to master, well balanced, good thematic and very strategic gameplay.

More importantly but irrelevant to the score, I've made some amazing friends through the UK netrunner scene and cant recommend it enough to people who want to get into something truly strategic and rewarding.

RATING: 9.5
Always liked to play the original Netrunner game. Asymmetrical play for two players. One is the Corporate IT department and other is trying to gain access.
It is a LCG so its costs will go up as you need to buy more cards in you want to play with the serious players or in tournaments.
HOWever if you have the base board game then you can have fun with your friends. The best way to learn to play is to watch the video called "How to Play Android Netrunner: Complete Tutorial". Then start in the rulebook.

RATING: 9
I'm a sucker for cyberpunk (Mike Pondsmith is the man!) but this took some getting into. We're still playing with just the core set, which offers a ton of gameplay in its own right. Lots of tension and bluffing in a cat and mouse game with totally asymmetrical sides. We have an expansion to chuck in as well some time - not sure how deep down that rabbit hole (pardon the pun) I want to go though... Once you get your head around the jargon I think it really immerses you in the theme. You find yourself actually speaking and understand this mysterious lingo of future tech geeks: runs, ice, grips, stacks, heaps, servers, subroutines. Great fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I was introduced to the new Android version of netrunner when it came out, and have kind of fallen in love with the game since then.  I find it scratches a different itch than other card games, focusing more on bluff and risk management than pure calculation (though there is a lot of that as well).  Instead of having monsters attacking each other, the game system is a race for position and economy.  Above even those issues, [i]time[/i] is the most important factor, as actions are precious and you can only do so much in a turn.   

If I have any complaints at all about the game, it would be either with the randomness or the length.  Anyone can tell you about a corp game when the runner beat all the odds and grabbed enough points to win (or at least an insurmountable lead).  Even if you play well, drawing a hand full of agendas without the support necessary to protect them is deadly.  Runners aren't immune to these problems, but have far more card-draw and tutoring effects available to them.  
The game can end swiftly in such cases, but most of the time will go longer than other card games.  There is a kind of compulsion to play to the end, even if you don't really have a chance to win.  I've rarely seen people concede, even if their position is all but hopeless.  This is because there's so much hidden information that even if things seem bad to them, there's still a chance their opponents won't spot the weakness or will make a mistake.  Even if one player is crushing, it may take them a while to secure the win, just because they have to find the agendas in order to score points.

These are minor issues, though.  Un/lucky draws are unavoidable in card games, and as long as the players are enjoying themselves, length is largely immaterial.  

Aside from that, my biggest issue with it is the balance.  FFG seems to be doing a pretty good job, but there are still too many decks, in my estimation, that rely on the same types of cards to win.  The anarch faction has viruses that can easily destroy defenses many times their own cost, and can be recurred repeatedly.  Corps, meanwhile, seem to disdain these defenses, and just fast-advance their agendas through.  Each side wants to interact with the other as little as possible in order to coast to victory, and this does not make the game as fun or interesting to play.
FFG has realized the power of these stale archetypes, and printed cards specifically to answer them.  But, there are answers to the answers, and these types of decks remain.  It's just a little frustrating to see the card pool get littered with 'must-run' cards designed to hose specific builds, and having to try and find room for a substantial portion in your deck.

Anyway, I play casually more than for tournament victories, so these problems are less noticeable to me.  I've even been surprised at the power of some of my wonky theme decks, once properly upgraded to compete in the occasional local events.  The game offers a nice mix of factions, strategies, and deck-building challenges (much more so now that the card pool's big than it did at the beginning), and as long as it keeps supplying that, I'll keep trying to play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.3
Richard Garfield, the father of Magic the Gathering, delves into William Gibson by creating this super cool cyberpunk duel with cards and a bunch of tokens.
Very interesting asymmetrical gameplay, where one player is the Evil Corporation and will install servers, and softwares and firewalls to progress their agenda and protect their valuable data, while the other will act as the Netrunner - the hacker - and will use specialised software, icebrakers and whatnot to break into the company's databases to prevent them from reaching their goals. But if they are not good enough the company's security measures could fry their brains.

RATING: 9.5
This is a fun, asymmetric, clever game. 

Have bought all expansions up to Data and Destiny.

One player plays a weird cross between Poker and Labyrinth. 

The other player plays something that resembles a cross between Master Thief and Magic the Gathering.

The theme is awesome, and shines through the way the game plays. I have a particular fancy for cards from the NBN and Weyland factions, as they closely resemble my actual life in a large corporation.

I played this weekly for about 3 months, and I intend to get back into it. 

Only issue - it's a bit intense, and you feel brain burned after playing it for a few games. Semantics.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
(If I wasn't so angry at how disappointed I am in this game after all the hype it got, I'd probably score it closer to a 3)

Notice how many of the people who rated this game a 10 already played and loved the original.

One more example of a game loaded up so heavily on theme that the gameplay totally suffered. I really, really don't know why this game has gathered as much popularity as it has.

It should be noted that this is NOT a strategy game, it is a BLUFFING game. 

Pros:
-the theme is super cool

Cons:
-for a deck-building game, the base game offers VERY little variety in how decks can be built. Expansions are desperately needed before the deck-building aspect starts to get even remotely interesting.
-the theme is taken so seriously that you have to learn an entirely new vernacular just to learn the game (example: the deck of cards a player draws from is never called their "deck". It actually has a different name depending on whether you're playing the Corporation or the Runner - and you need to memorize the correct name for both, as cards will affect them)
-once you look past all the theme, you realize the whole game is nothing more than the Runner randomly picking from a series of face-down cards and hoping he doesn't pick the wrong one

If you're really, really, REALLY into cyberpunk, go ahead and buy this game. Otherwise, The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game is better in terms of gameplay and in deck-building options, and its story-driven format is just as exciting thematically. If you really want to get into Living Card Games, my suggestion is to get into LotR rather than this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm surprised a game like Netrunner was designed back in 1996.  Why do I say that?  You win by getting the most victory points (common for boardgames but not so much CCGs).  Well, in this game they are Agenda points, but you know what I mean.  Beyond that, the game uses an action point system which became popular in a lot of Euros (ie Pandemic, Tikal, Chaos in the Old World, etc).  This game would also overcome issues of other CCG's which tie currency to the cards that you draw.  All this leads to an extremely well designed game, particularly back in 1996.

It's surprising that it wasn't very successful for it's time and was cancelled.  That is until FFG acquired the rights to the game and re-released it in their Android universe.  The only thing that's really changed with the game is that cards are now designated into factions which greatly affects deck construction.  Most people see this as an improvement to the original design.  Anyone who has interest in CCG's/LCG's owes it to themselves to try this one out.

I decided against keeping it in my collection because I'm not really into any customizable games that require time outside of a game day to play.  The basic starter decks from 1 Core Set is not enjoyable enough after having experienced deck construction.

RATING: 9
A master piece. The theme is incorporated fantastically and the gameplay is very different from other CCG/LCG style games. I personally prefer a different resource system, but in this game it does work, and not sure if a different system would improve it, probably the opposite in this case. 
Other then that, so much to think about, so many options, I love, love, love the bluffing and double guessing and the atmosphere is just so tense. All corps and runners play very differently too.

Not that easy to explain though, but definitely worth it!

RATING: 9

There are some minor rule changes from the original, but I didn't see anything worth getting up on a soap box about. I currently do not have plans to own this one. I only am interested in casual play and a bunch of old cards or new cards will easily satisfy that need. If you are interested in playing Netrunner casually buy whichever you can acquire cheaper. If you're interested in competitive/deckbuilding/extensive play buy Android Netrunner.

My only thematic complaint: it's a bit, not a credit. Also would it kill anyone to put a CRT monitor or two in the new art?

RATING: 8
What's good: Fun game, nice mechanics. You will have fun! 

What's bad: Where to begin with this? The biggest thing is money. This game really needs you, tempts you, begs you to spend money on it. It needs your money in order to be more fun, and then the fun just won't stop and it keeps going crazy and then eventually you have fun over to your house for dinner and it wants to borrow 30 bucks from you. And you know fun will never pay you back... or will it? So you give fun the money and then.... well, I hope you see my point. Some people say a LCG is better than a CCG on your pocketbook... and just because I'm not having to get a second job to pay for my hobby, doesn't mean I'm not eating hot pockets and oatmeal for dinner.

get ready to spend the money.

RATING: 7
I liked this one a lot more than I expected to – the meta-game, the feints, the tension of trying to get things done – they raise the game from merely playing powerful card combinations from pre-constructed decks to a bit of a poker match. The asymmetry of the sides is quite interesting and novel (one offense and one defense), and I’m sure able to hold one’s attention through the subsequent deck releases. 

However, this may be the best game that I don’t play, and that’s due to the commitment required. If I ever get a game-playing spouse, I may very well revisit this one as it seems to be a lifestyle game that requires regular, consistent play among equally skilled players.

RATING: 8
Netrunner is a great game - it offers a great immersive experience in which you really feel like a «Corporation» or a «Runner». The designers made a great effort to translante emotion into mechanics. 

It's a complex game though. I'm only a beginner but I can see all the depths and complexity available for he who would want to plunge in. Be warned - the assymetric experience and the flexibility of the game makes for a steep learning curve. Once you know the game though, it's well-paced and full of bluffs and fear and what-not, in addition to heavy on strategics decision and ressources management.

It's also impossible to play any multiplayer games and I don't see any way to make any home-house rules to circumvent that.

RATING: 4
My friend calls it deep; I think it's simply broad. There are lots of paths to watch, setup and/or avoid, which makes it a bit of a game of whack-a-mole with limited whacks. So, fun and good replay-ability, yes, but not deep.

Feb 2015
After many expansion pack releases the game is such that you can no longer prepare for every circumstance, so games are now officially a crapshoot. And I am in agreement with alexfrog about the game being far away from the spirit of the original with fast advance corp decks dominating. It's either fast advance or the perpetual minefield of Jinteki. The runner game has mostly become one of hammering the central servers. What's the point?

May 2015
I am done with this game. The game meta is a perpetually moving target that is a full-time job to keep up with (creating decks and playing *a lot*). Great if you're a teen or 20-something with nothing but free time, but as a 40-something I have neither the time nor patience for it any longer. I'll stick with the non-collectible Blue Moon to scratch the same itch.

RATING: 9

UPDATE: I have sold my Netrunner collection.  Not because I dislike the game, but because an inherent problem with competitive "collectible" games is that you really need the time to commit to them, as well as a dedicated group.  Unfortunately I have neither at this time.  But I still stand by my previous rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I must admit that much of the high rating I give to this game is due to its spectacular theme. More than just cyberpunk, it's amazingly great sci-fi: sometimes tongue-in-cheek social commentary, other times an exciting glimpse into the future.

Mechanically, it's no slouch either. I consider it an "economic warfare" game, where both players are focused on generating credits (or cards) and striking when their opponent's economy is weak. I also find the "trace" mechanic (essentially an auction) interesting because it boils down to how well both players can read the game state and translating that into how much they should pay.

Some complaints I have are the randomness of the HQ and R&D draws which can decide games, and of course needing opponents who are also into deckbuilding to fully enjoy it.

RATING: 10
This has all the characteristics that most suit my gaming tastes: controlled risk, hidden information, opportunities for creativity and aggression, and thematic cohesion. Setup and play is fast. Art is beautiful. Each game is intellectually challenging, but also fun and tense from start to finish. Replayability is infinite, even discounting deck building. If I was forced to choose a single game to play for the rest of my life and shun all the others, I would be sad indeed - but I would not hesitate to choose A:NR.

RATING: 8
JUL/13 On one hand, I'm so glad designers are trying new settings//themes for games. And this game is brilliant design well-suited to the theme. On the other hand, I hate the theme and it prevents me from getting into the game.

Dang.

FEB/14 The theme and jargon are growing on me, and the expansions are introducing art I connect to more strongly. This game is quickly growing on me.

MAR/14 I've lost something like 14 games of this in a row, but even aside from that, all my playings are starting to feel "same-y". I either don't understand the deckbuilding and/or don't understand it (and I've deckbuilt Magic for years). I took a look at the expansions cards for Corp, took a stab at deckbuilding, and felt no excitement at all to tool around.

I expect I'll buy the base game as a solid 2-player game, and leave it at that.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I think i have found the perfect 2-player game with lots of depth, ideal game length and logical/intuitive thinking balance. I love that, unlike many other games of the format, this game feels more boardgame-like, because with all the deckbuilding its still very important how you play during the game. The game is also full of interaction and thats a thing i like - being able to take risks when i feel the urge for it, bluff and mess with my opponent. But more important is that Netrunner is very flexible and does not restrict you to any particular playstyle, so if you like zero risk full control, you can play it that way. The deckbuilding aspect blurs these line even more as in Netrunner you have clear and simple parameters that interact in complex manner leaving you lots of intriguing  deckbuilding options and many many cards haunting your mind, begging you to make combos and new decks. Overall i am pretty sure this is a solid 10.
P.s. I fully acknowledge that the logic/intuition and strategy/luck ratio i call ideal is subjective, but do not make the mistake of many other reviewers who judge a d6 based on a single throw result, instead of a 100 throws. Same goes with card games and as such Netrunner as risk management lies in its soul and probability is whats important, not a couple of lucky draws.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Currently best card game I've played

Pros
-It's different than every other card game other there (not just: play as mage/general, draw, gain resource, summon monster, attack, cast spells/tactics, upkeep)
-Two different ways to play the game (Corp or Runner). Both play differently beyond just theme. They have different objectives, type of cards etc.
-Very flexible turn structure - a player can choose what they want to do (e.g. draw 4 cards, get $3 and draw 1 card, make 2 runs and purge a tag and install some equipment etc.)
-Consequently, luck of the draw feels less significant (you can just choose to draw more cards).
-Lots of approaches a player can take on any given turn (you can attack enemy servers, their hand, their discard pile, their deck, you can build up cards/money/equipment) --> lots of strategy and decision making
-LCG model, no random packs, always know what you're buying. Saves players money compared to CCG model.
-Game comes with a total of 7 different factions (at least 24 different match ups).
-Bluffing is not only possible, but an important element of the game
-Fairly straight forward deck building (or players can use pre-designed decks).
-Components are good, art is amazing.
-Excellent card design. Cards feel mostly balanced, very little power creep, , each card feels unique and fills a strategic niche and each faction continues to remain different.
-Short game length (~30mins). Little setup involved.

Cons
-Somewhat steep learning curve for non-card gamers. Lots of terminology (most obvious examples: a players deck is either called R&D or Stack depending on who you are...hard to remember stuff like this first time around)
-Large amount of cards available for purchase and growing --> big barrier for newer players, and card knowledge becomes very important.
-Very cutthroat play style is not for everyone
-Core set does not come with 3 copy of every card, nor does it come with enough cards to have 7 decks simultaneously (you always have to take out ~15 neutral cards to put into the deck you want to play)
-Some luck element (e.g. doing runs on R&D, in one game you may easily find and score all the agendas, while in another game you may find none).
-Very limited deck building out of box - Corporations MUST use the neutral agendas provided (to meet the requirements of a legal deck), there are no others to swap out
-2 players only
-Card game still dictated somewhat by luck
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I hate to say it, but this is actually a pretty innovative game. Not is it only asymmetric, but the goals of each side are far from the typical card-battle CCGs.

The Corporation knows almost everything, and builds (mostly) permanent defences in order to advance agendas; the Runner sets the pace of the game, probing and passing those defences in order to steal those agendas.

The flavour text is generally very weak - verbose and heavy-handed.

The templating/drafting is so terrible that it has spawned all sorts of unnecessary fiddly rules issues (eg Accelerated Diagnostics triggering card draw, or Caprice Nisei), and understanding timing windows is critical to playing the game properly (eg House of Knives after Komainu but not Psychic Field). Another issue with Netrunner is that much of the game is understanding what tricks an opponent can pull, making card memorisation very important.

(I own two core sets.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First of all, i would like to thank
[user=pyjam][/user]
who introduced me into this game.

Wow, just wow ! I can't believe that such a thematic and well designed game exists. It must be a dream !

A cat and mouse game in a cyberpunk world, 2 asymmetric sides with differents goals and tools :

(1) - Corporation always play cards face down in servers protected by security programs (called ICE). His goal is to advance and score agenda (secrets projects), by luring and slowing down the runner. The corporation can try to locate the runner and tag him (find is MAC address) in order to inflict him brain or physical damage (lesser card in runner's hand). When the runner doesn't have any card in hand, he is considered flattened and lost the game.

(2) - Runner always play cards face up. They came with different types, from resources, hardware and programs to viruses. They consist of tools allowing the runner to be able to launch infiltration on the Corporation's servers in order to steal agenda or trash whatever the Corporation was developing. When the R&D deck is exhausted, the Corporation lose the game. 

The first player to seven points of agenda wins the game.

One of my most favorite card's artwork :
[IMG]http://www.cardgamedb.com/forums/uploads/an/ffg_archived-memories-core.png[/IMG]
[b]My favorite Living Card Game[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Very difficult to learn, but also very appealing and compelling.  Then dispiriting and hard work.  Then enjoyable. I only get to play this over Skype so there's another barrier to overcome, and I don't think the bluffing aspect is coming out properly, but something about this game makes me want to play it, learn it, understand it.  I mostly enjoy it when playing, it feels like I could do so consistently. (7) 2015-07-06

____

6 months later I feel like this might be over, the game really offers nothing for the casual player and deck building is such a tedious and time-consuming chore that you have to be really invested in trying a particular card or strategy to want to go through with it.  More expansions mean more cards that will never see play, and the core set does not give enough to play the game properly.  I feel like the core set gestures at a game that would be enjoyable rather than being it.  Having run through the first 5 data packs there's now too many possibilities to remember to be able to guess what particular card my opponent is playing, and I'm just not invested in the outcome of the game.

Ultimately I think the asymmetrical nature works against me enjoying it, and so much is decided in the build before you play that one player can start with a huge advantage over the other with neither knowing it.  Cycling between different identities just seems to lead to waiting for a lucky draw between decks that can interact with each other, and the identities and asymmetry seem to act as a smokescreen for how unbalanced the game can be.  I'd much rather play a game where both players start in an equal position and the outcome is entirely determined by the play after the game has started. (6) 2015-12-23

______

Having not played since last comment, I can now no longer remember playing a game of this and enjoying it.  The game has too many problems and the play is not worth the preparation time.  I really doubt I will ever play it again. (4) 2016-03-17
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really like this game a lot so far. Its asymmetrical nature is really appealing, and the different factions feel quite different while still sharing a number of key characteristics with each other. At first I was very disappointed by FFG's decision to include only one or two of certain cards in this core set because it feels like a play for more money. But now I think about it a different way:  players who are hardcore deck-tuners are essentially subsidizing my (and other casual players') purchases of the core set. They buy two or three, I buy one, and the overall price of the core set is a wee bit lower.

Yes, it absolutely would have been better had there been three of every card in the core set. No question.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My first impressions of this 2-player LCG is very favorable - I can't wait to play with more of the decks!  It took a little longer to absorb the rules than I thought it would, but once the concepts are understood, it actually flows together pretty well and probably only takes about 20 minutes to explain to a newbie.  It was a very strong bluffing element, which may turn some people off, but if you like a tense 30-minute cat-and-mouse game that allows you to build up your strength and gives you all kinds of platforms from which to launch attacks and surprise your enemy - check this out.  The core set comes with plenty of game in it - it's complete enough by itself that buying additional packs is not necessary, although hard to resist.  This is just one cool game that I look forward to exploring for a long time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Awesome! A newer, better Netrunner.

My favorite card game and my second favorite tabletop game (the first being War of the Ring).

It's nice to see a customizable card game where most of the strategy lies in playing. Deck building is important too, but unlike many other customizable card games, don't expect your deck to run on autopilot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Got some immature customizable card game problems (card pool is too small, a few cards are much stronger than the field, and there are only a handful of competitive decks) but the core is strong. Tons of choices to make on a turn and plenty of ways to work yourself out of a bind. As long as they find a way to expand the design space without breaking the game this could be, with time, one of the greats.

Update: Upgraded to a solid 9. I like this more every time I play. Great distillation of limited information, calculated risk, and deck building.

RATING: 9
Excellent 1v1 card strategy game. Requires a good amount of time investment and benefits greatly from both players being quite experienced. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first ever LCG (or CCG even) game and I'm completely hooked. I like the theme and the fluff of the Android universe.

The asymmetry of the game is great. The bluffing, the double bluffs, the reading of players, the many options from the cards, the building up of you rig/servers. There is a lot to like. And I do.

And then comes the deckbuilding. As soon as you start mulling over the possibilities of card combinations then you know the game really has got it's hooks into you. I can spend many an uncomfortable tube journey thinking up janky combinations for my next Netrunner night.

This game has been a regular weekly fixture for a number of years now. We meet in a pub, have a few beers and a few games and I've made some new friends along the way.

2017 Update: I quit playing regularly. It's a "lifestyle" game and a time sink. Very fond memories of the my time with ANR but once you dip out, it's very difficult to keep up with how the game changes and develops. I've had the occasional game since. This makes it a difficult game to rate; it changes based on my commitment to the game as keeping up with the cards and combos was part of the draw. It's a little overwhelming if you dip out of a cycle or so and then the deckbuilding rules and MWL etc change. It's been as high as a 10 for me, but I think 8 is a good fit in retirement.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Just didn't work for me.  Randomly pulling cards from a players hand or hoping to burn the rights cards from the top of their deck seemed too luck based for me.  I understand there is a bluffing aspect to playing agendas to the board and blocking them with ice, but it all seemed way too slow and its not nearly as satisfying as, for example, hitting my opponent for 20 damage in a single turn.  Needlessly complex and has annoying terminology.  Not for me.  Also, its a living card game.  Meh.

RATING: 8
FFG have done a superb job with this relaunch. It's a complicated game to learn, however once learnt it's one of the best two player card games out there. I think you'll especially enjoy this if you have a technical job (e.g programmers, web-designers, server engineers). It's worth noting that the base set alone is a great experience and a self-contained game - you could play this for a long time and still have fun.

RATING: 10
This game is very deep, and one of the most satisfying 2 player duel games I've ever played. TONS of replayability, and is a fantastic reboot of a classic game. Very glad to be able to deckbuild now that card availability is not an issue. Full disclosure: I am a playtester for the game (AND a computer professional, so the theme is a hit for me), but I wouldn't be so enthusiastic about it if it wasn't consuming my thoughts.  Highest of recommendations.

RATING: 3
Pros:
- Nice artwork
- Interesting concept pitting two highly different opponents against each other

Cons:
- Far too luck-based for my tastes
- The runner is far more interesting to play than the corporation
- Deckbuilding is what makes the game interesting, but you need several expansions for that
- Money drain
- Annoying fanboys (though you cannot fault the game for that)

Conclusion: while the core idea behind the game is not bad, I don't want to play it as I would not be a match for those who know all the expansions by heart, and I do not want to invest money nor time in a game that was designed as a money drain. Were this game a one-time purchase (base game plus maybe 2 expansions in one box, and that's it), I might consider playing it. As it is, my first few plays sufficed for my final assessment: this is definitely not for me.

RATING: N/A
Not willing to state much of an opinion until I've actually played it more as these sorts of card games with deck construction don't lend themselves to first impressions.

Since tokens are used for paying cards that are accumulated separate from the actual decks, the resource system is not nearly as frustrating as other deck construction games. But I fear that assets\resources are sort of similar. Your economy really can be shot within a couple of turns and the wild asymmetry to the game makes analyzing play extremely difficult.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm not an LCG-kinda gamer and wasn't seeking out any inspiration to pursue a career in Netrunning, but I thought it was a worthwhile thing to do as a hobby gamer to play the best-rated LCG game out there: Android: Netrunner (or as I call it: 'Johnny Mnemonic: The Card Game'). As my gaming buddy said, it's great to have a semi-collectable card game out there where it isn't just all about "he who has the strongest monsters wins," and he's absolutely right. Netrunner is quite interesting as both sides play differently and the theme comes out through the mechanics. Players are rewarded by knowing the cards and anticipating good synergies. And it's a fairly tense game, though I was surprised that meeting the primary win condition can have a lot to do with what cards you pull. But it's obvious that the stronger player will win most games, though this luck factor doesn't make it a foregone conclusion. But you have to anticipate and control for that luck and not necessarily succumb to it; so again, I think there's enough in Netrunner to say it's not just a two-bit money sinkhole whose fanbase can't be readily explained like some Pokemon fad. I'm still not going to pursue this or any LCG game at the moment (maybe if I was there from the beginning my thoughts would have been different). But I can see the appeal and I can understand why the game has lasting power.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is based on the original edition of Netrunner (Wizards of the Coast) from the 1990s.  An excellent set of rules for an asymmetric 2-player card game that simulate a conflict of Runner and the Corporation they are trying to steal data from.  Very good rules with little or no timing issues.  In this edition it is a Living Card Game, with fixed expansion sets rather than purely random decks.

RATING: 6
Update: Ultimately the fact that this is an LCG killed it for me. I can't commit to a single game to the level needed to follow a CCG or LCG. The turning point came when I participated a mini-tournament after a few months not playing. I spent multiple rounds setting up something only to discover that I had misremembered a rule and what I was working towards wasn't actually a valid thing. It's the closest I've ever come to literally flipping a table. Instead I conceded and walked away to calm down.

I honestly doubt I'll ever play this game again, but could possibly be talked into it.

Original Review:
My favorite LCG (Living Card Game). I always liked the original CCG, but never got that into it, largely because it wasn't big in my area and I never owned many cards. 

The preconstructed decks seem to favor the runners, but now that we're finally getting into constructed decks, things seem to be evening out a bit. I'm looking forward to future "data packs."

RATING: 8
Absolutely amazing living card game!! The asymmetrical style of play is something very new for me and very very interesting. It's also perhaps the best union of theme and mechanics I've ever seen a game. With regular expansions provided by FFG this game is bound to be around for a long time.

Only downside is like all LCGs once you tinker with the starter decks it becomes less easy to introduce new players to the game.

2018-01: After rotation and the release of the release of the new core set I think this is heading rapidly back in the right direction. 10 for the new core set / cache refresh, and 9 for standard competitions.

RATING: 9.5
One of the best card games out there if you can commit to it. I haven't moved past owning 2 base sets, and likely never will unless someone lends me a deck. The game is simply too big for casual players, but in an ideal world I'd play this all the time. The mechanics work so well with the theme, and it's made me love asymmetrical games.

The game only loses a point because it can be very brain-burny, with some of the rules nuances being annoyingly complex.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game was originally described to me as "Cerebral." Boy, is it ever. This game will bake your brain, especially with it's un-accessible manual that raises more questions than it answers. Just watch some You Tube videos. You'll get it eventually.
A sequel of sorts to "Magic:The Gathering," I don't think this is the bluffing game to replace poker that Dr. Richard Garfield was trying to create. But it's amazing, stunningly complex, and very rewarding. The bluffing is there, but it's more "bait" than "bluff."
I suggest you grow into it with a worthy opponent who is willing to keep pace with you game for game. Both of you will appreciate it even more as you hone your skills. But don't keep it to yourself. Once you have the concepts down, get out there and try it with other players. There's still enough luck involved that you could take down an experienced player in one match.
The balance between skill and luck is better demonstrated here in this game than any other I've played.
However, like "Magic," I fear Netrunner will eventually devolve into a game of specific "I win" decks, brandished by nerds with nothing better to do than think of every way possible to ruin your strategy and this game. It hasn't happened, yet. And maybe it never will, but take a chance and try it out before it becomes so evolved with expansion packs that you'll never catch up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I enjoy Netrunner ok, but the games seem to take such a long time to play out. It would be much better if it too us less time to play.
