=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In the late 90's, Wizards of the Coast threatened to fire the designers of the then-recent Magic: The Gathering Urza block because the expansion 'power creep-ed' the entire game a couple of steps. The fallout gave way to the Masques Block, an overall weaker (pay no mind to Rishadan Port) block that allowed the developers time to conceptualize a healthier environment in the following blocks: Invasion and Odyssey (arguably some of the better expansions at that point in Magic's lifespan). So where does Netrunner fit in all of this?...

Netrunner began experiencing a power-creep with cards like D4v1d, NAPD Contract, Caprice Nisei, while already existing overpowered cards remained in the format (Breaking News, San San City Grid, Desperado, Clone Chip to name a few). Rather than address the problem with many of the base cards and either issue bans or errata, a 'Most Wanted List', which increased influence on a given card, was introduced as the balancing mechanism. In theory this could have addressed problems with the game, except that most of the cards appearing on the list continued to see competitive play in overpowered decks. Then, rather than scale back the design of potentially-overpowered cards, the designers introduced a slough of broken cards and assumed that they could balance the environment after-the-fact: 24/7 News Cycle, Global Food Initiative, Museum of History, Wireless Net Pavilion, Explode-a-Palooza, SYNC, Haarpsichord Studios, Faust, Marcus Batty.      

The result was a game that was more about 'cheating' agendas into your scoring area and fast advancing or, from the runner's vantage point, a game about avoiding all ice entirely in addition to multi-accessing. One of my friends won a tournament running a corp deck that contained only 6 ice, none of which actually ended the run. As the power of the cards grew, so did the supply of 'silver bullet' cards that served no purpose but to counter one card in competitive use, a clear sign of an unhealthy tournament environment. What was once a game where bad luck in accessing or bad draws were forgivable due to the relative balance of power level was now totally dependent on early game power plays and luck. Just go out and search for the distribution of runners and corps for a given tournament... you'll find that one corp is dominant (likely NBN) and one runner is mostly dominant (Anarchs) and one runner is hardly used (Criminals).

To add to this is frustration in the prospect of spending money on expansions that are poorly balanced. If you have all the money in the world, no problem. But many of the cards of late are either broken, silver bullets (competitive only), or unplayable (Jesminder, Laramy Fisk, I could go on and on about criminal cards here).

I enjoyed playing this game for years, but it's difficult to seriously consider playing again after looking at new card spoilers. At its peak, I'd rate Netrunner an 8 or 9.

Edit (9/18/2017): I just looked over Netrunner's latest revised edition of the Core Set, and I strongly approve. I probably would have removed Datasucker, Pop-up Window, and Diesel too, but they recognized a lot of the weaker and stronger cards, removing them in the process. The cards they've included in place of the more broken cards include some of the more fun and balanced cards they designed early on. This is a big step towards making Netrunner an enjoyable game again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I know that this game is well regarded, but my wife and I couldn't get into the game.  Maybe the theme combined with the asymmetric element of the game didn't appeal to my wife.  Further, reading the manual was a slog and hurt the chances of the game hitting the table multiple times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I can't decide yet. Love the asymmetrical play. Annoyed by cards that I never want to play in the core set (solved by deckbuilding). Have had a couple of very frustrating plays where the game seemed to be decided on who got lucky enough to draw the Corp's agendas first.

Now that I have done some deckbuilding, I am afraid that the immense number of cards makes this game all about the Meta.  Which decks you bring to the table and which cards you pick for your deck have way too much bearing on the outcome.  So the game becomes a bit of a guessing game as you try to think about what you should include to stop what deck your opponent might build.  I think this can be fixed a bit by limiting which card sets you play with.  So, I'm done buying new cards.  But it means I can only play against others who do the same, or I will be in for some rude surprises and many silly losses.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I feel this game deserves a two-part review, one from the perspective of the Core Set, and another as a competitive LCG:

- as a Core Set this game is fun, with 4 Corp and 3 Runner factions there are enough permutations to keep you interested for multiple games. The game is outstanding fun mechanically, however the Core set is really only the beginning, and will leave you wanting more ...

- speaking of 'more', as an LCG this has to be the best out there. The competitive scene is incredible fun with great support from FFG. The cost-barrier to entry is currently very very large and you'll be looking to spend roughly £200/$300 before you can be considered to have a competitive deck. I play this more than any other game I've ever owned though, and believe that it's totally worth it.

RATING: 6.5
This is a good game that I don't particularly like, and my rating reflects preference rather than the quality of the game. The theme is well-implemented BUT I don't like the theme. The mechanics yield a deep play experience BUT they aren't mechanics I especially like (for example the resolution system versus ice reminds me of scrounging factors to get a column break in a wargame, never my favorite thing to do). The opening act of the game offers multiple paths to victory and opportunities to bluff/counter-bluff BUT I prefer games that spool up faster and begin at the point of impact. If you like the flavors that I dislike, then you will likely like this game (!).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I resisted this at first because of my bad first experiences with LCG's. Any game element which reduces a beloved character--Legolas, say-- and his sum of being to, basically, "8 strength points," is neither thematic nor distinguished mechanically.

But Android: Netrunner is fantastic! Why? Simply put, bluffing and asymmetry. I haven't heard anyone compare this to a two-person Cosmic Encounter before, but that's what it feels like (even if the mechanisms are completely different). Is it thematic? Ask instead, why is there, like, a dragon made out of LED's on every other ICE card? Who knows? Who cares? The theme is most expressively forwarded in the way the game plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An excellent asymmetrical two-player card game with solid mechanics and tense player interactions.  Lots of resource management and bluffing.  

The cyber-noir(punk)theme fits extremely well with the gameplay and is further reinforced by some amazing artwork.  

Absolutely my favorite two-player card game and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys "heads-up" dueling card games.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.15
Found memories of the original version.  This newer release combines great art and an intriguing storyline that I enjoy.  The deckbuilding element remains intact and I'm sure FFG will only make it better for years to come.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Watched 2 new players try to play this and it seemed awful. first game just ended abruptly with a "well... I guess you just won, but I don't know how or why..." and the second dragged on and on. Would like to see 2 players who know the game play to see what we missed. EDIT- Still not my kind of game, but I know a lot of people who love it, so good on you, Netrunner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Lots of depth, but not so much that it gets overwhelming. I really like the Game of Thrones card game in theory, but in practice there's so much card-specific text that you spend half your time studying your opponents cards. Netrunner strikes a better balance. Once you know the basic rules, the individual cards don't change the mechanics too dramatically.

Update: I just played four games in a row, and I was really impressed by how infrequently we needed to refer to the rulebook. And we never had to go scouring through FAQs or internet forums to answer timing questions like happens with other card games like this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
A tremendous experience.  I enjoy both sides of the table.  Playing the Corp is tense, nervous, and full of difficult decisions on how to shore up defenses that are never quite strong enough.  I especially enjoy HB, even though I'm terrible at it, and Weyland, but Jinteki is fun too, and NBN is wonderfully thematic.  Playing the Runner is a more reckless, go-for-broke kind of experience.  I especially like playing the Anarchs (with their viruses) and the Criminals (with their back doors).  For me, those two decks do a great job of marrying the theme to the gameplay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love CCG/LCGs, but I can acknowledge some of the inherent weaknesses in the genre.  Often times it seems like the most important decisions happen while building the deck rather than playing, and poor card draw can literally leave a player helpless.

Perhaps the most important innovation of A:NR is that it is an LCG that doesn't play you.  Yes, deck building still matters, but deck enhance a set of abilities that every play has.  Each player has a number of "clicks" each turn which represent a sort of time economy.  A player can always spend a click to draw a card or gain a credit.  Of course, cards allow you to do things more efficiently, but this ensures that there is a game to play even when you are short on cards or haven't seen the right ones.

Clicks are also necessary to play any card from your hand, which makes your in game decisions matter much more.  Gone are those MTG moments when you empty your hand onto the battlefield.  Each card you play matters not just because of the money you have to spend on it, but also because of the time it takes to play that card.  Do you have time to play this card, or do you have to get aggressive now?  I wish more games had a system like this for regulating the tempo of the game.

I have said nothing about the bluffing aspect the game, but what is there to say that other players haven't?  Some people have expressed frustration about what this does to learning curve.  I've seen plenty of people walk away from this game grumbling about how either the corp or the runner is completely over-powered.  They hadn't figured out the game yet.  This game does take time to learn, but for an LCG that is a major perk.  If I'm going to invest in this game, I want know that I stand to grow with it.  That's what this game has to offer that is so exciting: I know how hard it is, so I know what it means when I see myself getting better.  Don't think of A:NR as a series of isolated games, the game is getting to know the game!

There is so much more I could say about A:NR, but I'll just leave it at this: A:NR is the best thing happening in analog gaming right now.  You have to try it!

RATING: 6
(update) rating drop from 10 to 6 with the latest expansion releases.  playing the corp is now an exercise in futility.

A worthy succesor to Magic in my collection for a duel-type card game.

great theme, interesting play.

LCG is quite desirable over a collectable game, esp. once some more expansions come out.  Even with the core set, 4 corporations and 3 hackers make for alot of game play, just with the starter builds.  Factor in deckbuilding and the you get alot of a small box.

RATING: 6
This feels like one of the most overrated games on BGG. I've been a longtime fan of M:TG, and like the cyberpunk theme, so that combined with the high reviews gave me high hopes for this one, but I am let down. It feels rather flat, with much less variety and variability of strategies than it seemed like it would have had. Rather, the play seems rather formulaic and mechanical: 

if Corp {
  limit remote servers;
  put multiple layers of ice;
  use some dupe assets to fool Runner into trap;}

if Runner {
  collect lots of credits;
  make runs early and often;}

/game

It also feels imbalanced (in Runner's favor) -- is that my imagination?

I will give it a few more plays with different Corps and Runner factions, but... do I need to buy expansions to make this interesting?

RATING: 7
The biggest pro for me with this game is how the game mechanics work. They're interesting, a bit different to most other things out there, and there's a strong match with the game and its theming... I'm a fan of the theme in general, and it's well implemented here. I like the asymmetric sides, which seem to be pretty well balanced, and overall it's certainly very well designed. However, out of the box, it's nowhere near deserving of the level of hype it gets. The variation between the decks is good, but the variation within the starter cards for each faction is pretty poor. You need to buy expansions with it to get anywhere near the most out of the game; without that it gets stale fairly quickly. Not as quickly as many other LCGs, and it's maybe more a flaw of the whole LCG genre than anything else, but I find myself more quickly losing interest in them than other game types (despite over the years being a big fan of card games).

RATING: 9.5
The most tense, and probably the most thematic, card game I've played and a load of fun. Cyberpunk hacker themed, allowing for clever combo blending long-term strategy of your custom deck build, short term opportunism and a heavy dose of bluff and mind games it ticks nearly all the boxes for what I enjoy in a game. However it suffers from only 2 drawbacks. As a 'lifestyle' game it requires committing the time to regular play, continually keeping up to date with new cards and planning and assembling new decks of cards to experiment with in play. Which is sadly why I no longer play. It also only plays 2 and is definitely not for the conflict adverse.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Android: Netrunner has sold me on LCGs.  I have a hard time ever thinking about playing another booster pack based card game again.  

Netrunner is a brilliant game that really chews at a player's brain.  The smallest clerical error in counting credits or cards can result in a loss or a victory.  This shows how delicately, yet expertly, balanced the game is.

And when it comes down to it, the game is all math driven under the hood but it throws a layer of player skill (in bluffing and deception) on top that makes the game a superb competitive offering where player skill really shines over the "variance" aspect of other card games.

The greatest feature is the asymmetrical design of a Runner vs a Corporation.  Each player is playing a completely different game while battling for the same end goal (and the caveat that the runner can lose based on damage).

There is a lot going for this game and the base set is clearly one of the strongest sets.  In fact for those not interested in the competitive scene there is hundreds of hours of play to have in the base set alone.

This is the card game of the future folks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Stopped playing, partly to the rather anti-social deckbuilding aspect (you're sitting by yourself a lot) and partly because i felt the noise-virus-trash-r&d-deck was overpowered.. no corporation i played against had a chance.
_________________________

Man is this addictive..! Imho this game has some huge advantages over MtG:
Bluffing is a major part of the game, and that's great, MtG is pretty much in your face all the time.
Asymmetry, playing the hacker or the corporate is hugely different.
Theming, whereas in MtG you hurl spells at each other, A:NR is much richer in theme.. every mechanic, every cardpile, every action makes thematic sense. And that is awesome.

Now the negatives:
I would have liked the Mage Wars mechanic of choosing the card you would like to play, instead of drawing randomly.
I don't like the thousand expansions.. this is becoming magic the gathering sci-fi.. and I don't like money-sinks.

RATING: 10
A game of territory, of secrecy, and of many cat and mouse chases. There really is no other way to describe Android: Netrunner, as both players will be playing a game of territory with each other, with one player hiding his cards while the other tries to capture them. In Netrunner, one player plays a futuristic corporation trying to protect themselves against a group of people called Runners, while the other player plays as the Runner, trying to hack their way through to stop the corporation. Netrunner makes for a great game to play over and over because it is asymmetric: the Runner plays by different rules than the corporation, but I will talk about that later.
Premise:
Netrunner takes place in a futuristic society ruled by various corporations and technology. Seeing the effect computer technology has had on our society, transforming it in various ways, really makes Netrunner seem plausible. The game originally came out in 1996 as Netrunner (not Android: Netrunner), designed by Richard Garfield, the creator of Magic: the Gathering. It was a time before computer technology really took its grasp on society, before social media and smart phones, so for Garfield to have created this world full of technology taking over people’s lives really was an incredible vision. Eventually the game was picked up by Fantasy Flight, and added to their Android universe. In addition, the game went from being a traditional trading card game, where the player had to buy packs of cards to build their deck, to simply a card game, creating a set that had all of the base cards in it with multiple factions to play as for each side.
Both players can choose a faction from four Corporation factions and three Runner factions. Each faction has their own specific cards and special abilities. Once the player chooses which faction they want to play as, they can start building their deck. For beginners, it’s probably a good idea to simply use your faction’s cards and the miscellaneous cards that every faction can use. Learning the game will take a few plays as there are a good number of rules; it can be confusing and overwhelming at first. Don’t let that stop you as the game is fun once you get the hang of it.
Each player has a certain number of clicks, which are like moves in a turn. What the Corporation can do using their clicks is a little different than what the Runner does. The Corporation needs to focus on a more defensive battle. Use Ice (defensive cards) to protect your R&D, Headquarters, and Archives (deck, hand, and discard pile respectively). You also need to build remote servers and protect them. The Runner’s job is to make runs on the Corporation’s servers, whether they are remote servers or Central servers (R&D, HQ, and Archives). Think of runs like hacking a system. The game is literally about computer and software hacking.
The goal of the game is to score Agendas. How you go about doing that is where the game gets interesting. The Corporation installs Agendas in remote servers and spends turns advancing them. If he advances them enough, he gains that Agenda (such as a private security force). The Runner can score Agendas by making successful runs on a remote server where an Agenda is installed. 
A Game of Strategy
This is where the cat and mouse games come in. Throughout the game, the Runner needs to constantly be thinking about the next run, trying to make sure it is as successful as possible. He needs to install Icebreakers to break through the Corporation’s defenses. He needs to install protection to make sure he doesn’t get hurt if he does. He needs to gain money to help pay for breaking through everything.
Meanwhile the Corporation has a little bit more on his mind. He needs to plan ahead so that when he installs an Agenda, it doesn’t get run on and stolen. He needs to plan his defenses. The Corporation gets fewer clicks per turn than the Runner, so he needs to use his time wisely. He needs money to pay for defenses and Agendas. He needs to install and protect his assets so that the Runner doesn’t destroy them.
I called the game a game of territory at one point, and playing through, it’s easy to see so. The Corporation creates all of these servers with various protections. The Corporation is playing a very defensive game of King of the Hill, trying to make sure the Runner never gets through his defenses and onto his servers. At the same time, the Runner is playing Capture the Flag, trying to get the assets and Agendas installed on the servers.
The strategies each player employs really comes through with their decks. Some Corporation factions are more geared toward running the Runner dry, keeping his money low, having him struggling to build. Other factions are geared toward trickery, laying down traps in their servers. The Runner can try to brute force his way through the servers early or try to wait until late in the game, if he can survive that long.
There are many different ways of playing, depending on the deck you build, letting the player coming back, trying to new strategies against even the same opponent. It makes the replayability very high.
 Overall
This is definitely a must-have game if you like strategy games. Fantasy Flight does a fantastic job at creating this universe and immersing the player. There is tons of reason to keep playing the game, even if you only play against one person as you both can keep changing things up, building new decks, employing new strategies. Plus, it’s always fun to try and get into another person’s head.

RATING: 10
This game is quickly becoming my no.1 favorite game of all time, all games considered, not just card games.

You wouldn't believe the amount of theme a card game like this could have. It's mind blowing. My mind = blown.

It's hard to explain but everything you do "makes sense" and feels like you're doing what you're doing. A "job" card feels like a job because after playing it on the table you can start spending precious time going to work, time that you could use for other things, just to earn some money. Or.. I dunno, Wyldside, which is a seedy Nightclub card. Once you play it your runner starts spending time there. Sure enough he makes contacts, gains resources, and learns new tricks BUT you can't choose to stop going there. You're addicted! It's Brilliant!

And each new Data Pack just makes me giddy like a school girl. The game is getting better and better. I'm so hooked!

RATING: 10
After reading the rules and following the forums for a few months, I like the concept and asymetrical gameplay.  Finally, a game that plays differently than MtG/WhI.  I hope that the bluffing aspect of the game will be strong enough to influence the experience.  

I am a bit concerned about the number of cards that sit on the table (meaning how much you need to remember to play effectivelly and still enjoy the experience) and the constant calculations (hopefully it is nothing close to Thunderstone, which seemed like an exercise in Maths).  It will all be clear in about a month when the games hits the shelves. 

Update.  Fortunately, my early fears about similarities with Thunderstone were totally wrong.  Netrunner plays smoothly and presents the players with many decisions.  The games played with the same decks unfold differently based on the initial decisions...

RATING: 7.5
Though I've only played twice this year, I've actually played many, many times over the past 3 or 4 years. I have the base set and a lot of the data packs and expansions. I'm bored with my current deck and want to build a new one before playing again...but...so many cards...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Most CCG/LCGs are based on bringing cards into play and attacking and defending with them. I like Netrunner very much because it plays very different to this formula.

One player (the Runner) accesses cards on some servers trying to steal the other player's agendas, while the other player (the Corp) secures the servers with ICE cards, and builds new servers to advance his agendas and to play additional assets.

It doesn't feel as attacking or defending, but as intrusion and counter-intrusion. The Runner searches for vulnerabilities to exploit and the Corp looks to make every intrusion as difficult as possible. Gameplay feels super thematic. The artwork and the cyberpunk background fits perfectly.

Some minor flaws prevent this game from reaching perfection: the first turns are too luck dependant, and you need many plays to learn to play properly.

RATING: 7.5
This was actually my introduction to table top board gaming. Ruben and I used to play Magic the Gathering, but the sheer expense and commitment that hobby required deterred both of us. So I started looking for games that were similar, but more manageable. I found out Netrunner was designed by the same game designer as MtG, and I was sold! 

It took us a LONG time to figure this game out. I can't really speak intelligently as to the quality of this game, because our first time playing it felt fairly clunky. I did like the theme (cyber punk dystopia? yes plz), and I hope to play it again. However, this isn't a game that's really easy to sit down and learn. Once we have the rules down I think Netrunner will provide us with a game that has a high challenge level but reasonable play time. But until then, we don't really have the time to sit down and learn it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As the game grows, it becomes harder to get it to the table if I'm not playing against someone who is keeping up with the new Data Packs; and teaching it to new people without extensive card sorting and deck re-hauling has become effectively impossible.

That said, this is a fantastic game, with fantastic mechanics. The asymmetry of the play styles is inspired, and the slight psychological/bluffing factor opens up tactics that wouldn't be possible in other games.

Great versus other hardcore fans if you have the Data Packs, but still great with new people if you're only using the Core Set. As a matter of fact, if you care enough, I would almost recommend getting a Core Set for the sole purpose of playing with new people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Un juego asimétrico donde los dos roles se juegan de manera muy distinta. Gran componente de faroleo, dado que la corporación construye defensas ocultas y trata de anotar puntos desarrollando sus planes, mientras que el runner las ataca para desarticularlas. Me gusta la sensación de evaluar riesgos, farolear, tomar riesgos e incluso hacer locuras y que no puedas ganar si sólo te mantienes en tu zona segura "tortugueando" PROS Mucho tema, buen trabajo artístico. Las condiciones de victoria tienen sentido. Metajuego: preparar el mazo antes de jugar. El juego base es más que suficiente para jugadores casuales. El tema es más atrayente que el de 1936 Guerra Civil y puede que vea más mesa. CONS: Poca variedad para la construcción de mazos. *Necesitas* expansiones para saborear bien este aspecto del juego. El tema se ha tomado tan en serio que hay que aprender jerga ("empuñadura", "I+D", "Archivos", "Servidores"...) Gran diferencia entre jugadores experimentados y novatos. Ideas de un juego de 36€ que al final, cuestan mucho más. Problemas de aleatoriedad. En NETO: un runner roba cartas boca abajo (ocultas)a la corporación deseando no coger la equivocada. 

Salvando las distancias, el tema y el faroleo, tema y el aspecto de Living Card Games, 1936 Guerra Civil me atrae más como juego de cartas a 2 personas. Es más barato, aunque más arduo, lo reconozco.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
If you can deal with the needlessly dense and confusing language the game uses and the standard issue FF mess of a rulebook there seems to be a moderately interesting game to be had.  The game seems deliberately designed to force both players to make risky moves out of necessity - if the Runner plays it safe he will certainly lose, so the only option is to take risky gambles in order to force the Corp to stretch its resources.  Only played one learning game so there was nothing one could reasonably call strategy involved, but I can see how two experienced players can make it a good game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Woefully, this is very hard to learn. ICE Breaker and ICE have very abstract Images that are hard to remember, and you will need a lot of games to feel comfortable playing this.

If you do, you are rewarded with hands down one of the best games for two players. Every turn is full of meaningful decisions, the Theme comes together (again, at the expense of learning the game - calling the Draw Deck "Research and Development", the Cards in your Hand "Headquarters" and the Discarded Cards "Archives" make it harder to teach, because the terminology is important, as with any card game). I can only advise to seek out a local community and take the extra effort to learn this game. You won't regret it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Excellent Asymmetric play. One of the only games where I enjoy the "Control" style more than the Aggressive style.

RATING: 10
Netrunner is probably the best collectible/living/customizable/whatever card game to date. It is the best of this genre to have made the actual playing portion of the card game be driven by more than just a well-built deck; Netrunner manages to reward players' in-game skills as well.
Combine this feat with an outright uncanny show of masterful game design and you have a winning formula.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Whew! What to say about Netrunner? It's a very interesting card game. You may play an evil corporation, secretly pushing your own agendas and bluffing your way to victory...or you may play a hacker attempting to manage your risks and uncover the corporation's agendas.

The real beauty of Netrunner comes in the deckbuilding. It's a game of statistics, resource management, bluffing, and risk management. You almost have to play it a few times to really understand.

It's a great game, but the base set only offers a taste. You'll want many more cards to get the full experience.

RATING: 10
I always have fun playing this game, even if I get creamed.
It's almost pure strategy, with a bit of luck for the runner when he runs on the central servers. This feels less like luck and more like calculated risk, and deckbuilding can increase your likelihood of hitting those agendas.
There are a million different deck types for both sides, and even with just the core set, you can make some pretty distinct decks.
I love it.

RATING: 10
Before playing Android: Netrunner, I did not think it was a game that I would enjoy given that I had no experience with LCGs or CCGs and had no interest in deckbuilding or the card tournament scene.  But, after reading countless  reviews and being intrigued by the prospect of a deeply thematic two-player strategy game that my wife and I could learn and play together, I picked-up a copy of the core set.  Now, after logging multiple plays, I can say that I really, really enjoy this game.  So much so that we've purchased all of the expansions and have been incorporating the new cards into our decks - which turns out to be a lot more fun than I thought it would be.  A:NR has become my wife and I's go-to game in the evenings - it is a quick-playing, interactive, deep, strategic game that is not growing stale.  I really cannot find anything to dislike.  10 out of 10.

Weighted Rating: 10 (Fun 10; Gameplay 10; Components 10; Theme 10).  

Formula:
[Weighted rating = (((Fun*4) + (Gameplay*3) + (Components *2) + (Theme *1))/10)]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've only played with the pre-constructed decks, so you could argue that I've missed a big part of the actual game. Asymmetry is an interesting mechanic to me but it doesn't seem to be super balanced, at least with the pre-constructed decks in the base set. In our experience the runner is more likely to win, and some cursory google searching has revealed that we aren't alone in that. It seems like if you wait too long as the corporation the runner will have such a strong setup that they can plow through even your really powerful ICEs, but then early you need the right one or two ICEs to protect your cards. And as the corporation your ICEs apply to a single spot, where the runner can have all their stuff apply to whichever column they happen to be attacking at the time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Wow! What a fantastic game! I wish I could play it more.

RATING: 10
This is now my favorite card game with LotR and A Game of Thrones right behind it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
love the game, best 2 player card game I've played.

The luck of card draw that plagues LCG/CCG's is somewhat mitigated by bluffing, and cards that allow you to dig for other cards that you need.

Needs to be played between players who put the same amount of investment into the game, eg. no point in someone who does a lot of deckbuilding playing against someone who just uses the same decks every game. Or someone with only the first few expansions and no knowledge of other cards vs someone who has everything (not having all the expansions isn't necessarily a disadvantage, but lack of card knowledge and therefore the ability to deckbuild properly is).

Unfortunately the rate at which new cards are released has caused the card pool to get to a silly size, and resulted in a significant barrier to entry for new players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
3 copies + all expansions
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This comment will read almost identically to my thoughts on the Game of Thrones card game: the barrier to entry for new players is REALLY high (it'll take three games just to digest the rules, and another three to get a feel for the basic cut-and-thrust going on; THEN you can start playing, but by that time, most folks have quit.)

But if you can get over that hurdle, it's a phenomenal two player card game.  The deckbuilding element is better in AGOT, the in-game experience is less of a brainburner and more of a bluffing game in Netrunner.  The base set here is better than the AGOT core set, so if you're just going to buy one $30 box, stick with this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The theme is great (the mechanics reflect it so well) and the bluffing and luck-pushing elements make the game very tense. Though the elements of luck can sometimes get a bit out of hand, it is tolerable (I find that there is as much luck as there is luck management and that a skilled player can usually turn a bad hand into a series of smart plays).

The main problem is that the gameplay isn't smooth. Part of this comes from the use of the Living Card Game model. While I prefer it to the Collectible Card Game model for monetary reasons, a design that allows for constant expansion usually results in mechanics that are fidgety and filled with edge cases. I can't count the number of times I have attempted a strategy only to have it pointed out that one word on a card has a slightly different meaning than I thought it did.

That combined with getting a late start into the game's ecosystem (it isn't much fun playing against those who have been playing since day one and have access and familiarity with many of the prevailing strategies) means that I might keep what I have for some casual play, but I'm not going to try and catch up with players who have been invested since the beginning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
This is an additional copy I acquired for deck-building purposes. See my other copy for a rating and comments.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I played the original, which was pretty broken and fun. The new version has obviously gone through more play testing and balancing, and it's still fun. 

The core decks seemed to play just fine against each other, although a couple of core sets are going to be required for any kind of competitive build. 

I've been out of the game for a while, and was discussing power creep with an avid player. His take is that the cards are not getting stronger on average, but rather that more options have been opened. I'm strongly considering a return to the casual/competitive scene, and will have more to say about balance afterwards.

RATING: 7

RATING: 10
I've never played LCGs, CCGs, TCGs ... anything. I have a few friends that play MtG, but I've never even really watched them play.

Point being: I am the furthest from knowledgeable about card games as anyone can be. However, I took it upon myself to find a card game that my girlfriend and I could occasionally play.

Being a big FFG fan (and the fact that this site rated Android Netrunner so highly) I figured I'd give it a go. As of writing this, I have only played one game, but it was VERY fun. There was a bit of a learning curve (at least for me), but once crossed, it was pretty straight-forward. The systems seem to offer a good deal of possibility for various strategies and I've already recognized that I will need to identify opposing strategies moving forward and build my deck with options to counter them (Icebreaker buff cards, I'm looking at you). I'm curious how long the core set will last me before I need to expand, but hopefully I'll be good for a while.

But yeah, very fun game. I'd definitely recommend, even if (or possibly in spite of the fact that) you're like me who is totally new to games like this.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really like this game for a number for reasons:

1) The asymmetrical nature of the game.  It is one of the few games that manages to do asymmetry in a way that feels balanced and interesting for both sides.

2) The hidden information.  It's amazing how quickly a "run" can turn around when a big ice is revealed, or how fast a whole game can be won or lost when the runner hits a particularly nasty trap.  This, combined with the scarcity of cards to reveal hidden information (so far) keeps the runner on his toes and helps maintain the balance.

3) The fact that strategy and bluffing are more important than luck.  Because you have the ability to take actions to shore up areas where you are weak, drawing cards to search for that key icebreaker, or taking bits when your bit engines are exhausted, you can exert more control in a game where luck isn't coming through.  And while you may still end up in a situation where you never draw your key icebreaker or any bit engines at all, it doesn't feel quite as powerless as being "mana screwed" in MtG.  You can always do something to control your situation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2013-02-20

Current Rating: N/A
[hr]

2013-03-07

After a couple more games, I’m beginning to see why this has gone up so quickly on the BGG ratings (it is currently number 6). I have only played as the Hacker, but now I want to play more. For me the game has a lot to offer, each faction plays differently and I feel the game is very deep with hard decisions EACH TURN which is what I want in my preferred games. Also the play time is under 1 hour and many times half that time. 

I love the asymmetric play, I wish more card games were like this. The rules are a bit involved but not overly complex. Explaining the game can be long because you have to teach both sides, however I really like the gameplay and bluffing required (by the corporation) to win. I’m amazed (and a little embarrassed) that I have never even heard of Netrunner before FFG picked up the game.

As is usual with FFG, the cards and components are top quality, I specially dig the cyberpunk art, it is great and conveys the theme perfectly :thumbsup:. In general I’m not interested (much) in the deck building facet, but I appreciate it is there if I need it (from time to time I DO delve in this), also I know this is one the main selling points for Netrunner. What I used to do with MtG (and I plan to do with AN and Mage Wars) is to look up on the internet some cool decks to play with :D.

Currently, I´m trying desperately to promote this game (and Mage Wars) among my friends and game groups so we can all evolve together and get lots and lots of plays.

Bottom line, Android: Netrunner is a wonderful 2 player game which I want to explore it further and it has the potential to go up in my ratings. I’m very excited about this one, already pre ordered the expansion packs and I want to play (at least once) the original game. 

Current Rating: 7.5
[hr]
2013-03-18

Netrunner has sucked me deep enough that I want to try my hand at some deckbuilding, I didn’t had this urge since I abandoned MtG years ago. I think I like deckbuilding in Netrunner because the options are not limitless, you have influence points to spend so I feel it is not that consuming time wise.

I’m upgrading its rating to denote my new feelings toward the game. I already built some decks and I can’t wait to test them, fortunately I have promoted this game among many friends so I won’t lack an opponent.

Great game. I’m already committed to buy all the game coming expansions, right now I have the four data packs that FFG released. 

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2013-05-06

This game definitely will enter my top ten of favorite games. Now I want to always play it and I’m also building decks for it. So far it seems the runner is much more powerful that the corporations, I always win when I play the runner and I almost always lose when I play a corporation, however I enjoy more the game when I’m playing with the corp. I suck at it but I enjoy it. So far only my GF has fallen for my traps when I’m playing with the corp. It seems I need to improve my bluffing skills.

From now on I will always play at least 2 games with the same person, one with a runner and another with a corp, that is, I will follow the tournament rules even though I won’t ever participate in a tournament. 

On the other hand I’m very disappointed that I cannot build the decks I want because the core game doesn’t have 3 copies of each card, the worst offender (so far) are the Desperado console and Ice Carver. I need more copies of those cards but I don’t have them and I have bought everything Netrunner so far :angry:. I won’t buy another core set just for these cards and even if I did, I still would not have the complete 3 set :angry::angry::angry:.

Current Rating: 9.0
[hr]
2016-02-21

I still love Android: Netrunner, but as the game continues to expand, many friends stopped playing it. All of us play causal so getting the game to the table has been harder and harder. Android: Netrunner is certainly a lifestyle game. You need to spend a lot of time creating and tweaking your decks and the meta game changes a lot with each expansion they release. I still think it is a tremendous game and I still buy every expansion FFG releases, but I no longer deckbuild my decks. With the new expansions, creating a new deck isn’t as easy as was before. Now you have a plethora of options so I’m going back to my previous custom and I look the best decks online. I won’t do any more deckbuilding, it consumes way too much time. Another bad thing about this, is that new players feel overwhelmed when faced with all the cards the game now offers, so finding new opponents hasn’t been easy.

In general, if a game is a reprint of another, it isn’t eligible to participate in my lists of top ten favorite games by year. Android: Netrunner is eligible to participate because it seems FFG improved the game a lot with the new edition (added lots of cards and identities) and I still haven’t played the old edition. If I do I will come back to rethink this point.

Current Rating: 8.0
[hr]
2016-12-14

This past year I almost didn’t play any game of Android: Netrunner. I still think it is a tremendous game, but getting it to the table these days is next to impossible. I think I will stop buying expansions for it. Also my desire to play it again isn’t as high as before, now, building the decks is more of a chore than a joy. Due to all of this I’m downgrading its rating. I’m still open to play Android: Netrunner casually, but I almost always prefer to play an Euro game now.

Current Rating: 7.0

RATING: 10
Best. Game. Ever.

Elaboration: Android: Netrunner is a customisable card game that sees players facing off against each other in the classic cyberpunk trope Corporation vs. Hacker. The game is asymmetrical, with each player using completely different cards and methods to score points. The theme of the game ties in very well with the gameplay. The monthly expansion packs provide players with more options and play styles.

I highly recommend Android: Netrunner. However, it does requires a fair bit of investment (time, money and knowledge) as well as a network of players for it to truly shine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Myself being a - used to be - 'devotee' to MtG, this one intrigued me quite a bit. Asymmetrical game play with very interesting theme. And I don't have to spend a fortune to make a competitive deck? I would love to try this out.

Being a perfectionist that I am...I could not help but shell out some money to buy all the data packs. And it is amazing how you can own every set of cards with fraction of amount that would take you to build a single decent deck in MTG (tournament worthy decks sans RDW or burn decks...).

I have yet to actually sit down and play but had chance to play by myself and it definitely is a unique game. My first assessment of this game coming from long time MTG experience is that the core concept is very rigid in that the strategy may not be too diverse (you need ICE breaker as runner to get through no matter what deck you are trying out but corp-side felt very flexible.) bu as more expansions come out, I feel like it can only get better from here on. And honestly, game feels very young in that it has potential to grow even bigger.

RATING: 10
My current favorite game

I like how no-body can have an all powerful deck

Should be an 11
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a great deckbuilding game.  Fantasy Flight's LCG system offers a gamer various ways to approach classic CCG's such as Magic: the Gathering.  If you're happy with a simple set, then the core game offers plenty of replayability - 7 different decks in the box with customization available.  Data packs are being released which offer new cards to build upon.  Of course, the serious will collect any and all Data Packs, while the more relaxed of us will pick and choose.
as for the game itself...as a previous Magic player/collector, I am impressed with this system.  As usual with a card game, card draw can kill you, but creating decks against the current meta game is a beautiful challenge I enjoy.  The system is assymetrical in that each player (one the Corp and one the Runner) plays a completely different game.  The Runner is trying to hack into the evil, greedy Corp and steal their precious Agendas while the Corp is trying to defend their assets from the evil hackers.  This results in the two players having different available actions.  The icing on the cake is the bluff/press your luck aspect of the Corp/Runner, respectively.  Do you run against that well defended server assuming the Corp has a juicy Agenda stored there or is it simply bait to lure a greedy Runner to it?  The rewards/penalties are high and is great fun to squirm with these decisions.
Anyone disinterested in MtG because of the 'hard to get into' aspect should seriously consider this LCG.
Have to lower this to an 8 as the game, to me, is about the surprise factor.  Once you've played a deck, you have a decent idea what's in it and that changes how you play against it, especially as the runner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great, intricate and strategic card game for two players.  I quickly fell down the rabbit-hole with this game, joining a regular playgroup almost straight away and I have already signed up for my first tournament.

There is an incredible variety in the possible strategies to win the game and the deckbuilding components are, in particular, a really interesting way to explore these strategies.

Unfortunately the game suffers from a couple of minor balance issues and, at the tournament level, there is not an awful lot of variety in the winning decks.  However, in most areas, I am finding a very vibrant meta for this game and, as a result, I am able to play fairly often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Slick revision of the 1990s classic, which has flown under the radar for too long. I'm glad I restrained myself from buying into original NR, now that this is available and alive again. I like the factioning, and look forward to the upcoming data packs that will add variety and flesh out some of the nascent Corp and Runner abilities. I was never big into the CCG scene, but this plays unlike anything else.

RATING: 6
NEW UPDATE: I stopped playing after a while. There is something a little off with the way the game flows and it becomes a little fiddly. Compared to SW:LCG and the new GoT:2nd ed LCG it just falls flat

UPDATE: Have played more and more and it keeps getting better. Don't listen to people saying that more base sets are nescesarry, you can easily have tons of fun with just 1 base game. I am impressed with the way that 2 games of Netrunner can play out so very different from each other, even with the same identities going against each other. Compared to Magic, here the game is in actually playing the game, not just in deckbuilding. /END UPDATE

Played 3 times as of this rating. Really really good, lives up to the hype. Love the theme, comes through in the cards. Exciting and not as long as I first thought. Has bluffing, engine building, resource management and each side plays very differently. Got better with more plays, as we started to get to know both our own and the opponents deck. So replayability is very high. Sold off Warhammer Invasion, this is so much better, will be my confrontational 2 player LCG from now on. Well done again Mr Garfied (was never a magic player, only tried the playstation version, but love King of Tokyo and RoboRally)

RATING: 8
Complete Genesis Cycle 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm not sure that open-wallet games like this (and Magic the Gathering) can be fairly compared with regular, single-box euro games, but with all the expansions, Netrunner easily surpasses almost all other games when played between two fairly skilled players.  The core box is quite generous, and allows decent scope for deckbuilding.  Thanks to the game being asymmetrical, you can have a two-player constructed deck game out of a single box without having to draft cards - that's fantastic.  A lot of extra value comes from the large community of skilled players, assuming that you are willing to keep up with all of the datapacks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

I'm not into LCG/CCG, but if I was; this would be the game I'd get. Learning the rules can be a bit daunting at first, but FFG did a great job on the rulebook. I can only recommend to try it out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is a lot of fun. The game play of the two sides play is very different even though they are both resource/hand management at their heart. The mechanics are full of jargon but once that is overcome they are pretty simple and engaging. The artwork is fantastic which has become the norm for the LCG line of games.

I rate the game an 8 because that's how much fun I think the actual gameplay experience is. However, I'm not really interested in the 'real' game of Netrunner which, like LCGs and CCGs before it, is all about the meta-game. I don't have time to deckbuild and constantly update the game, and my knowledge, with Data Packs and expansions. It's kind of sad that fun and engaging games like this will have to pass me by, but the alternative will only end in madness and frustration.

I invested heavily in the LotR LCG and it remains a fantastic game but I simply don't have the time to enjoy it properly. I like to play a lot of boardgames and don't have the attention span for games like Netrunner. I'll happily play the game though if someone hands me a pre-built deck :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As a fan of the original I can only say that FFG have knocked this one out of the park.

They have improved the game experience (everything is so smooth!), the art and production is incredible, the cards are nice and the factions in the core set make this really easy to just pick up and play with a LOT of variation to tide you over until the chapter packs start to appear.

As with the original player skill trumps card draws and deck construction, although all three will decide the winner over the course of a match. The thematic integration is excellent.

I'm usually an omni-gamer, never getting too deep into one game, but if a tournament scene develops for this game as i hope it will then I'm in.

*Update* The game just gets better with the first couple of chapter packs released increasing the choices and enabling new strategies. My favourite game of 2012, and not looking like anything will overtake it for 2013 so far.

*Update* First expansion cycle finished and C&C big box out and the game is still going strong. 111 plays not including Octgn. Certainly my favourite game of recent years.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
For trade only in combination with expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent LCG.  The asymmetric style is very compelling, unique, and surprisingly well-balanced.  The game effectively combines bluffing and deep strategy to create some of the most interesting situations of any game I've played.

The game can be expensive to play competitively since you need 3 copies of the base game to build the really good decks, and expansions come out monthly.  However you can get around this to some extent by playing online.  For casual play a single copy of the base game is sufficient, and in some ways is more balanced with fewer copies of the most powerful cards in the game.  However competitive play is a completely different experience.

Like all games of this type it suffers a bit from balance issues of individual cards being too powerful, but overall it has reasonably good balance and there is an excellent variety of competitive play styles.  The game clearly has very competent designers and play-testers.

The game has just the right amount of luck in my opinion: enough so that the better player is more likely to win but it is never a forgone conclusion.  An advanced player can play a novice and still have an interesting game.  The game has a long skill curve with diminishing returns, which is perfect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[b]Verdict: Still exploring, but possible keeper[/b]

RATING: 7
Android: Netrunner's appeal compared to other LCGs is its theme and the large local player base, making it effectively the only LCG playable competitively. Game-wise, it has enough on offer to pique my interest as a dyed-in-the-wool Eurogamer, never having played any competitive CCG/LCG before. The asymmetric corporation/runner decks with their contrary tasks gives each player a different challenge, avoiding the dreaded tug-of-war feeling.

The truth remains to be revealed though as I have to build my own decks yet. Without deckbuilding, a preliminary 7/10 rating. Validation will show if LCG's could be feasible for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Facial expression: bored

The asymmetrical game is the thing I like most about it, and I don’t like that much. The theme is OK, too, but from there on it’s all downhill.

I seriously dislike the self-consciously melodramatic rulebook with its ladled-on thematic jargon that makes the game a total bear to learn. And then I dislike the game. Asymmetry is great, but the game is broken if the two sides are playing different games, the outcome of both depending hugely on how the decks - particularly the corporation deck - happen to be sequenced. The play is made more tedious because it focuses on accumulating credits, rather than on the nominal action of the game, which involves few decisions (run? not run?), and a rather tedious kind of bluff, all of which makes, in my view, for a lengthy, dull exchange across a litter of gaudy cards, with little or no interest or engagement.

The game strikes me as a dud, but game apart, I dislike even more the whole Living Card Game concept. It seems wildly stupid for people to buy into a game that is designed for enthusiasts who will buy cards that are so powerful that they crush anyone who has a standard deck. I understand that logic perfectly from the company’s point, but I’m not the company and I’d rather play a game where everyone at the table differs mainly in their wits and experience, not the money they’ve spent on kit. I understand that people get a buzz out of building a great deck, and testing it over the board, and going back to their FLGS to improve it a little more, but that entire world of addictive acquisition leaves me colder than a penguin in a blizzard. 

Pokemon left me puzzled; Netrunner leaves me numb.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is the only TCG-style card game I've played that derives almost nothing from Magic, and it's a lot better for it.  Of course, leave it to the original designer of Magic to not reinvent his own wheel.

The game excels in having lots of interesting, paradigm-shifting features (asymmetric gameplay, lots of bluffing, different gameplay styles, action points rather than phases, and a very egalitarian art direction), all of which reserve its spot next to my most interesting board games.  When people say this game is good, they aren't kidding.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The flow of this game is beautiful. When you are the runner every decision you do is so crucial and tense that you can feel the tension between you and the corp. Do you run that server? Is there trap there that might kill you? Do you have enough money to avoid a sea source? Every decision matters! On the other hand as the corp you are worried about completely different things. Can the runner pass that server? Can I score before he finds his breakers? Do I have enough money? Even though I play this casually I still feel so connected to the game, It's just insane. My only complaint is it is hard to teach new players this game since it is quite a commitment.

RATING: 8
The asymmetrical aspect of the game really works. It's a fun 2-player game .

I really enjoy the CCG aspect without feeling compelled to purchase endless, expensive booster packs. I have the first 6 data packs (packs of ~30 cards), but I've stopped grabbing the expansions due to limited tabletime.

Even as-is, I have plenty of cards to enjoy match-ups.

UPDATE: Expansions come out far too often for me. It feels too much like the CCGs that I wanted to avoid. There's a great game underneath the barrage of expansions, but it's too expensive for casual players to keep up with.

RATING: 10
I have played a metric butt-load of CCG/LCGs in my time, but none of them compare to Netrunner. Everything about this game is great: the theme, the deck building, the asymmetric play, the bluffing, the agonizing decisions ... all condense and interlock into a perfect gameplay experience. Yes, the learning curve is a little steep, and the community's jargon can be daunting to parse, but persevere and soon you'll reach gaming nirvana.

RATING: 9
2/12/14 have all expansions to date. What a superb game. Good art, excellent gameplay, lots of ways to deck build. Nice you HAVE to play 2 sides (unlike Mtg where its possible to just be a Red and Black player ALL THE TIME)

Jo has a starter box and a few data packs

16/5/15 having reading a lot of the comments of people giving this game "1", I had a few thoughts.
1)you need 2 base sets to play - a bit true; you dont NEED 2 but its useful (and 3 if you want to have 3 of EVERY card).
2) No variety - these comments come from the starter box; there were 7 IDs but they were a bit limited. But now, 3.5 cycles and 3 "big boxes" in there are a LOT of choices.
3) Only bluffing and totally random - a bit, but I think the bluffing is what makes this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The new version of the classic Netrunner card game. It is an asymmetrical card game where one player is a mega-corporation attempting to protect and advance agendas while the other player is a hacker determined to break in and 'liberate' the information the corporation is so desperate to protect. It is a game of strategy, resource management, and bluffing and it is quite fun to play as either side. 

I like the original game as well but the rules tweaks, aesthetic re-work, and conversion to a non-collectible game all combine to bring this version up a few notches.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[size=12][b]Top 100 board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I like Android: Netrunner:[/b][/size]
+ I like how the asymmetrical decks (between the runner and corporation) can be balanced to a fairly even win rate.
+ The game is easy to teach (for casual play at least).
+ The game incorporates mechanics that I like.
+ The game is short.
+ The game requires meaningful decisions to win.
+ The game has decent replayability as a result of the various ways you can build a deck, play the game, etc.

[size=12][b]Fixable dislikes in regards to Android: Netrunner:[/b][/size]
/ I am not particularly interested in collectible games as this model tends to cost a fortune. Android: Netrunner is not entirely collectible and instead uses a LCG model. The LCG model is good for ensuring that the game is up to date, which I like. However, I am still not interested in keeping up to date with the various releases. I think that video games make this process easier. Anyway, the solution here is to just play with the revised core set.

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Usually willing to play this game[/size]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I am not sure how I feel about this game.  It is fun to play, sure.  But it is so complicated to teach and explain.  

I like the game out of the box, though the rulebook is a little confusing and the box insert is less-than-worthless.  But I am not really sure how to take the deckbuilding aspect:  it's nice, but it's sort of a slippery slope: once you start, everyone you play with has to do it too.  I feel that it quickly degrades into a contest of who can set up the best deck, and then it becomes less about the play.

So, I certainly enjoy the game, but I just don't think it will ever become a favorite.

RATING: 4
Having played Magic for over 15 years, I have some expectations from LCGs and TCGs. This one seems to be the most random I've ever played, and hopefully I don't ever have to again. I played few times as corp, which was mildly amusing, if simple. Rest of the times I played as hacker, where you were forced to run blind and hope to get lucky in order to score points. In short: if hacker is a luckbag, there is no way corp will ever win, if he is not, corp will surely win, as all ways for hacker to score points are totally random. It is interesting if hacker is a mediocre luckbag, as both players have an option to win.

RATING: 7
Fairly easy to learn the mechanics but the game play is very rich and deep meaning you can play for a while and still learn new things.  There is too much power creep in the expansions which means if you have the base box you can't really play against people that have a few expansions.

A fun two player game that is fast to set up and doesn't run too long.  Good for when you don't have much time.

Update:  It almost never gets played because the more experienced player always wins which makes it not fun when playing with friends who are new to it (for me and them).  I'm not interested in playing in tournaments.  Doesn't get much use any more.

RATING: 10
I usually don't enjoy much randomness in my games, so it's quite surprising that I love Android: Netrunner so much. The asymmetric gameplay, bluffing, analysis, risk-taking, strategy, adaptation, etc., all come together to create such a deep and rewarding experience. Even after deck creation, there's so much importance on how you play the game and how well you read the other player. I think the only drawback to this richness is the learning curve to design your own decks and play very competitively (if that's your goal).

RATING: 9
On its way to my home. Haven't played any games, even on OCTGN, but got hooked by the LCG format and the youtube videos. Though I don't have anyone to play with now, I will collect anything A:N-related and hopefully find someone to play in my area.

---

Update 12/7/2014: After a while, I think I'm more of a Netrunner collector than a player. One reason is that I don't have a playgroup to play with, but I think the main reason is I suck at this game as Runner, which in my opinion is the exciting part of the game.

---

Update 21/9/ 2014: As I get better playing as Runner, the game does feel more appealing to me. I begin to be able to analyze the game state and make more meaningful actions to react to it, not just auto-pilot like I did before (like when I played Corp). Bumped to a 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Android: Netrunner is an asymmetrical Living Card Game for two players. Set in the cyberpunk future of Android and Infiltration, the game pits a megacorporation and its massive resources against the subversive talents of lone runners.

Corporations seek to score agendas by advancing them. Doing so takes time and credits. To buy the time and earn the credits they need, they must secure their servers and data forts with "ice". These security programs come in different varieties, from simple barriers, to code gates and aggressive sentries. They serve as the corporation's virtual eyes, ears, and machine guns on the sprawling information superhighways of the network.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
► Best card game
► Best expandable card game

Once I tackled the rules (and special terms), I completely fell in love with this game for many good reasons: great theme (dystopian cyberpunk sci-fi), gorgeous artworks, very clever game design, great mechanisms, completely asymmetrical roles for two players, great strategic depth, Expandable/"Living" Card Game format (no blind booster pack gambling), very high replay value, pre-game deckbuilding/strategising, bluffing, 2 factions split into different sub-factions (each with their strengths and weaknesses).

One of the finest games I ever played.

RATING: 10
Jesus.. it took me about 3-4 years to finally get it to the table. My first game was rather okey (very basic Weyland and Shaper decks), but after my third game it really took off. My spouse also loves it and she absolutely destroyed my Jinteki deck. But guess what.. Although I've lost 0:7 I've had a lot of fun. Most LCGs tend to show their beauty after 8-10 games (SW:LCG, L5R etc.), but this one did it right out of the gate. It's fast, it's complex and weeeeeeeeird. I love it.

edit: After over 30 plays in 5 weeks I can absolutely say it's one of the best games I've ever played - if you're willing to get into deck constructing beforehand.

I would LOVE to stay in this game if there were CASUAL formats like Draft. Unfortunately, there just ain't enough players to pull it off, and the LCG format makes drafting all but obsolete.

RATING: 7
Starting at a 9. I could see this moving up or down as time goes on, but for now I want to play it all the time.

May downgrade to a 9 now that the Genesis cycle is fully out and FFG don't seem to give a crap about high-level balance.

After playing C&C, I'm more convinced that they blew it with a faction-specific box that didn't help one of the factions. High-level play is less balanced than ever. Back down to a 9.

After the first couple of Spin Cycle packs (December 2013), this is back to a 10.

2014: back down to a 9.

2015 was a pretty rocky year for Netrunner, imo, and 2016's been a disaster. Down to a 7.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Picked up first day at Gencon 2012, and played it at least 10 times total over the past weekend.  Why buy it?  Heavy hacker, corporate defense themed game, incorporating an elegant card structure in the dystopian future.  First impression:  awesome game!  I'm a sucker for 'Blade Runner' or dystopian games, with this being no exception.  I'm a huge fan of Android as well, even though the game is a little clunky with its mechanics, it's still a lot of fun.  Netrunner on the other hand, is very easy and perfectly executed, but keeping the Android style theme alive and well.  

The corporation (you can pick from various ones) has the complex task of protecting its servers with various ICE and anti-runner defense tactics, while the runner tries to infiltrate them.  The runner installs custom programs, hardware, and resources to his liking - you get to build your own hacker computer!  It's a very cool system, easy to learn, and has enough complexity to add years of enjoyment.  Can't wait for additional sets to be released.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played several times.  I love the original Netrunner.  It was so flavorful, suspenseful, with a very tight design.  It also really should never've been released as a CCG.  This newest incarnation is nearly perfect.  I love all of their design tweaks, the deckbuilding rules, and the theme integration into FFG's similar proprietary setting.  My only complaint - not enough of each card in the base set to build any deck.  But that is so minor, considering you get plenty of cards to play the pre-constructed decks, and expansions should provide tons of new options.  

The last 4 games of this have given me reason to adjust my rating and opinion.  Those games have simply not been fun, at all, and I'm not entirely certain why.  They have all been lop-sided affairs, and that's never really fun. I suppose if I had a regular opponent that was really into the game, I might have reason to play more.  But as it stands, I have little desire to play again.  And another fun memory is ground to dust under the wheel of reality...

RATING: 6
Played the game once as the corporation in order to experience the game once for my own culture. I did not like much the game, but I think there are interesting mechanics in there.

I lacked money all the time and I rarely had the cards to get more money. I think that is one of the flaws of the game is that you are dependent on the luck of the draw and the design of your deck. If you don't get the right cards to do the basic stuff, then the game won't cover up for you.

For example, I was short of money all the time and could not get any way to make money. I managed to discard randomly the few cards my opponent needed to break the type of ICE I had, making me impossible to get attacked. which made me win the game.

I also liked the terminology which somewhat reinforces the theme constantly ad you play even if the game is very mechanical. 

So it will not appeal to everybody, I don't like it much but I cannot say it's a bad game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
+ The menaces are quite clear, even when they are not precise, which is a plus compared to Magic: the Gathering, where it is often hard to guess that an Instant might be cast. In Netrunner, the Runner *knows* that an installed card might be a deadly Asset. He *knows* that ICE is dangerous, even when they are not rezzed. This creates an interesting tension, a real sense of purpose, real, concrete goals to attain, which are very thematic. Both Innovation and Race offer goals (tactical goals, for Innovation, strategic goals, for Race).

+ The need for Credits, for scoring Agendas, for protection by ICE, for Programs that can break ICE, etc., all this creates a nice tension. A little bit like wanting to play all your cards in Agricola without being able to, a little like having many nice plans in Race without being able to implement them all, a little like needing to get a majority of icons in Innovation and struggling to get it.

$ I was initially disappointed to have so many copies of a single card, in the Core set: I was afraid that this would limit the versatility of the deck. However, a Magic: the Gathering deck does not really have many more different cards, because of the presence of Lands, and Magic games have a huge variety. I don't yet know if a similar variety is present in Netrunner, but it is not excluded.

- During my first couple of games, I missed a few rule points, and/or had to refer to the rulebook. Not a completely trivial rule set. Not too complicated, though. The theme helps making it simple enough.

+ The game can be unforgiving: it seems that there is sometimes a *single strategy* that has to be followed in order not to lost.

+ I like to come back to the game because I want to learn to *see* this strategy. The bluffing aspect makes it some kind of meta-game, sometimes. This is quite unique. For example: my opponent might have 3 agendas in HQ, unprotected, and an agenda in a remote server, unprotected: I must learn that this opponent might not be afraid to do this, and I should do runs on these servers.

+ This game is also quite unique in that little clues picked up at the right time can really make a difference. Example: a person putting an ICE before an Agenda or Asset on a Remote Server: this may mean that the card is an Agenda, as the player was afraid to leave it unprotected, psychologically, even during their turn. Another example: during a Run on HQ, a person might shuffle their cards: it may mean that there is an Agenda in there, as otherwise the shuffling becomes less relevant.

- I don't like so much waiting for the actions of my opponent, or taking multiple actions in a turn: I am afraid that my opponent will be bothered. I prefer the fast pace of Agricola, or the simultaneous actions of Race, or the often interactive turns of Magic. After a dozen games and a few games with the same decks, things flow faster, though; I still feel some pressure to keel the game going while I go through my actions. 

$ Less rich and deep than Race. I enjoyed tasting the game though: I feel like I am getting to know it a little better and starting to enjoy its subtleties. The learning pace is slow, though; not that the game is difficult, but it does not move so fast: it takes time to accumulate ICE, or ICE breakers, so the number of in-game situations is not so large (it is even slower than Magic: the Gathering, where Creatures come and go relatively fast). That said, I still feel like a child who is learning how to walk: I don't feel fully in control: I want to keep exploring the potential of this game.

- It is not always so easy to keep track of the number of actions, again, despite using tokens taken by the opponent, like in Jambo. Or remembering to take a Credit through the Pad Campaign,…

Also, there is not so much to do when waiting for your opponent (maybe that's why I tend to be a little bored and not follow the actions of my opponent precisely). Netrunner is much closer to Magic, in this respect (but Magic has faster turns, which helps), than to Race for the Galaxy.

I love the mind game. The closest games I have that give this feeling are Lord of the Rings: the Confrontation (especially during combat, and also a bit during movement, with many laughs too), Skull (many laughs too, but there is not much to think about), games with simultaneous actions (Race for the Galaxy, but the guessing is only on which actions will be chosen, and does not have much consequences, and games where the choices matter much but live in a more limited space than in Netrunner, because it's mostly about simultaneous movement: 2 de Mayo and Clockwork Wars).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
While I enjoy the basic core set I do feel a tad shortchanged. Many cards have 3 copies however, there are a few with only 2 copies; I'm wondering why this was printed this way for any other reason than greed. However, I do suspect that the game will only increase in strength and playability as the new data packs are released.

I really love the asymmetric quality of this card game which allows bluffing which is, in my mind, one of a card game's primary mechanics and often not utilized very effectively. Here I get this mechanic and so much more. Even though I enjoy playing the bluff (i.e. the Megacorps) I most enjoy the Runner aspects of detecting and counter-detecting bluffs. This game hasn't reached parity amongst all factions yet but it's fast approaching. With just a few more data packs released (there are only two so far) this will happen some time in the next year.

Update: August 2015

I fucking LOVE this game. My favorite card game; no competition. The asymmetry perfectly suits the LCG format.

Corp: MBN 'Tag n Bag'
Runner: Anarch 'Tag Me'

Far moreso than MtG, deckbuilding feels natural with careful consideration to the powercurve and meta regarding the consistent game design. And no banned cards. What is this science? I guess we'll have to see if this holds.

This is the ONLY LCG or recurring purchase I intend to stick with until they pry my debit card from my cold, dead hands.

And now that my group has embraced draft, cube design is consuming me. So much fun.

Love. This. Game.

Rating increased.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
We were never big LCG players and with all the hype with Netrunner we decided to try it.

The first few attempt, we were luke warm on the game, however after several plays and attempt to deck build our own characters, it has really change our view on this game. 

We love it. 

The learning curve is steep. Takes 2-3 games to fully grasp it depending on player experience. 

I recommend deck building after a few try with basic deck. The experience is very different. That was the game changer for us.
