=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After playing this for 1,5 years I increase my rating from 9.5 to 10. I played probably around 600 games of this and still want to play it all the time.

Never played an LCG before this, so I was not sure if this was for me. But I bought the core box to try. After having watched the intro video from FFG it wasn't even as hard to learn and teach as I expected from the comments here. It fascinated me from the start. The asymmetric play gives a completely different feel depending on if you are runner or corp. There are so many options for every action, and every action seems to matter. This does not even include deck building. With deck building the variety is endless and i really enjoy exploring the different playstyles of the different IDs.

Always looking forward to the next game. Excellent!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very unique asymmetric card game, the corporations and runner definitely play very differently. The hackers not knowing what servers contain and being able to more strongly disrupt the corporation by messing with their hand and deck fits with the theme very well. The only downsides to this game are one: it isn't super gentle on giving those new to it a fighting chance and two: the difference from getting one lucky run from the corporation's hand can make a huge difference in the game, as even a 2 point card is almost a third of the game for the runner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Netrunner is one of those special games where the play and player interaction outshines the actual system. The core game is a 9, but because players can play the game well and win rather than just build well and win speaks volumes.

I'm at 60 plays and never looking back. In a way it's good that Netrunner failed in the early days because I think the time for things to simmer, ideas about card games to evolve, and players to mature as, well, players, makes now the right time for it to re-emerge. That it is not collectible is simply the cherry on top.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Type: directly competitive 2-player customizable card game with asymmetrical game play.

Best With: 2
Weight: Medium
Duration: 15-45 minutes
Notes:
Can use base decks, but best with someone who will be interested in customizing decks on their own time.
Entirely card-based with plenty of text and effects on those cards.
Does require knowing opponent's cards decently well for best enjoyment.
Luck based on card draws.

An excellent game that I love playing. The artwork, theme, asynchronous play, balance, and huge card pool once you get into the expansions and data packs are top notch.

The biggest downside, and it can be a very big one, is the fact that this is a customizable card game. In small gaming groups, this game will always be slightly unbalanced towards players who take the most time *before* their gaming sessions to research current decks and tailor their decks to their desired play styles. This game is best played by players willing to put time into creating their decks before the gaming session, and by players of relatively equal interest in the game. Sitting down at the table and making your deck right then is just not going to cut it; those players should instead look to deck-building games.

Also, a player who just owns the core set will always be at a very big disadvantage to a player who has 2 core sets plus various other expansion sets. Likewise, a small gaming group will need to have a relatively similar level of interest amongst all the players to have a good time. But if one player in a group of 4 dives in full on and gets more data packs, he's going to be at a huge advantage over the others.


That said, if ever there was a game that could be affordable and yet scratch the Magic: The Gathering itch without requiring players to chase rares, this game is it. Solid, deep, relatively easy to learn, but very hard to master, especially as the card pool continues to grow.

if I have a pair of decks at hand already made and somewhat up-to-date with current cards, I'll happily always play this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After 1500 face-to-face plays, and countless hours deckbuilding, I still want more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 10
Melhor card game. Sem Mais
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I played the original, 'cyberpunk,' version of this, which I've always though was one of the most original games, thematically and mechanically, even to come out of the USA. I can totally see why so many serious games have gotten addicted to this re-implementation. What makes Netrunner so much fun is the dramatic tension of every game, as players scramble for cover at the beginning then smash all their most expensive resources against one another at the end.

I have somewhat mixed feelings about setting the new version in Kevin Wilson's ANDROID universe. The art comes across as lamely cartoony compared to the original, which at the time really did catch the edgy, underground ambiance of the cyberpunk movement. But there's no denying the richness and originality of the gameworld, and the fact that one can play other games and read (surprisingly well-written!) novels about the same characters and setting really does make this whole thing a bit of a special moment in the history of the hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've played several games of this, both Runner and Corporation, played all basic decks besides the Anarch Netrunner and dabbled in a single deckbuilding game, which went terribly for me.

I'm having a very hard time judging this game. I love the theme, artwork, and idea, but can't wrap my head around the gameplay. I keep having enormous economic problems with both the Corp and Hacker (less so with the latter), and find that I can't attack nor defend well, even against novice players. That, plus the fact that I've got a very bad feeling about the game format, will probably mean I'll never be able to get invested in the game enough to seek out matches.

It seems to be a big hit among my friends, so if there's a mini-Netrunner scene going on in a month or two, I may be tempted to join in, but I've got a feeling I'm "too old" for CCG-like games. I just can't see myself investing enough time and sinking enough money in this to play it in any other way than casually - and you can't really do that once people around you start buying expansions and doing serious deckbuilding.

I'm rather disillusioned and disappointed at this point. Unfortunately, I may be forced to sell my set off to one of my friends - the idea of a game so thematic and so awesome in what it does which didn't appeal to me is almost painful :(

01.12.12 - with a heavy heart, I'm letting this one go. I can't see myself getting into it, I don't have the morale to keep trying to love it anymore. Just another unnecessary buy-and-sell in my collection, only this time the disappointment is extreme.

03.08.14 - and just a follow-up comment. Holy shit, fanboys of this game are INSUFFERABLE. There's no explaining to them why I think this game is deeply flawed in both its rules and its format. All I ever get back is ridicule. It makes me feel even worse about this title.

RATING: 9
My Favorite LCG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The best 2 player card game. Asymmetric game play with a lot of different Identities to chose from keeps the game fresh and of course the Living Card Game format where you get new cards all the time helps with it. So many possibilities to build your deck around and the value of cards really depend on your gaming environment (meta) as people try out new combinations to exploit your weaknesses while trying to negate your strengths. The game has strong elements of bluffing and guessing your opponents moves which I really like.

I just love this game. Game play is really tense and a small miscalculated risk can cause you the game against a strong player. After 50 plays I feel like I have only scratched the surface. I have taught this game to at least 7 of my friends and some of them were immediately hooked and bought their own. It's getting harder to get anything else on the table these days.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Apart from breathing new life into a justly venerated card game classic, FFG have done good on Netrunner  by getting a better grip on a playable core set. If you compare this with the stuttery start of the Cthulhu LCG with its unwieldy highlander approach, there really has been a steep evolution. I’ve gotten a lot of play out of this without touching the starting decks so far, and have made a firm pact with myself that I will not get into real deckbuilding until the first cycle is completed.

Until then, I’m pretty sure that modifying the core decks will offer a lot of potential all by itself, probably helped along by the cat-and-mouse nature of the game. So far, I can attest that the hype got it right this time, and continuing the background of Android, one of my favorite games, is just icing on the cake.

RATING: 9
Great game. I mean, really great. Up to date the best card game out there. 

Quite time-consuming as there are too many strategies which need careful planning and deck-testing. A deck-Builder is a must to have a strategical overview and speed up. Pays off for all players of previous card games like Pokemon, Yu-Gi-Oh, Magic as well as online gamers (Hearthstone etc.)

As per my personal taste (biased of course):
Minus one point since you simply can´t bring the game to a friend who does not own this game by himself without having preconstructed decks which need explicit explanation how to pilot the deck.

Personally I dealt with this issue as I made my very own variant. :-)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I rate CCGs and their expandable cousins (LCGs, etc.) on this basis: "I will likely never invest in one again, but assuming that someone else hands me a deck here's what I think of the game."

I hated the original Netrunner. The new one is a lot more interesting.

Even based on just one play, I see layers of interlocking strategy, tactics, and elements from other games -- like Poker -- that are really neat. I imagine with some time and money and a local meta this would be a blast to get into.

I didn't love it, though. Maybe that's a function of trying a basic weenie vs. wall game as my first, since that dynamic -- which never changed and was really dull -- is what I loathed about the original. But I'd happily play it again and would love to see some other kinds of deck cross my gaming table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great game.  Out of the box, no need for more than one base set unless you have larger plans (like more than one game going at once).  A nice incremental improvement over the original - living vs. dead, art, graphic design of cards, coherent theme.  Highly recommended for people who like tense two player card games.  I am already waiting very impatiently for more cards... more more more!!!  This game could get a 10 rating, I am always thinking about it.

Now over 100 ftf games. Simply put, a classic. Detractors haven't played this game and are stuck thinking the old version is somehow better, it isn't (played it a lot in the day). If you like card games with tension and tough decisions, this is it.

Only tiny complaint is the lack of 3 copies of every card in the base set. Also, if you don't like designing your own deck stay away from the whole genre of customizable games (including this one).

RATING: N/A
716
116
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the best (if not the best) 2-player games I've ever played. To play one player builds and plays a "Corporation" deck with "Agenda" cards that they attempt to play and score. The other player is a "runner" who attempts to steal agenda cards before they are scored. The asymmetrical aspect is so well done. Each faction plays specific cards to help them, while their counterpart has specific cards designed to stop them. The game uses smaller decks than other card games, and very strict deck building restrictions that do a great job of balancing the game for new players (even though the back log of cards is extensive). The cat & mouse and mind-games presented here are some of the best I've ever experienced in a game.   

Purchased: 07/27/16 (MiniatureMarket/Ebay/Titan)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.59
Assume Cycles 1-4.

Rating:

Game quality: It loses a point because the LCG format rears its ugly head here more than it should compared to a game like The Star Wars: LCG or GoT: LCG. Each of those have definite entry points into the LCG and at places to expand. A:N you just kind of pick a spot and go with it while never being fully right or wrong. My best advice is 1-2 Core sets(lean on two), 3 data packs, and C&C. What three data packs is up to you. Research StimHack for deck ideas before deciding. You don't have to buy everything, but it will benefit you to at least do your homework.

Post first couple of plays via starter decks. Don't judge it after plays with starter decks. Those first plays were rather uneven. Play around with other runners and corporations and then go from there. As a base game so far, 8. 

Would I buy this again if I was starting over: Way too early as I think the system can only be judged once you get expansions and start building some decks that are worthwhile. 5.

Do I want to play this if asked: Always until I at least get a better feel. I still think this will remain high as my chances to play it still remain on the low side. 9.

Overall: 8.59

Rating potential: I repeat, way too early. This can only go up over time unless it really falls apart for me, and I don't see that happening. I've done the CCG thing more than once so I know what I'm getting into. Additional plays put this higher.

Really fun with sides that are so different to play. Hidden cards creates some fun surprise moments and engaging post-game discussions.

RATING: 9
My favorite of the LCG's from FFG.  I love the bluffing aspect of it, the assymetric sides and win conditions, and the fact that a game is never over until the last agenda is scored/stolen.  With that said,  played it too the point where I got a little burned out, and for competitive play, I think there are only certain decks (some of which are not very fun to play or play against) that you can realistically win with.  Still love it, regardless.  (Obviously I haven't kept my # of plays up to date, I think I have probably played this 100 times or more).

Unless Nate is reading this, then I have only played a couple of times and am still learning the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I don't like being attacked, so I play as the runner.  I'm also not into deckbuilding, so I just play decks that my partner puts together.

What I like:
- There's a tableau building aspect where you build up your tools and defense
- Some money management aspects too as you need some sort of money engine to be able to run effectively
- Huge variety of cards and strategies
- Each faction has a different feel so you can pick factions that match your type of play style.

What I don't like:
- It's stressful trying to decide which server to run on and the potential consequences of the ice and traps you may encounter

RATING: 10
Easily my favourite tabletop game. Asymmetric play, the corps moves all being hidden and brilliant card design to boot. Lots of expansions to give you more ways to play. There is an ultra-competitive scene which requires a lot of investment to get involved with, which I've shied away from since attending a few tournaments. Looking forward to my copy of Terminal Directive arriving which introduces narrative play, not sure how that would work but very eager to find out.

RATING: 7
*Update*

Okay, so I'm starting to enjoy this game after playing it a few times. I will not change my stance on the theme, it still does not do much for me, but I do enjoy the bit of bluffing that comes built into the game. 

I may consider getting my own set.

My continued knock on the game is that it is an investment of time and energy. You are not going to be able to say to someone who's never played before, "Hey, want to play Netrunner?", and expect it to go well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
First few plays against an inexperienced player (I was too, but I was prepared). I won all three (2 times as corp, one time as runner). The first time was a flatline due to a trap, the other was 7 agenda points for the corp, but I postponed it just to get my opponent to run (he was scared because of the flatline earlier). And as a runner I scored 7 points, but the corp did well. Slowly building it up: my opponent wants revenge! :) As a runner you really feel the thrill and I love the theme.

Edit: I love the art and theme and the gameplay. The only drawback is the deckbuilding: the only reason for me why this games stays at an 8 (I just don't have enough patience, time and playtime to build and test decks).

Edit2: The game becomes too 'big' for me. Too much expansions, etc. *CG's are not for me. I'll keep my Netrunner 'collection', though, but I won't be expanding it beyond the 2nd cycle.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is a very good 2 player experience and better if the theme appeals to you, not my case too much, MTG is still my favorite Garfierld's game. I specially like the design and outstanding artworks on ANR cards, but asymmetrical sides, difficult decisions and bluffing are always cool features. I'd buy and play Netrunner if the spanish Edge editions were available at good prices here in Colombia.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
As a long-time MTG player, I was intrigued but sceptical of this - I just assumed that this was Magic re-themed and with the LCG model as opposed to the CCG one, and therefore more palatable for the anti-Magic crowd. I was wrong.

This is a great and intriguing card game heavy on bluffing, playing the odds, and walking a tightrope. The 7 agenda points (researched by the Corporation player or stolen by the hacker) or flatline (the Corporation player forcing the hacker to discard cards they don't have) to win makes the game much more volatile than the sometimes drawn-out games of MTG (especially in control or midrange matchups). Here, while things can take a long time, and you play for incremental advantage (typically through improving your economy, and defences/offensive capabilities as a corp/runner respetcively) similar to MTG, when you steal a 3 point agenda you are suddenly half-way to winning. Even the hardest fortress, with pile upon pile of ICE (defensive cards played by the corporation), can unravel at the hands of the Runner by something completely unforseen, a weak spot, a bluff that was called. Alternatively the runner can think themselves safe, with a massive pile of programs and money only to be lured into the perfect trap and suddenly be dead in the water. A game where at least it feels like nothing is ever completely set until the last point is scored (though it often is).

I really like it, and the packs and deluxe expansions are always there tempting me, but I'm not buying into this, I know it for the trap it is - I just don't have anyone to play with, to share my obsessive nature when it comes to games like this. I don't have the time or desire to go play at my LFGS, and I don't have friends who are willing to invest themselves like me in - so no, I won't go down this road even though I might want to.

Even so, I have the core set. It's fun, but I know it's just an appetizer to what the "full" thing would be so I ultimately prefer other games for the same settings as I'd play this.

A good, even great, game but I'm not going down this ICE filled rabbit hole - I'm taking the blue pill this time
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An excellent two player, cyberpunk  game with asymmetric play. One player plays a megacoproration and the other a runner (a computer hacker) who has to infiltrate the corporation network.

There are 4 different corporations and 3 different runner decks and they all play differently, so this one is not going to get boring fast.

RATING: 9
We read the instructions and started our first game.  A lot of rifling through the instructions.  I like the heralded asymmetry so far!  I pulled off a bluff which made me feel so cool, although maybe a little sinister.  

Update 1:  Rating dropped 9.0->8.5.  Great card game with tons of variety in the box without adding any expansions.  In the end I just can't rate this as high as all of those overly fiddly too long Euro style games that we adore.

Update 2:  I always play the Corporation and my wife always plays the Runner until I win with all four Corporation decks.  Then I will get to play as the runner and that will be so mind bending, no more suit and tie!  Its down to needing to win with Jinteki.  I get the feeling that Jinteki and I are going to have a long happy relationship together based on my recent efforts.

Update 3:  Rating undropped from 8.5->9.0.  Oh fine, it deserves a 9.0.  I did finally win with Jinteki a while back, so I am getting to enjoy all of the Runner decks now.  What a blast! Plays way different then the corporation.  By far our most assymetric game.

RATING: 8
An excellent asymmetric 2 player duel game but there are some things I kind of dislike:

It's really fun that you need to create one deck for both runner and corp sides.

Very balanced and exciting gameplay that is a bit marred by the bluffing/luck factor of running blindly.

With the concept of "LCG" so you don't need to buy random expansions, they force you to buy 3 copies of the core game in order to get every deck-building possibility. This is the most hypocritical thing I've seen in board games and it reduces the score by 1 full point for me.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Rating after one play with the 'beginner's decks' (see below; we cancelled the game after about 40 minutes by the way).

Well, while I could see some potential in the game (e.g. the bluffing element - however, this seems to only come with the cooperation decks...) our play was just utterly boring.

Both sides didn't have any useful actions to be done. The runner already owned 5 out of 7 points (quite at the beginning) but couldn't do any harm to the cooperation besides attacking his deck of unused cards (which didn't do any damage because the chance of getting points for it by having a card worth points on top of it is 1:5). So we drew money all the time, played useless cards (again, these were only available for the cooperation player because the runner had everything he needed already in play... so the runner could only get even more money and throw away some more cards...).

This might be pretty different in case you don't play the two decks which are recommended by the rulebook for your first play. Anyhow, I don't think I'll give it another try...

----------------------------------------------------------
Very good game and an excellent update/expansion by FFG of the original game.  

Good to see the rules kept mostly unchanged.  I like the idea of factions and special abilities as this change gives a game a richer thematic feel.

Don't quite like the new "anime" inspired artwork as much as the original, but at least the graphic design changes don't get in the way of playing the game and the game now has a consistent graphic look compared to the original game.

Card stock also doesn't feel as sturdy as the original, but won't matter much as I will be sleeving all my cards.

Very much looking forward to the expansions.

RATING: 7
Loaned to Ethan
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the best games I've ever played, and by far the best card game I've tried.

PROS
- Innovative theme in card games.
- Amazing theme-mechanics integration.
- Total assymmetry, this are almost two different games.
- Different win conditions that really feel different.
- Very high amount of archetypes which should be played in totally different ways.
- Great development of the Android setting.

CONS
- It requires a lot of time and dedication to play when your collection is large, as any game which demands deck creation and metagame observation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is very hard to get into. Rules are numerous and some aren’t used in every game, terminology is unique and somewhat hard to remember, rulebook is big and you’ll find yourself going back and forth many times. The first few games you’ll play will be slow and you’ll be fumbling around not knowing what to do.  But if you manage to get past the steep learning curve, you’re in for a treat.

The theme is excellent and excellently represented. The gameplay is actually a cyberpunk experience, where you actually feel like a determined hacker going against the rich corporation risking your life, or like a mighty corporation looking to protect its secrets and keep pesky hackers out. Playing is fun and calculated and cards have a strong impact, and that’s after me playing only two factions! 

It’s an excellent game that needs dedication to get into but it’s definitely worth it if you have the time to invest and friends to play at the same level as you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The canonical asymmetric card game. Bluffing, deep planning, tight tactical gameplay.

Sadly, a lifestyle game. You're dedicated to it, or you're not competing with serious players; and a bear to teach.

RATING: 8.8
I thoroughly enjoyed the theme and flavor of the game, and the asymmetrical play made it fun time and again to pull out.  Being a collector, I quick;y swooped up most of the expansions (as you will see below) - and never played them.  One consequence of never having a consistent set of people to game with means the expansions were never opened, and in fact the base game never got "drafted" for custom decks.  As a result of the "wasted" purchases, and also knowing that there are many other two-player games I prefer to both teach and to play, I only felt a bit of sorrow that I sold this ensemble.

In short: definitely worth checking out for people seeking a grand 2 player asymmetrical option... but be wary of the more professional players, as the experience is apparently cutthroat and not fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
1. Start a game
2. First Round: Runner plays "The Makers Eye", drawing 3 Cards from R&D, all agendas,game over
3. Netrunner ---> Ebay

Played a couple of games, and I can see why some people love this game, but definitely not my cup of tea. There is way to much luck involved for my taste. The upper case was an extrem example with a very low chance, but the fact that it could happen is for me a sign of bad game design. Winning a game from 0 points to 100 % in one Action with pure luck is just horrible. And: compared to many other LCGs, this game is way more unforgiving if u start with a bad hand of cards. This game feels like a complex Pokergame with a cyberpunk-theme stolen from the RPG-Universe Shadowrun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I have some doubts with this one. 

I dig the theme a lot. It's unique. I like the asymmetrical sides as well. There is also a lot of guesswork and a fair amount of luck in the game as well. The runs on HQ and R&D are luck of the draw; the idea of using Ice as defense is interesting, as is the way the Corp player can put agendas and...other cards...face down to try to throw the Runner off. The different types of Ice and their corresponding Icebreakers seems like a bit of a crap shoot, at least with the base game. "Oh, he's got lots of Barrier Ice, I hope I have some Barrier Icebreakers....looks like those Sentry Icebreakers are useless this time."

I know that part of building a well-rounded deck is having an attack plan for anything you happen to face, and I think part of the limiting feeling comes from the small pool of cards from which to build. The base set is almost a preview of the full game, and the full game is base + expansions.

My major issue with the game is that it's sort of a lifestyle game; it's going to be at its best when played frequently, and against the same opponent(s) if possible. Building decks and battling someone, learning their tendencies, bluffing and suckering, etc. I don't have the time to devote this much attention to a single game, which makes me iffy about the game. 

Ultimately, I think Netrunner may be a very good game, but a poor fit for me at this point in my life.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I enjoyed the original Netrunner. This feels the same. However, I found that I'm just not very keen on these games that require lots of planning beforehand and dedicated play.

RATING: 9.8
What an amazing game this is. Complete and utter integration of theme, a dense metagame that is focused on reading, predicting, and responding to one's opponent, and not merely one's opponent's deck, and a rich, web-like, tactical layer that requires intense concentration, patience, and a sense of not only hand management but timing. The more I play it, the more I want to play it.

RATING: 10
Csodás játék. Nem véletlen van előkelő helyen.
Alapvetően nem szeretem a gyűjtögetős játékokat, de maga a téma nagyon megtetszett. Aztán játszottunk vele egyet. Meg még egyet. Meg még egyet... és így tovább :)
Amilyen hosszúnak tűnik a szabály, igazából annyira egyszerű, értelmesebb emberrel hamar meg lehet értetni.

Van benne egy olyan nehézség, hogy minden kis résznek van külön elnevezése, pl az eldobott paklik nem eldobott paklik, hanem archive, a kezedben lévő kártyák HQ és ez ráadásul különbözik a cégnél és a runnernél is. De igazából ez a témát akarja csak jobban előtérbe hozni, szóval nincs vele baj.

Nekem nagyon tetszik az alap készlet is (más még nincs), rengeteg az újrajátszhatóság benne, a random tökéletesen bele illik a mechanikába, és ezért az árért... tökéletes vétel volt!

Update: sokadig jatek utan megallapitom, hogy vannak esetek, amikor a runner harom lap huzassal siman nyer. A ceg semmit nem tud csinalni. Kicsit frusztralo

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
This game is becoming a quick favorite. Netrunner is one of the most thematic card games to come along in a long time. It feels like what it purports to be- runners raiding servers at great risk, while corporations desperately try to defend themselves, punish the runners, and push their agendas forward. The asymmetrical nature of the game calls for a change of mindset for playing each side, but the better you become at one the more you know how to play the other. Since I am a part of a growing base of players in my area, the game has also provided a great gaming group experience as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
Netrunner is a great, complex 2-player game.  While a lot of 2P games are just battle tactics, Netrunner adds in some euro-game elements: as a corp, you have to build up protected servers; as the runner, you need to create a good economic engine.  The wide diversity of cards and factions and the asymetrical game makes each game feel different.

I have 30 data packs (up to Business First).

RATING: 9
The mechanics of this game are superb and the asynchronous play really adds an incredible depth. That and the cyberpunk theme are what drew me to it. The backstory is rich and all the playable characters have identifiable styles.

I don't know if metagame is a valid point when reviewing, but that's really the only issue with it. Like every other game, serious play tends to distill a game down to its essential parts and with Netrunner, that has (in the past) created a boring metagame. But that's really only for tournament play which I think the majority of people don't participate in.

RATING: 8
Incredibly good 2-players, pure asymmetrical card game. Cyberpunk theme is everywhere - in the original ENGLISH version (ICE is an acronym, not the solid state of water... poor italian translation...).
No other game gives you the thrill of a good run on a hugely guarded server, or a good bluff to fry the hacker's brain; the only con I can think of is that it requires a good deck preparation but hey, it's a struggle for the fittest isn't it?!

Buy it, play it, love it. In english. A shining diamond and a very good FFG reboot of an old classic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Apart from go, this is the game I have played the most times. I stopped logging plays quickly...

I love this game, even though I haven't played it in a long while. I love (almost) everything about it: the interplay of theme and mechanics; the cards' art and text; the never-ending evolution of the rules.

It's easier to list the 2 things I dislike about it: the game is usually not played with a clock, perhaps because the flow of the game makes that impractical (the opponent often has actions available during your turn); more importantly, the rules and cards' writing is unbelievably sloppy.

RATING: 6
Pep: Muy buen juego pero para nada apto a todos los públicos, con una temática muy bien implementada. Complejo de aprender y al ser un LCG, prácticamente infinito. El problema que tiene este juego es que es más que un juego. Es decir, se necesita mucha implicación, tiempo, dinero... Como dicen muchos, es un "metajuego". La asimetría le da un plus y originalidad. Un gran juego, que difícilmente verá mesa :(

Nany: De acuerdo a lo de la temática y lo de la complejidad. Este juego, lo adquirimos con mucha ilusión, pero a mí particularmente no me ha entrado. Considero que es un juego que sólo disfrutas cuando ya lo tienes dominado, y para eso hay que jugar muuchas veces. Es muy complejo de aprender y de interiorizar las reglas. Personalmente no me gustan los juegos que requieren tanta dedicación para poder disfrutarlos.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I cannot say enough about this game. The theme is excellent but the game play is even better. If you enjoy bluffing and trying to get inside the head of your opponent this is the game to get. 

Asymmetrical game play gives each side a very distinct feeling and caters perfectly to different play styles.   

The cards in your deck are important but how you play is probably more important. We'll have to see how Netrunner develops over the long haul but so far I much prefer it over Magic The Gathering. 

The best part is that as a LCG it is no longer about who can spend the most to build their deck.

Regarding the Core set only - Traces/Bad Publicity, and especially Brain Damage seem pretty under utilized and some of the factions are better than others but future expansions will likely alleviate these issues.

If you do not want to start collecting cards and/or get involved in deck building I still highly recommend picking up the core set. It is a fantastic game right out of the box even with my minor quips.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After about 10 games now, A:NR is now my favourite 2-player game. 

Each session is done in about 30-40 minutes, allowing 2-3 sessions to be played inside 90 minutes. Aside from deckbuilding, which really should be done prior to a game session, set up and break down is also very quick.

The pros:
- The main appeal of the game is the bluff and second guessing between runner and corporation; 
- The factions each have completely different resources and options which mix and match to create asymmetric sessions that are different and sometimes surprising results;
- The runner and corporation also play very differently, adding to the variety of experience and appreciation for each side's available strategies and tactics in response to the other player's resources. The expansions widen this experience and promise some great metagame; and
- the base game sets and expansions are relatively cheap, and each expansion is purely optional depending on player tastes.

The cons:
- its only two-player (in its current form) so other LCGs that permit multiplayer will usually be preferred;
- the game's significant nomenclature isn't there just to add theme and is necessary to the specific rule set, which steepens the learning curve;
- its prone to some analysis paralysis-related downtime, especially for the corporation player while they plan and execute their ice and asset placements. This should reduce to a large degree through experience with the game;
- in addition to the above, the structure of the game is highly specific and fiddly but important to get right, significantly adding to the learning curve. I've often missed or forgotten to play rules in my early games;
- added to the above two, like many LCGs/CCGs, the cards "break" the rules, often requiring frequent reference to FAQs and card rulings;
- like most card games, a player's card draws can start very poorly or spectacularly well. The game mechanisms, as well as deck tuning and mulligan, does reduce this problem to some degree; and
- custom deck building requires at least two core sets, and possibly a third if a player wants to include 3 unique cards into a custom decks. This isn't a major issue because A:NR is not nearly as expensive for a player to build decks as compared to, for example, Magic:the Gathering.


>>minor update. I'm still really enjoying this brilliant game but the need to frequently check rules in the poorly organised rulebook and FAQ is persistent and a bit annoying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This asymmetrical game is something that won't make a lot of sense at first, but it will come to be a competitive game in ways most players aren't prepared for.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
In the CCG design world, you're trying to increase the design space for hundreds of interesting cards while avoiding adding complexity; but given the choice, you'd rather get both complexity and design space than none of them. Well Netrunner has a lot of both and I can recognise the good in its core design, but it really requires you to have a dedicated group of players; because amongst all the TCG/CCG/LCG games I've come across, it has the highest entry barrier of all. Not because of some inherent complexity, but because knowledge about the opponent's deck (or, at a larger scale, the metagame) is a way bigger egde than in other games. That makes it absolutely terrible for both pick-up-and-play (where a newbie will be clueless) and deckbuilding on a whim (because some cards will simply be dead against a given meta). Probably a great lifestyle game, but I'm not willing to put the investment to get enjoyment out of it.

Also boo to FFG who managed to take a fairly accessible ruleset (once you're past the nerdy cyberpunk vocable) and make the cards harder to decipher than they should by applying a different but always busy-looking template for each card type.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A very strong card game, I'd say it's one of the best. I really enjoy the variety of options available on each turn and the bluffing element of the game. It feels much more like a battle of wits compared to other card games such as Magic: The Gathering.

However, just like Magic, it requires a commitment from each player before they can fully enjoy the game. You need to be aware of the cards the opponent might have in the deck. You also should ideally make your own decks. This means it's not a game to pull out and teach a casually interested player, it's something you play for an extended period and learn to love over time.

RATING: 5
An inferior LCG. This prevents Netrunner from being truly great, but then again, I don't think it was ever intended to be. I will probably be getting several expansions to this over time, which means it must be fun enough to warrant it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In this 2 player card game, one player is the Corporation attempting to protect it's assets, while the other player is a "Runner" attempting to cyber attack into the Corporation. The Corporation places "ice" protection on the draw deck, servers and hand. In the servers can be placed agendas which are worth VPs, or ambushes. 

The runner attempts to make "runs" at the Corporation, to either score Agendas, or make the Corporation run out of cards. When you run, the runner reveals the ice and/or agendas. Since the cards are hidden, there is bluffing involved.  If the runner hits an ambush card, they can suffer damage.

On a player's turn, they can use actions to draw cards, play cards or earn credit, and in the runner's case, make a run.

The game seems alright after one playing, and I'm looking forward to trying out the other decks. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[b]Android: Netrunner[/b] by [person=14][/person] (Magic: The Gathering, RoboRally, King of Tokyo, King of New York...)
2 players

Card game, asymmetric player powers: Corporation versus Hacker.

Took a while to get through the rules, which ditch the generic terms (such as draw deck, discard pile, etc.) for more thematic terms. It is a bit problematic when learning the game from the rule book.

Have yet to play. The cyberpunk theme in a dystopian future setting is not for everyone.

See FAQ here:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/948642/nr-faq-please-read-posting-questions

RATING: 7

Not the game itself, rather why I did not enjoy it was a mystery.

I love deck builders, I love the cyber punk theme. I loved laying down ice. I loved the bluffing and trying to outsmart my opponent. I love card games. The cards looked beautiful. I love the concept of the game and everything about the game.

However, for some reason that I cannot explain, I just did not enjoy this game, and I tried many, many times to enjoy it with several different people.

It is hard to rate a game when I do not even know why I don't like it, but I ranked it how I feel none the less.  I kind of sound like my wife: Having feelings but not being able to explain them, but that is Android: Netrunner for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Extremely fun deck building game that is fast, fresh and highly strategic. Has the best asymmetrical gameplay I have encountered; Netrunner (hacker) vs Corporation. The theme works really well and is executed perfectly. 

I recommend having someone who likes the game teach you for first play, as the rule book and terminology used is not as intuitive as it should be. This can HEAVILY influence your impression of the game. Especially if you are playing the game incorrectly. 

2012: Rated ~2. "What is going on in this stupid game". 
2014: Rated 8.5. After being taught by an enthusiastic player (also purchased the game immediately afterwards!). 
2014: Rated 9.5. More plays, its fast, fun and cant wait until the next game. Want to buy the expansions, but don't feel it is that necessary either: there is a lot of game play in one core set and the first cycle (Genesis) would add more than enough for my gaming group.  

Cons:
-Envisage that competitive play may be hard without owning every card available.
-Its a living card game: aka money siphon. But on the bright side its much more economically feasible that MTG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A remarkably thematic asymmetrical card game, with a good amount of replay-ability and an interesting collection of mechanics. 

It is admittedly reliant on at least some expansion cards for long term shelf life, but with each pack of cards being fixed (players can easily check each packs card list before purchase) that is far more tempting and justifiable than the old collectible format. I would recommend the deluxe boxed expansions, with other data packs added as desired for flavor/completeness.

An excellent game, especially with a few add-ons to keep deck construction variety high.

RATING: 9.5
Android: Netrunner is a near perfect game in my opinion. It's truly amazing the way it integrates traditional CCG style card play with economy management and even adds in a bit of bluffing. On top of that it covers all of this in a wonderful theme that feels 100% natural to the game. Android: Netrunner could not possibly be about anything else.

The only thing keeping this from a perfect 10 is that all of these things that make it so wonderful also make it quite a chore to teach and keep up with. An interesting caveat but a caveat nonetheless.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I really don't understand the hype about this game. It looks cool, I give 10/10 for the theme and artwork. When I first played this game, I wanted to like it.

In the end it's all about bluffing and deck building and stressing credit management which drains your game totally if you don't get the right cards at the right moment. Maybe I had a bad deck but still.

Pros:
- Awesome art and theme!
- Thrilling gameplay because you don't know the opponent's next move or see their cards (and you really want to)
- Very dynamic because of the different corporations and runners. Great replay value.

Cons:
- Terminology. Heap, Grip, rezzed ice... really? I'm a programmer and a computer nerd by profession, still these terms feel stupid and confusing.
- CCG. To me that's a downer.
- This game is too hardcore. You can't ask your wife or some random friend to play this. You really need to be into this, building decks and going through your cards. You have to own it, expand it.
- Resource management is a bottleneck. If you have bad luck with the cards you can't do nothing. You spend all your "clicks" or actions to get credits to do stuff. Boring. Not fun.
- The gab between more experienced player and a beginner is HUGE. I have read this elsewhere and agree. This is a game for hardcore fans.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very difficult to learn, a few games in and I'm still not confident that I groked it all yet. I like the idea of all the different factions, but it might be a too much game to get into.

RATING: 8
Very thematic and very aesthetically pleasant.

Not only do Corporation and Runner decks function very differently; Identities within the two opposing factions feel different when playing.

I can clearly see why this is so well regarded.

Unfortunately, I don't necessarily like the economy flow, where you have to build many credits, then use them on an educated guess and have to rebuild them again.  I think that slows down things a bit and yes, it contributes to the uniqueness of the game and tension of runner vs company, but it's not enjoyable to me.

RATING: 2
I don't get why this game is so popular. Also, is it possible to learn this game solely from the manual? No, not frozen water, but rather a stackable layer of protection. So very thematic, but come again?

RATING: 9.5
Incredible spin on the LCG genre. Nicely designed with the asynchronous goals and play. It's the next evolution in the head-to-head card game genre, collectible or no.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My favorite CCG of the post-MtG era gets the FFG Royal Treatment: Significantly improved artwork, balanced-ish factions with deckbuilding potential, the LCG model instead of digging through packs of boosters for rares.  Almost every change from the older version has been a smart one, from reworking the trace and bad publicity mechanics to OOBE decks and a well-designed backstory tied to their Android universe.

And as predicted, the claustrophobic nature of the core set has been significantly reduced by the expansion packs.  This game broke the BGG Top 10 for a reason, folks.  It's the best reprint of 2012 and my happiest surprise.

2017 UPDATE: There is currently a LOT of noise around the lack of dominant strategies in the game, and how certain identities appear empirically better than others.  It might apply to the tournament scene where consistent identities are required for competition, but as a PvP experience without the scene it's still one of my Top 5 game designs of all time because it actively encourages experimentation... precisely because those so-called dominant strategies are so high-risk/high-reward that a single well-timed play can destroy an otherwise bulletproof strategy.  The only reason I'm not rating this a 10 is the learning curve for new people is obscenely steep.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Such an excellent game. Fun to play with expansions but it's not necessary. Fast and easy-to-learn. Nothing more, nothing less.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love the theme, like the artwork, and most of the mechanics.

The theme has been well captured in the game play.

Artwork is fantastic.  Card layout/design is really poor.  It is difficult to identify card factions and stats.  My main complaint is with the ice cards - the layout totally differs from the other cards.

The head-to-head nature reminds me of BattleLine, which is still one of the most intense games I've played.

If you read my comments before, yes I have changed my mind radically.  While reading about the tournament rules, I realized I had been playing one thing incorrectly (I was not paying credits for existing ice when installing additional ice).  So I decided to try again.

In my last 5 games, I have come to realize how good this game is.  I discovered a handful of misplayed rules that mostly favored the corporation.  I think the additive power of that created a totally lopsided effect that removed the fun.  Wish I had a standing partner with whom I could play.

After continued play:
Corp seems to have the edge.  As Runner can only trash certain cards, that reduces the benefit of multiple runs on either HQ or R&D. And that restricts viable options.
After further play:
Runners now seem to have the advantage.  Not sure if I'm getting the hang of Runner, am naturally inclined, or not playing Corporate correctly.  Tried tuning a Corp deck and it worked as expected and should (a tuned deck should be able to handle a non-tuned out of the box one)

This has been my worst ever game for missing rules.  I have had almost no trouble with CCG's in the past.  Almost every interpretation I had for LoTR LCG were spot on in the FAQ.  I am usually pretty decent.  But this game has absolutely eaten my lunch.

Why this is not a 10:
-> Cannot effectively evaluate whether I would play this all the time as it is not solo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm less enthused about this LCG than I thought I would be. I really wanted to like it, but it never seems to hit the high notes that it promises.

In particular, the amount of deception and mindgames in play is far less important than advertised; one imagines the corp laying down a web of remote servers, protected by varying levels of ice, and the runner having to mind-read to find the correct one. In practice, it just ends up as either a bunch of identical unprotected servers (random guessing) or two asymmetrical ones, one of which is promptly exposed, which obviates all need for guessing.

To make matters worse, it is vital to get a good balance of several kinds of cards (for the runner, icebreakers and resources; for the corp, agendas, ice, and assets). This creates the same problems as good old mana screw in Magic, but on an even worse scale.

The jargon, particularly for the various zones, is annoying and I constantly forget it. There's not much of a sense of building in scale either.

For me, this game doesn't come close to Magic.

Update: I've played a lot more now and I enjoy and understand the game much more. It's not so bad... but the criticisms above still stand. In addition, cardpool knowledge is very important in order to play half-decently.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very solid game. Asymmetry makes it awesome.

RATING: 10
The setting is WONDERFUL, finally a good working game with a Cyberpunk setting and with a hacking system which works. Game is pleasant to play and easy to learn. 
However, unfortunately, this *IS* like an asymmetrical Magic! The fact that cards are not sold randomly does not change the feeling so much: if you do not continuously buy cards and if you do not have a group of people doing the same, it will end up into a drawer exactly like the old Magic cards. It is rather difficult to involve another player into playing it, from a tactical/strategical point of view there are better two players games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The setting is WONDERFUL, finally a good working game with a Cyberpunk setting and with a hacking system which works. Game is pleasant to play and easy to learn.

It is rather difficult to involve another player into playing it, from a tactical/strategical point of view there are better two players games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An interesting and different 2 player card game. It is essentially a game of risk management and having the best economy to either sustain your attack on the servers or raising the defenses. The game has bluffing, but it's quite superficial and that's OK. After repeated plays you see through the fact that a lot of cards are played face down, and realize that your actions are actually much more open to you that you first thought.

The more you play the game the paint you scratch of the surface into the inner workings of the system. And it's a really good system! Of course the game is sustained by the constant release of new cards which make the game much more wide than deep. It's IMO still a deeper, richer experience than playing Magic: The Gathering.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I wish I had time to make decks and play them. This game is amazing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
規則:
*兩個人分別拿不同牌組洗勻，抽五張牌，公司先決定是否重新重抽在換駭客，只能一次，拿5個信用點
*起始牌組可用任意公司牌搭配公司中立牌，駭客可用任意駭客牌搭配駭客中立牌
*兩方的勝利提件都是7分議題分，公司沒牌抽輸，駭客沒牌棄輸
*公司方手牌為總部前面放一張該公司身分卡代表之，右邊牌庫為研發中心，在右邊棄牌堆為檔案庫，開著的棄牌兩分都可任意看，蓋著90度旋轉的只有公司能看，此三區為三個中央伺服器，左邊可蓋著放卡成為遠端伺服器，升級卡都放在後方，前方可以放防火牆來保護，一個伺服器只能有一張議程或資產卡，升級卡跟防火牆卡(新的往外擺)不限制，公司卡牌分六類
>特性卡牌 標示公司名稱跟組牌限制還有起始能力
>事務 一次性使用後棄掉，支付左上費用
>議案 蓋著打出，上面可放推進標記，達到要求時可翻面放到計分區(左中)，並獲得文字效果
>防火牆  蓋著放到伺服器前，駭客侵入時才能選擇支付費用打開，分成屏幕/陷阱/警報/門禁
>升級 蓋著放到任意伺服器後，可支付費用打開才有效果，右下是駭客的銷毀費用
>資產 蓋著放到伺服器位置，可支付費用打開，一樣可被駭客銷毀
*駭客 手牌叫操控器，右邊牌庫為存儲線，在右邊棄牌為堆陣，左邊分三列，前到後依序為程式硬體資源，卡牌分五類
>特性卡牌 駭客名稱跟能力還有組牌限制
>硬體(件) 支付左上費用放到對應列，無上限
>資源 支付左上費用放到對應列，無上限，被鎖定是可被公司銷毀
>程式(序) 支付左上費用放到對應列，費用旁有內存數字，不能安裝超過上限，文字會敘述可破解的防火牆類型，左下為強度要大於等於防火牆強度才能作用
>事件 支付費用打出後棄掉
*有些卡牌有獨有標記，場上只能有一張開著
*遊戲由公司方開始輪流進行直到一方勝利
*公司方每回合有三個時點(行動力)，駭客方有四個時點，每人回合分成三個階段>從牌庫抽一張牌(駭客不抽牌)>行動>棄牌至手牌上限(正常五張)，公司棄牌蓋著棄
*公司跟駭客的共同行動有
>抽一張牌
>拿一元
>打一張事務或事件牌
>觸發需要行動的卡牌能力
*公司獨有行動有
>出一張蓋著的牌，議案資產升級或防火牆，出牌到該伺服器前可先棄掉上面任何牌
>花1元放一個進程指示物到蓋著的牌上(特定牌)，如果是議案且上面指示物數量超過卡牌上需求，則在公司回合前或行動後都可以翻面放到計分區
>花2元銷毀駭客的一張資源卡如果駭客被鎖定
>花三個行動清除病毒指示物
*駭客獨有行動
>安裝程序硬體資源，牌面向上，遊戲起始內存單元上限4，安裝超過要銷毀程式
>兩元移除一個鎖定標記
>進行一次攻擊(潛襲)
***潛襲 分三個階段***
1.啟動階段 駭客宣告攻擊的伺服器，公司每有一負面聲譽駭客拿一元(此次攻擊可用)
2.對抗階段 有防火牆的結算(接觸到蓋著的時候公司可決定是否支付費用打開)，如果要取消防火牆的子進程效果，要有強度等於大於該防火牆的破解器，並使用對應能力支付費用解除子進程，多張防火牆由外至內一一結算，每次遇到新的可選擇是否繼續深入
*被破解的防火牆不會銷毀，破解器的強度增強通常是指有對應一張防火牆，除非有說明
3.讀取階段 突破所有防火牆如果駭客選擇繼續，公司有最後一次機會翻面卡牌，之後讀取，研發中心則看頂牌，總部隨機抽牌，檔案庫全部一起看(蓋著的翻面)，遠端伺服器就直接拿起來看，同時可看所有升級(安裝的防火牆不能看)，如果拿到議案開著放到分數區，可銷毀的卡牌可付資源銷毀(讀牌庫多張時要照順序放回)
*追蹤 上面有強度，公司可在先花費每1元增加1強度，在由駭客花錢決定要增加中轉強度多少，最後等於小於中轉強度時追蹤失敗
*鎖定 被放置一枚以上就被鎖定
*傷害 肢體跟網域都是隨機棄牌，腦部除了隨機棄牌外手牌上限減1，拿對應標記表示
*如果同時要執行行動時，有當前回合玩家先
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game deserves its love.
You'll fear your enemy as you never know what he's up to.

There is room to do a lot in this little gem which takes 30-45 minutes to play. And a lot of factions which focus on its own kind of thing.

I wish it could be just a few boxes, similar to Dominion, so you can just take it and play. It would narrow down the number of strategies but will deliver a good experience for a wider player base.
Nonetheless the core box has a lot of gameplay in it.

The rules are heavy, don't be fooled, there is a lot of timing in the rules to be learnt (when you can/can't do solmething) and will need around 4-5 to learn the gameplay perfectly. 
Furthermore, the card pool has to be learnt as well, so you know what to expect from your deck and your opponent's deck.
Thus, high steep learning curve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

英文版 1200 已拆未玩
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wow! I played many ccgs back in the day but missed this one.  So happy I got a second chance on the rerelease with an improved format (lcg).  The asymmetry is great, I feel like I have the disadvantage no matter which side I am playing.  The out of box variety is superb for having so few cards, and the corps/factions all play differently.  So far I am loving the deck building and the amount of strategy when playing.  This game seems very likely to end up a 9 or 10.  Very excited to log a lot more plays and for the expansions.

Edit: Did not update to a 10 for over a year after it deserved it.  The best LCG/CCG easily, but it is more than that.  It is simply the best game ever made.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is not just another game. It is an incredibly intricate and nuanced dance. Its player asymmetry and unique mechanics offer a great blend between long term strategy, short term tactical moves, some pure good-old bluffing and a degree of luck that is just right to always keep you on your toes. I've been playing this game intensively for over two and a half years and I keep finding new ways of approaching both individual cards and the game as a whole. You can make it as complicated (and personalized) as you like by going deep into the deck-building aspect of the game, or you can simply pick up a pre-built deck and still find infinite different ways to approach it. Oh, and it also has one of the best implementations of theme ever. Basically, its really good is what I'm saying here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Currently favorite 2 Player card/deckbuilding combat system. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've only played with the starter packs and that gives a very satisfactory game by itself, without having to delve into money-pit mode to buy more cards. It's a wonderful 2 player game for gamers. Rules complexity is high and a barrier to entry, but if you can get an opponent into it with you, there's a wonderful asymmetric struggle in store. There's bluff, there's surprise, there's multiple approaches, there's the luck of the cards, there's the hard decisions each turn on where and what to invest in. I'm not into the deck building thing as a rule, so I'd be content with what the starter set provides given it provides multiple factions to try out, which is more than the original did.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I fell in love with this game when I started reading the rules. Asymmetric gameplay, no card rarity and the theme are quite attractive to me. I first rated this game 9... after a few games 8... now that I've explored and made my own deck out of all the current cards (free online)... 7... I had forgotten why I didn't play TCGs. I fucking hate losing because of bad draws.

I like to play Corp (Haas-Bioroid especially). In my opinion, there's a frustrating disadvantage to playing defence here: you're stuck having to draw those damn agendas. I don't know how many times I lost because all I was drawing was agendas. Nor can I count how many times I won or lost depending on which card was randomly accessed from my hq (hand) or r&d (deck) by the opposing hacker's attack.

Don't get me wrong, it's a good game. If you're into TCGs and you don't mind luck as a factor in games then it's a great game, go for it. When you have a tight game it's awesome. Hell the inconsistent frequency of that reward, never knowing when you're going to get it, is quite addicting. But if you're like me and you absolutely hate feeling powerless, save yourself hundreds of dollars and hours. Too many times, in my opinion, do players win just because of luck.

I'd still play but I'm not buying more cards.

RATING: 1
Hype purchase. Big mistake. When will I learn to avoid BGG rankings? I give myself a '1' for that. The game also gets a '1'. Huge box filled with air. Requires expansions, requires deckbuilding, requires interest in the theme. Could not get one person interested in playing due to the extremely narrow and dry theme. Might be a good game in here (doubtful, as it is built for expansion purchases) but we will never know because of obstacle 1) lack of theme interest. Soon realized I could not get into the theme either, and looking at the cards and their artwork was the height of tedium. I did play the original in 1996. Times change, pc's and their 'mystique' were somewhat interesting in the early years of the internet, now they seem like stale and crash ridden remnants of the past on the way out due to tablet supremacy. That makes this theme an exercise in nostalgia that is 20 years too late. A waste of time (going to store, trying to learn it, trying to find someone interested) and money. Sold. It doesn't help that I hate my PC. It crashes, it loses my data, it's always been a headache. I have virtually zero positive associations with it over the years, unlike my ipad.  This game reminds me of my PC. I spend enought time on it. Being reminded of my PC and its problems over the years through a 'game' is actually very unpleasant and not relaxing at all. 

Bought 'Star Wars LCG' and theme interest at least got it to the table. That one gets an '8' as it does not remind me of my PC.

RATING: 8
A very cool take on a card based game. I personally hate games where you need to buy expansions/boosters and build your own deck, so I would never buy this, but the game is a lot of fun. One side is the runner, while the other is the corporation. Each side plays very differently as the runner must get program breakers and attack the servers (assets) or R&D (deck) of the corporation, while the corporation sets up firewalls and traps. Very original and fun and you can simply play with the base game if the continuous upgrading of your deck does not interest you. Although just the base game may get repetitive after a while.

RATING: 7
Netrunner is amazingly tight, extremely asymmetric, and games are quick (30-45 mins).

Rulebook is OK, but uses "thematic" wording very liberally which makes it extremely hard to figure out what it's actually telling you to do, and some nuances are unclear. 

If you have someone that already knows it it won't take long to teach, otherwise it will take a few games to get the hang of it.

RATING: 10
Acquired at Jupiter in Nov, 2012. First plays on 11-24. Replaces Eve ccg via Jones rule for me. Initial rating, 9. [oct 2013] This game is really really great, even just with the base set. A lot of value here, tons of game to explore. The only challenge for me is finding an opponent to invest the necessary time to dive into this, as learning the cards and combos takes many plays. // Update: early in 2014 I gave this away to my only opponent. Have not played it since, and neither has he. A lot of good games have come out since then, and I'm not the type to devote myself to just one game, which is what I think Netrunner might require. It is still an amazing game however, if you are willing to put the time into it. Dropping to an "8", but would be a "10" if I could clone myself and let the clone spend the time.

Nov 2014: Played 4 times in two hours, as corp against one of my four best opponents for games. Was an amazing two hours. Raised back to a 9, and if I could just get to play this a little bit more... Man this game is amazing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Playtime: ~45 minutes

Comment: Holy shit do I love this game. The theme is dripping in this one and I can't wait to find actual opponents to play against. The deck building is the only aspect of this game I haven't tried. Amazing artwork, fast play, and LCG to boot. Can't wait to play some more of it.

Edit: After getting quite a few more plays of it in, I'm not sure how to feel about this game. I can't seem to figure out how to do well, even after almost 30 plays of it. Even against novice opponents, I tend to lose. I also don't care for deck construction in general, so maybe I'll enjoy this more if I can look up some prebuilt decks to play. This game is waning in interest for me. I'll give it a little while longer, but right now it's a 7, leaning towards a 6.

RATING: 10
Superclever old CCG remake. 

Never played the original but absolutely loved Android: Netrunner! Gameplay is radically asymmetrical, which means both players have a completely different ruleset to follow. The runner needs to build his arsenal effectively and then chose his battles wisely. The corporation is all about bluffing. 

Only played with the pre-constructed decks but it's easy to see that deck building will take this to another level. 

In the age of the dominion clone and the multi-effect card game, this cult classic feels very novel and imaginative. Richard Garfield is undoubtedly a genius.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Quite possibly the pinnacle of CCGs. Richard Garfield really hit his peak with this one. It strikes such a great balance between strategy (deck building) and tactics (table play) that most CCGs fail to deliver (most are primarily concerned with deck building). The fact that it's an LCG now and not a TCG only makes it more balanced in that respect.

Perhaps the biggest weakness is that there is no multiplayer variant, and a second problem is that it's hard to wrap your head around the rules at first if you're totally new to the game (even though the game flows very smoothly, and is easy to follow once you get a few core concepts down). But this game is absolutely worth the learning curve. One of the highlight releases of 2012, easily in the top five for the year if not #1.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First thing, every competent player can build a good deck and have a lot of fun [u]with only one core set[/u]. How is it possible? Because there [u]isn't[/u] three copies of each card inside. Thank you FFG.

Now...

This is the game.

This is the game that combines every aspect.
You prepare your resources before the game (deck building).
You play your opponent, not your deck.
You have to manage your resources: cards, actions order, money.
You must bluff, evaluate the risk, take risk, try crazy things.
You can rarely win if you stay in your safety zone.

The game is fast and intense. It plays smoothly. The theme is everywhere.

I'm a big fan of the classic Netrunner. It has a believable theme and incredible mechanisms. It's sad that some cards have broken the game.

Hopefully, Netrunner is back in a better incarnation. The incredible mechanisms are still there, sometime even improved. The broken cards are removed.

Thanks to the factions and the Android universe, the theme is deeper than ever. The anonymous corporations now have a name, a logo, a spirit, strength points, weaknesses, and specific agendas. The runners have also different motives and manners.

The core set is playable out of the box for two players, with 7 decks and a lot of room for deck-building.

For me, this is the most exciting game ever.
Thank you Mr. Garfield! Thank you FFG!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[floatleft][ImageID=1311896][/floatleft][b][u]Initial Impressions:[/u][/b]
Finally! Fantasy Flight gets something right! It's about damn time! 

I am flabbergasted at this successful reimplementation of the original [thing=1301][/thing]. As a CCG, Netrunner was only a murmur in the gaming world but it garnished enough of a following to merit as a cult classic. Dwarfed by its older brother Magic: The Gathering, I don't think the gaming world was ready for Netrunner when it was first arrived on the scene. The original Netrunner was progressively ahead of its time but failed significantly with card balance and deck building restrictions. FFG has done an excellent job so far correcting the mistakes of the original. Android: Netrunner (A:NR) stands on the shoulders of a giant and FFG has done this cult classic justice. It will thrive as a LCG. 

[b][u]What I like:[/u][/b]
Netrunner is a cool game. This is two player asymmetry at its very finest. Each player has distinct actions and objectives. When I play as the Runner I feel like I am hacking into a Corporate system trying to find chinks in their defenses. Playing as the Corporation, I feel as if I am trying to keep the Runner out of my servers to accomplish my own sinister agendas. This game is intensely thematic.  

The factioning system in A:NR is really what makes this version stand leaps and bounds above its predecessor. Only being able to spend a certain amount of points on out faction cards really introduces some dynamic factors into this game. Each faction has built in strengths and weaknesses and you want to splash all those juicy cards from another faction in your deck but you can't have them all. Through limitation you have to strive for deck building ingenuity. 

The best part of A:NR is that it is a skill game. At the highest levels of play I have lost an entire match to one credit. It still surprises me how balanced this game is despite all the factions and cards. There are some random elements inherent in any card game but the same guy won the World Championships two times in a row is evidence enough that skill matters. 

[b][u]What I dislike:[/u][/b]
I think the thing I dislike the most about Netrunner is the LCG release life cycle model. After playing Netrunner competitively for a couple a years I got burnt out trying to keep up. I had to stop by data pack expansions after the SanSan cycle. It's sad that I got burnt out on a game I absolutely love. I think I am content with my A:NR collection now. 

[b][u]Overall:[/u][/b]
Android: Netrunner has become one of my all time favorite games. I think this is second only to Go in my rankings and that is saying a lot.

[i]Scorched Earth is an a$$hole.[/i]

[b]OCTGN Games Played:[/b] 58
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I found this game a lot more frustrating than enjoyable.

:star: Art and components
:nostar: Innovative mechanics
:nostar: Handles 5 or more players
:nostar: Good with different player counts
:star: Low time between turns
:nostar: Comfortable complexity
:star: Re-playability
:nostar::nostar::nostar: Enjoyment

RATING: 7
My regular 2p opponent bought this recently and we were both keen to try it. Unfortunately neither of us knew the rules already, and the rulebook is horrid. The game may be asymmetric, but I found having different thematic terminology for 'draw deck', 'hand' and 'discard pile' for each of the players unfortunate to say the least. Once we finally got going, I found the game surprisingly simple, though Fantasy Flight did their usual best to conceal that under a layer of unnecessary chrome. The asymmetry is really neat, and I like the mind games. I enjoyed the game, and would like to play again, but I do feel that most of the point of it will be getting in really deep with the deck-building and expansion packs. I don't think I'm interested enough for that to be likely. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Beautifully thematic asymmetrical gameplay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
I am a big fan of games like Agricola, Power Grid, Railroad Tycoon (Railways of the World), Twilight Struggle, Brass, and Eclipse. The other 7, not so much. I wanted it to work, really (especially after the $40 donation to the neighborhood game store), but after eight games, I had to call it off--too many other games to play.

RATING: 8
8 - Got this in a trade and threw down a quick game, despite the initial difficulty with the terminology the rule book is pretty well laid out which allowed us to jump right in and stumble our way through making only a few major mistakes.  The next day I realized I was rolling in the back of my head how I could have done better, and wanted to play another deck to learn more about the weaknesses and strengths.  I was pleasantly surprised with how addicting this game is right out of the box.

*****
I don't think this game is bad, but when I got it I was expecting it to be more akin to smash-up, grab a base company, shuffle in the core stuff, and go at it.  Because it begs and screams to be tweaked and tuned you cannot play this with one box, you need each person to get their own set and while I would rather play this than magic I can't see convicing my crew to jump ship considering the games are much more in depth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
So LCG's, as a money making model, is awful, but whatever, that's not intrinsically a game problem. Then there's the huge amount of work you have to do to catch up on this game buying data packs and learning what kind of cards and combinations come out. I can't stand games that involve building custom decks, because then half the game isn't the game, it's preparing the materials you use to make the game. Games like Imperial Settlers are at first fine because it's all preconstructed decks, but then fall apart when you're expected to custom build your own decks for a 'better' experience. I don't want to build my best experience. I'm PAYING YOU TO DO THAT GAME! This can be a huge problem in social games like the werewolf games, and especially when you oversaturate with roles, like in Two Rooms and a Boom. 

I'm also not a big fan of a game that revolves around building these custom card interactions, but then you're still stuck with the process of drawing cards, and hoping for the best. While in game design I think that a deck of cards can be a nice randomness generator, I don't think that everything is best represented using this. In a game where you're a future-hacker, why would your stuff be randomly generated? I'd rather have there be a pool of cards that you're working from, and then have that be what you're customizing (but then you're halfway to Dominion, which features the same problems where there are certain intrinsically positively valued plays). So I haven't nailed down the problem of Netrunner in a coherent central hypothesis, but at least now I know for sure that it is what it is.

tldr: I hate LCG's but this is probably the finest LCG out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A very tense experience. Completely asymmetrical, bluff, strategy and a lot of choices/decisions make this game a fantastic one.

The core set is quite well done too, with four Mega-Corporations and three Runners; twelve different match-ups with complete decks of about 50 cards each.
I'd say it's a complete game out of the box as it is and a good start for those interested in deckbuilding. 

A little flaw is the new FFG artwork which is so and so, while the heavier flaw are the balance problems in my opinion: Jinteki and (mostly) NBN are not so competitive out of the box. Both need more Credit incomes and the TAG mechanics are not supported by enough powerful cards to scare the Runners, which will simply take the TAGs and go for the Agendas (mostly at the start of the game). A real pity. I added some tweaks to balance both the decks.

RATING: 9.75
This is the real deal. I've never seen my friend group get hooked on a game as quickly and deeply as Netrunner. A lot of the best strategies are very counter-intuitive, which irks some players but greatly rewards those looking for a deep test of skill. It is only imbalanced at the absolute highest level; anything below that provides an immersive, tightly-constructed test of intelligence and wit.

only previously owned because my little brother spilled water all over the cards, I am working on getting a replacement as soon as I can.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
All right, okay, FINE. After 15 plays, trying out two corps and two runners, I can no longer deny it—this is my favorite game. I love playing as the runner, building up my rig and weighing whether to run against that juicy remote server... or maybe R&D? I love playing as the corp, pulling traps out of my deck (or knowing they're lurking down there somewhere), and daring the runner to try me. This little card over here with three advancement tokens? Is it a high-point agenda? A devastating Project Junebug? Why don't you come and see? I love the thought and care put into the game, the incredible art and how Netrunner can tell a story through the cards. I love the levity injected into this dystopia—we don't have Thomas Haas/The Source yet, but he's already our favorite disappointment.

I've only built one corp and one runner deck so far, but I adore both of them, and can't wait to try building a deck for each faction. I love that even though my husband and I have different playstyles, we can both tailor decks to our tastes. At this point, it would probably be easier to list the things I don't like about Netrunner, but my only fear is how tempting it will be to part with my money in order to expand the game. But! I also think you'll have a ton of fun without ever using more than one core.  The reason I chose Netrunner is that it seemed like an LCG you didn't /need/ to expand (if you just want to play casually), and I'm happy to say that I've found that to be true. We've been playing with the Revised Core Set for just over a week, and I can already tell that we're going to get a lot of enjoyment out of this box. However, are we going to expand so that we can explore this world and spend some more time here? Yes. Oh, yes.

If you're at all interested in Netrunner, I don't think you'll regret pulling the trigger. Just watch out for Project Junebug.
