=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A different kind of a beast. LCG game, so you just buy everything once and then jump into deck building. Beautifully done, superb theme integration, great artwork and flavor text. 

But above everything else, here you play your opponent, not your deck or table. This is a game of knowing your opponent's hand, denying cards, stealing cards, sitting there with a poker face while secretly sneaking a trap, bluffing, double bluffing and triple bluffing. A good deck is needed, sure, but if you won't play it wisely, you will still lose. Runner and Corp game is very different and choosing from several factions, you can tailor your gameplay to your preferred "character". 

Really an amazing game, but you have to learn it a bit and construct a deck for full enjoyment. It's a gamer's game, so it will be hard to just play it casually with friends. But if you seek an ultimate card/deck building/resource management/bluffing game, you've found it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Poor rules.. You'll need someone to teach the game. Very hard to teach once you do know it. Core game was boring as hell.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This will be one of extremely few exceptions to the not-having-half-points rule. I currently will never turn down a game of Netrunner that I am able to participate in realistically. I love the game, and I love the direction they're taking it in.

A 10 signifies that I always will want to play the game, and while that's true for the moment, the game relies pretty heavily on an expanding meta with new packs released. If at some point FFG releases a bunch of cards that drastically change the game for the worse, then my opinion can change.

But for now, this is my card game of choice.

RATING: N/A
This game is freaking amazing for a CG/LCG. Sadly, I feel like my collective card game days are behind me. I played Yugioh a lot, but lost interest as I disagreed with the hugely immature and cutthroat attitude of the community. The main thing that led me to quit was the way that Konami was going with the game. The public disapproval and cost for the game didn't help either.

Anyways, this game does a two player card game right. There is a huge amount of bluffing, a high skill cap, great theme, a reasonable price tag, beautiful artwork, and more. It's a shame that I don't really have too many people to play with. My friends and I would rather play a big game (like Mansions of Madness) than to play a two-player game, as we usually have a lot of people. Hey, the more the merrier, right? :D

This game is pretty darn tricky to learn though (not as bad as Yugioh surprisingly) and extremely intense. It's a shame that more people don't play.

RATING: 9
I think it took some major balls to release this gem. Back in the day, it sold poorly and was dominated by all the multiplayer CCGs so there's little reason to wonder why this asymmetrical 2 player cardfest didn't do that well. Still, it had rabid following (I was creating extra cards and illustrating them with 2D/3D art etc).

I was expecting that they'd just use Netrunner's name (even though the IP is old enough that I doubt it has any resonance with the current crowds - so I was mindblown to realize it's pretty much the same game.

I love it - I love the microexpansions, that they stuck to their guns with the texts etc etc.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Toma de contacto buena, con la primera partida ya da la sensación de que hay muchas estrategias y configuraciones de mazo posibles, nada mas terminar la partida nos pusimos a analizarla, los fallos y aciertos y nos quedo una muy buena sensación.

Mas profundo de lo que parece, hay muchas formas de jugar las partidas y muchas formas de perder, una de ellas duro 10 min. Proyecto Gallina Ciega, con dos marcadores de avance en el segundo turno, tres cartas en la mano del runner, incursión contra el servidor y se acabo. Hay que jugar unas cuantas partidas para aprenderse los combos y cartas.

Es un juego en el que el factor suerte es bastante determinante, cuando te haces el mazo lo haces planteando una estrategia pero si a la hora de jugar no te salen las cartas, ni estrategia ni nada, lo único que puedes hacer es ver como tu contrincante puntúa sin rascar nada. Podríamos justificarlo en que no has jugado bien los turnos, o que quizá no hayas hecho el mazo con el suficiente numero de cartas de un tipo para que tengas mas posibilidades, pero aun así si el azar no te sonríe solo puedes ver pasar los turnos. Por ejemplo, en una partida que me duro unos 10 turnos, a mi compañero le salieron 5 hielos, puntuó 5 planes y gano con los 7 puntos, en mi caso no me salio ni un solo rompehielos y eso que me había tirado barajando varios minutos mientras preparábamos. 

Eso si , espero que la siguiente vez me sonría la suerte...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really like the game as it is truly a bluffing game at heart. Each turn is about trying to get what you want done. However, your opponent is also trying to do that. I really love many things about it... the art, the asymmetric gameplay, the interesting theme and flavor text, etc. It's a very rule intensive game however and the specialized terms such as remote server, grip and heap do not help. Also, it can really be a hard game to get out if you don't have the audience for it unlike Magic. And those $15 data packs can add up. I'm also not liking FFG too much at the moment because of the netrunnerdb cease and desist fiasco. If you do find a dedicated opponent for it, it is a very satisfying game.

RATING: 9.5

RATING: 3
Ugh.

I love FFG games. I really like cyber-punk. I also quite like the idea of asymmetric gameplay and goals. I don't particularly mind LCGs.

I hate Android: Netrunner.

As runner, I feel tension. Should I go for this card, is he bluffing, am I about to snare myself? Fairly enjoyable.

As corp, I feel completely powerless. Nothing I do works, the runner can just go through R&D at will and I get the impression I'm the AI behind their single-player game.

Yes there are ways to ensnare the runner, I get this from being the runner myself. Yes you can protect R&D with good ice. Yes there are even more ways to do so in more data packs. Do I want to commit a load of money to better my corp experience? No.

Speaking of which, why do you need credits to do everything? Why does it not just cost an action or two to Rez ice? I don't see the point of having a money system tacked on top of everything else, it just favours those who are lucky enough to draw a money card early.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

but I don't think I will ever teach this game to anybody again.
lots of specific word and term to remember.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.64
Wow.   Great 2P card game.  It is the tensest and most engaging experience that you can have with a deck of cards.

If you play the runner (think computer hacker), you'll have the feeling of being a renegade trying to infiltrate the network of an evil corporation.

If you play the corporation, you'll feel the power of trying to make your servers so well protected that no hacker has a chance of accessing anything.

Despite being so different, both sides of the game offer a great experience.

I only have the base game and that is all I plan to use.  6 plays in we've only used one of the runners and one of the corporations so far....with no deck building.  We'll play all the runners/corps and then we'll start some deck-building (thinning and personalizing the deck).  The base game has enough to keep you engaged for months/years.

Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Its a great game, but everyone knows that :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
What started as a great game has fallen victim to the plight of many card games: it no longer plays as intended.  There are so many cards and combinations, that the current meta supports a wide variety of strategies that have little to do with established remotes behind ICE or running those locations.  The hijinks and jank is very strong with the current level of card bloat with little to no rectification in sight.

RATING: N/A
+ Good in the sense that it is very different to Magic: The Gathering, unlike most other card games
+ Asymmetrical sides and strategies adds an interesting twist to 1v1 card games
+ Introduces Magic players to a new take on economy (especially when playing Corporation), also card advantage isn't as significant as it is in Magic
+ Base game gives you a fair bit of replayability, data packs are by no means essential right from the start

- A very fast moving Living Card Game that could become as expensive for some as a Trading Card Game like Magic: The Gathering. I think a casual Netrunner player could probably get by by just waiting for the big expansions (Creation and Control & Honor and Profit) to be released and getting those instead of every data pack available.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Brilliant reboot of an old liscence, Netrunner does better than ever with Fantasy Flight's LCG approach. For those unfamiliar, LCGs get new cards in waves of 20, that can be purchased for $12-15 for 3 copies of each, allowing players to focus more on building their decks and strategy than spending money and 'rare pulls' that games like Magic and Pokemon rely on.

Fantastic game with an amazing theme that really shows in all aspects of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A nice and solid asymmetrical card game. Should get better with a larger card pool.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This game was a gift. A carefully-researched and very thoughtful gift meant to be the backbone of a weekend of celebratory gaming.

Day 1: Excitement (note that no gameplay actually took place on this day)

Day 2: Confusion (“We have to watch a 20-minute video just to understand the basic jargon? TWICE?”)

Day 3: Anger (“Why can’t this game just use normal words for anything?”)

That was the first weekend. We really stuck with it for another couple of weeks by adding custom player aids, doing research online, and trying different configurations of cards. That’s more work than either of us put into our actual relationship so the game has gathered dust ever since. We’re pretty sure that all the reviews saying it’s a great couples game are written by robots from a joyless future where the only game that exists is Android: Netrunner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It feels as though the runner should run early and run often. Early in the turn so the runner has enough clicks to shake any tags or take advantage of events that reward successful runs. Often throughout the game because, even if the runs fail, it will force the corporate player to rez Ice, giving the runner more information on what programs he should install and where to focus his efforts on later turns.

Elsewhere I've said asymmetric games always make me suspicious that players have unequal chances of winning. This can be mitigated in two player games by having the sides switch roles every match, and playing best of 5 or until one player has two more wins than the opponent.

RATING: 6.5
for a while there i was single and bored and looking for a place to hang out weekly. my local boardgame cafe is actually a LCG hub on all the other days, so i looked to see what was on offer. Android Netrunner... i remembered playing the original Netrunner long ago and i'd recently read Neuromancer, so yeah that sounded great. i bought some cards and fiddled around. bought some more cards, play during lunch at work a bit. bought some more cards, and then began to worry. for one thing, i didn't feel good enough to play at the game shop yet. i mean, it all just felt spectacularly random, despite how i could see better deck pilots succeeding. i guess the game was both more nuanced than i'm prepared for (feels a little funny to say that as a mid-high weight euro player) and occasionally more swingy-but-fast than is my preference. it's like saying "i don't care much for chess anymore because sometimes the other guy gets two queens out early, but at least it was over quick." i think it's the issue of "take-that" (counterspells, stealing, destroying, discards, etc) and what it means to me. stomping or being stomped doesn't feel very rewarding to me, even if we can easily shuffle up and play the next game which might actually be fun and not a shut-out. i'd probably very much enjoy checking out that new Legend of the Five Rings LCG, except i've run out of all that single-guy time (and money) i had before. at the moment i'm holding onto my cards because i bought Terminal Directive like a dummy. considering it's just sitting in my closet not even making it to work anymore, maybe it has overstayed it's welcome. ugg, i really wanted this to be a favorite!

RATING: 7
Android: Netrunner.. Very nice LCG.

Excellent easy-to-learn hard-to-master cardgame. I do like that you play very differently, if you play as a hacker or corporation. Corp playing defensively/passive aggressive, hacker going on the hunt for agenda's.

I like the theme a lot too, nicely different from another magic-like game.

I still think MtG offers more options, and doesn't force you to play either aggressively/passively. You are also not alloted as much freedom as I would prefer in deckbuilding. But AN is a very good replacement, that scratches a similar albeit slightly different itch for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Played the original one time back when it first came out. The bad rules and being taught by someone that didn't understand them kept me from getting into it then, but I always thought there was a lot of game under the mess of rules somewhere.

The FFG implementation is amazingly good. The core set is perfectly playable out of the box. There is a good amount of deckbuilding with one core set, and with a second core set you are really able to customize your deck how you'd like. I can't imagine how good this will be with more expansions. 

The asynchronous play is what sets this apart. Playing the corp and being a runner are so different that you really get a ton of variety. The bluffing element in the game is fantastic, and unlike many CCG/LCG games this one lets me feel very much in control. I am playing my cards rather than having my deck dictate what I do all the time. Fantastic game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
We are just getting started on this game, which appears to have a lot to offer. Very happy so far. With the exception of Ticket to Ride (an odd comparison, I admit!), I can think of no other game that gives me such delicious tension, such highs and such lows.

Plenty of game just in the core set, even just playing the core decks + neutrals without deckbuilding. Over 50 plays in now, and we haven't even bothered with the deckbuilding yet; it remains something to look forward to.

UPDATE: around play #60, we have begun deckbuilding. It makes the game even better (though I stand by what I wrote above--you can just shuffle in the neutrals and have an incredible good time).

It's not going to happen, but this is the only game I have ever played that I could imagine becoming a lifestyle game for me. In some alternate universe. Where all the other awesome games mysteriously disappeared.

UPDATE: around play #100, I am playing this A LOT now, teaching it to a bunch of my gamer friends. So the next question is whether I will burn out or not. It is now, as of this writing (March 2015), my favorite game.

UPDATE: around play #150, it is fair to say that A:NR has taken over. Taken. Over. (April 2015)

UPDATE: around play #200, we have finally opened the first expansion pack, and are "Deck Swapping" (deck building using just Core Starter + 1st expansion, so Zero influence), using at least two copies of each of the new cards, to force us to learn them all well. (May 2015)

UPDATE: 350 plays in, we are through the fourth data pack. We play Netrunner constantly. Talk about it. Think about it. An amazing game. (July 2015)

UPDATE: 500 plays, we are through the first six data packs plus first deluxe expansion. We are playing so frequently and so quickly it is difficult to keep track of the plays. Still nothing but good, with regard to ANR. (August 2015)

UPDATE: Around 600 plays, we are speeding a bit through the Spin Cycle (loaded with awesomeness), with some hope of "catching up" enough to play at some local store competitions in the year ahead. We will see. (October 2015)

UPDATE: Around 700 plays, we are finally Caught Up on data packs. We have begun testing our decks against championship decks here at home (albeit without the championship pilots!) to see where we stand, and to inspire our own builds. The next step is to start attending store tourneys to get a feel for the competitive play experience. Intimidating, but we will see. (December 2015)

UPDATE: Around 800 plays, beginning to play in store championships, making cuts and doing well. Really interesting playing against different opponents styles and ideas.  (February 2016)

UPDATE: Around 900 plays. The store champ circuit doesn't sync up well with our winter/spring schedule. But we continue to play within the family. So, so many cards in the pool right now, it just seems that anything is possible. Not only can you have hundreds of ideas for a deck, but each of those ideas can be implemented in countless ways, and accommodated by a handful of ID choices. Just amazing. (April 2016)

UPDATE: Now over 1000 plays. Amazing. Just this week, a new MWL shook up the deckbuilding rules. And that is so awesome. The boys and I got right to work building up new legal decks, trying them out. The "Living" aspect of the game is so good, and the design team entrusted to keep this thing moving forward is doing great. (July 2016)

The story this game tells is utter bollocks! (I'm not talking background, I'm talking about what happens on a "run"). 
And story is half the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a really cool experience: a CCG (using FFG's Living Card Game model) with all the depth that comes with that, but which has asymmetrical gameplay and a really engaging theme.  There is some barrier to entry, especially if you try to use all the special terminology the rulebook prescribes for simple things like your hand and deck, but I think this is quite playable if you keep some starter decks ready to go.

This is one game which I feel is better, at least for me and my group, if we don't peek behind the curtain of organized play and online metagame discussion.  Though it clearly lends itself to competitive play, I think it can work as a fun, thematic one-on-one experience with two players, so long as they both view it that way.

RATING: 8
Excellent asymmetrical card game.
Heavy emphasis on mindgames and bluffing if you're playing as the Corporation, which meshes really well with the theme of the game.
Excellent move from FFG to convert Netrunner to a LCG format rather than the original Collectible/Tradable CG format.
Corporation and Runner strategies continue to evolve as Data Packs get released down the line, so there's definitely a high level of replayability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Game play is absolutely superb - if you have the right gaming partner and don't care about the outside world, then you could get a hell of a lot of play out of the core set alone. There's much to be learned about playing this game well, and it relies on more fundamental gaming skills than just knowledge of cards - ie, bluffing, reading intent, managing risk and putting your neck out, boldness and invention. I really like it.

Can't keep up with the sale model, though. It's really great that the entire game is affordable if that's your gaming focus, but it's not so great if your budget is limited, though that is what it is. There's nothing stopping a deck without Clone Chips or Jackson Howard or currents or whatever going up against a netdeck tricked out with every flash card going and still scoring a win - or even just enjoying a good game (though getting pummelled)...

If you live in an urban area where there are a lot of Netrunner players meeting up regularly for games, you are depriving yourself of a delicious addiction if you don't give it a try. It is a game that demands real commitment, though - not so much because you have to stay up to date to stay competitive (though you largely do), but because it is that good of a game in itself. Which is no bad thing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In this era of multi-use card games (every card in Glory to Rome, Race for the Galaxy, Innovation etc has a gazillion uses), Netrunner has aged well, and sets the standard for single-use cards.

True to its CCG lineage, the complexity is all in the cards and the combos you make with what you put onto the table. But never getting caught with your pants down on credits (money), cards and clicks (actions) is also crucial. The play-or-draw action never fails to work for card games, giving you the option of either a more cautious approach, or to go in guns a-blazing and to hell with the consequences.

Unlike other CCGs, though, it's not merely about the meta-game. Awkward match-ups can occur, but good play (reading and signaling the enemy) can potentially overcome them. You do not win or lose merely via deckbuilding, with the face-to-face merely being a foregone conclusion; decisions during play can actually swing the game. My favorite part about CCGs was designing flavor-rich thematic decks which I would unfortunately never dream about taking to a tournament. It's great to have the freedom (or at least the perceived freedom) to design decks that are both thematic and competitive in Netrunner since in-game play matters a lot more.

The wildly asymmetric gameplay is a huge draw, especially in 2-player games. It's the Corporation vs. the Netrunner, with no clear-cut roles of offense and defense. Instead, each player tries to run out or prolong the clock at different points of the game. And layered throughout is the bluffing, where the Corporation throws out a few signals and the Netrunner needs to have discipline.

The "awesome theme" in here -- with many calling this the most thematic card game ever made (in my book, that's [thing=4174]Lifeboat[/thing]) -- is a little contrived by the game forcing you to call every single thing by its thematic name (including in the hard-to-follow rulebook), but hey, after 30min of brainwashing, it works. You get to be one of the cool kids who discusses strategies involving R&D, HQ, Programs and when to Rez Ice, instead of just where to place random pieces of cardboard (helps that I love cynical/dystopian themes). Pretty cool that the game tries to incorporate the hand, draw deck and discard pile organically too. My only reservation here is that "make a run" sounds wussy. Why not something like "let's run on it" or "break the system" or "plug in" etc? I like the "jack out" term.

[hr]
I wasn't sure after a few uneven plays early, but see now that the play style (especially of each faction) didn't click with me yet. Suspicions confirmed: the potential for smart play means 'fun, themed decks' and 'tournament-competitive decks' aren't mutually exclusive, and win/loss isn't determined primarily by match-ups. Finally a customizable game I can love again! I haven't obsessed like this over a game for a long time (with deckbuilding ideas popping into everyday life), so this deserves a bump to a 10!

Current small card pool means the faction you choose really limits your strategy (just a core theme, with variations on it), but this lowers the entry barrier, and makes deckbuilding a breeze. Factions help lend theme while simplifying the customization process, and cause the upgrade packs to be incremental changes (since 20 cards are split among 7 factions). Smart decisions everywhere. Looking forward to growing with the game.

[hr]
Warts that have emerged after hundreds and hundreds of mostly online plays, with a few tournaments thrown in:

[-] - The tournament scoring rules are flawed, biasing against certain deck-types and increasing the impact of luck. I say just do straight wins and losses (with 2 games against an opponent, if it's 1-1, so be it), and never any elimination rounds. The current flaw also magnifies the Corp/Runner imbalance (which I'd normally have no problem with).[/-] FFG listens to the fans! Still need to get rid of the system for elimination matches though: I favor tennis tiebreaker-style, keep alternating sides until one player wins 2 in a row.

 - Always the fundamental fact that a Runner can dig out of bad initial luck, but a Corp might just lose based on a poor initial draw.

 - As the card pool grows larger, Runner deckbuilding gets more and more fun, but Corp deckbuilding is a headache, since there's very little wiggle room after putting in your requisite agendas, Ice and economy (whereas the Runner never really needs to respect any sub-type constraints). I understand trimming A+B+C into A+B, but I hate have having to trim A+B+C+D synergy into just A.

 - The once-a-month incremental change helps nobody except FFG's coffers and marketing department. It'd be fine if the data packs were used to address issues with each iteration, but it appears that the cards are set well in advance. This means issues that leak out to the public take a long time to address (if at all), and the 'fix' might actually fix it too much. A big expansion every 3-4 months or so would do much better in terms of game balance and maximizing strategy space, plus foster deeper exploration (instead of, say, 1 tournament with each set of cards) and it'd be less overwhelming to have to update decks every month. On the FFG side, I suspect incremental changes are a bigger barrier to entry and keeping players than less often step changes (all the data packs do is just create buzz). I'd like some stability instead of just having 1-2 tournaments with each card-pool before it's on to the new cards, and constant tweaking again. This would've worked fine in the past when there weren't many good games around, but in this golden age of tabletop gaming, I don't have enough gaming opportunities to focus on keeping up with the monthly release schedule when there are so many other fine games that function perfectly without it, and so many others to experience.

Like any game involving bluffing, level 1 is getting ensnared, level 2 is anticipating and optimizing, level 3 is bluffing once again. Games are highly varied, and every 5 or so games, a new OMGWTF moment emerges. Even if no data pack is released anymore, the game is still a classic with unlimited replayability.

[hr]
Taking a sabbatical from this game, starting from Opening Moves (my previous one was during Humanity's Shadow). I hope Corp-Runner balance will be better when I return, the designers/developers will be less close-minded, silver-bullet cards like Jackson Howard, Datasucker and Plascrete Carapace become less common or are restricted/banned, and the distribution model can slow down.

...Currently downgrading my Netrunner collection to the bare minimum. Think I'll just play Draft and see what decks I can build out of my card-pool to teach newbies with. I only foresee maintaining decks to demo the game.

4+5

[color=gray][b]Favorite 2-player Short - Runner-up[/b][/color]
(Waiting for card release to slow down or hoping for draft format to be good, more potential and rated higher than favorite: Flash Duel)

RATING: 6.5
Ah, the sacred cow. And the most controversial of opinions - I neither love it or hate it, I find it okay, but nothing special. Theme implementation works, asymmetrical gameplay works (even if corporative side seems a bit more difficult to learn to play well), art is cute, everything comes together well and that's it. Card drawing mechanism feels clunky and dated and gives uneven feel to the game, the game could be more open to in game decisions (as opposed to deck building). When I compare this to Summoner Wars it's no contest - that is a tighter and deeper design, games are tenser and more involving. It seems that a lot of people are really nuts over the theme and art or asymmetrical gameplay, but I own Android, Cosmic Encounter and CitOW, so I fail to see what the big deal is. It is the best of FFG's LCGs though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[i]Fantastic Game with Limitless Potential Tarnished by Over Ambitious Release Schedule[/i]

This is a thrilling game and one of the best examples of asymmetrical gameplay that I know of.

Great design where the decision to give you a menu of actions, especially having control over the rate you draw cards, gives you a greater feeling of control than other similar games.

However, there are too many expansions for my tastes that release too quickly. Why this is bad for the game:

1) Bluffing is hurt when there are too many possibilities. When game was new you could reasonably expect what is in someones deck. As the game expands, not so much.

2) This games main advantage over its competitors is that your in-game decisions matter so much more. Just because you built a deck doesn't mean the gameplay mostly ends there; you now have to play it differently against different opponents or decks. The more cards that are added, however, the more likely you are to go into disadvantaged matchups or metagame decks -- in-game play starts to gradually take a backseat to deck building again.

3) I'd like more time to explore each format and delve in deep, but there is a shakeup every month.

In short, this is one of the best games ever made which is unfortunately (for players like me) such a cash-cow that it has no chance of ever slowing down. So rating is 10 for the game, which has some of the best gameplay ever, but LCG model gets a barely-passing grade from me

Also, if you consider only the core-set, the game does not feel as complete as advertised if you want a deep or balanced game. It's GREAT for what it REALLY is -- an intro into a system, rather than the standalone game option it claims to be (where it's still good but much less than that)

[b]I'd Rather Play:[/b] Yomi. Not as strategic as Netrunner, but has a lot of the tension, opponent-reading, and strategy without relying on "surprises" from not knowing opponent's deck. Netrunner is better for people who want constant shifts in the game, while Yomi is better for fixed-content play (no surprise there, since it was designed that way)

(5 Design + 4 Enjoyment)

buy: 28€
sell: 12€

RATING: 9
Bluffing, pressing your luck, spending action points... This game uses a lot of different game mechanics and executes them all well. The depth that this card game has is surprising. Though the rulebook makes the gameplay seem intimidating, it is relatively intuitive. It is also largely replayable due to the different match-ups between faction decks and the amount of card combinations available.

What makes this game unique is the asymmetrical gameplay. It creates a game of cat-and-mouse between the computer hackers (known in this universe as Runners) and the big corporations.

RATING: 8
[url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kEt3z-CEl-E]Dice Tower Reviews - Android: Netrunner[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Possibly the best competitive card game ever made. The action point system is designed so brilliantly that none of the common downsides with these kinds of games are present.

Need more cards? spend a click, draw a card. 

Need more credits? Spend a click for a credit.

"Tutoring," the act of an ability allowing you to search your deck for a specific card, is abundant in "Netrunner." This would be immensely overpowered in any other card game I can think of, but here it just allows you to counter play and build combos with ease, and since both players can do it, it works.

I love the game mechanically and thematically. The lone hacker vs an oppressive mega-corporation is prevalent in every card. So much so a game of "Netunner" can tell a story.

A hacker runs into a mysterious piece of ICE and trips a subroutine. The Weyland Corp. traces the intruder, and finds their approximate location within the city. Suddenly, outside the hacker's apartment window, the entire block explodes in in a fire-ball... Scorched Earth.

It can be played as casually or competitively as desired.

Fantasy Flight's LCG format also means there are no rare cards, you buy a pack you get a playset of every card. There's really not a better way to do it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I remember having Netrunner in the 90's.  I don't think I ever found anybody to play it with though, so my whole experience consisted of reading and rereading the cards.

RATING: 9
NetRunner is a not a game. NetRunner is a secret society. Unless a NetRunner has personally invited you, don't bother purchasing *the game*. 

Tough to learn, near-impossible to master. Once learned, the mechanics immerse players in the cybernoir theme. High-stress. The game-ending win condition can be triggered suddenly, sometimes surprising both players, hitting the loser like a shovel to the face. Best game ever. 

Among my peers, the game is a 10. However, it gets -1 for being extremely inaccessible to noobs. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Netrunner is the best. It is just the best, man. It has it all. Difficult tactical decisions. Bluffing and mind games. Luck in all the right places to keep the game exciting and tense. A deckbuilding aspect that is more about building a deck to suit your own playstyle than MtG-style ULTIMATE COMBOzz bullshit. And, unlike most other deckbuilding games in which 99% of the game is building the deck and then the actual game is just watching the deck play itself, deck construction in Netrunner is just one part of a multifaceted, interesting game.

RATING: 9
 Giving it a 9, because some of the cards and identities seem a lot more effective than others. I prefer being the runner over the corp anyday. Game play and strategy can be really different depending on the corp/runner combo. My husband is the only person I've played with so far and after over 20 plays, we're still not bored of it, but tensions do run high during the game, because it's a dueling game and if you're at all competitive, it can be INTENSE. 

I think the gameplay would be totally different if I wasn't always playing with the same person. I want to teach it to my gamer friends, but most are intimidated by the rule book and what they perceive to be a steep learning curve. Even after playing it for four months, I still have to look stuff up sometimes. I like the challenge, but it would be more interesting to play with different people! Overall, it's a solid game that I enjoy playing, particularly if I want a more cerebral, intense gaming experience. 

The only downfall is that it's a Living Card Game with lots of data packs, so if you're not keeping up with them, you are probably at a disadvantage when playing with others. It doesn't lend to casual game play.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This fills a nice little spot in my collection.  I probably like other two-player duel games better, for example Mage Wars and Diskwars but both of those take upwards of 2 hours to play and both are a little harder to get a new player up and running with.  This game takes probably around 30 minutes per play and isn't too terribly difficult to teach others.

The game is a completely asynchronous card duel.  One player plays a corporation who plays cards with the intent to score them and protect them with cards called Ice.  The corporation plays many of his cards face down and can do a lot of sneaky things this way.  The other player is the Runner, he is trying to steal the cards the corporation plays to score them for himself and otherwise disrupt the corporation player.  Both players have tons of different kinds of cards to augment their ability to do these things.

One thing I realized right away when playing this game though is that the more experience players have with this game the more it changes.  As I said, many of the corporation's cards are played face down and this can lead to some fun strategic options and surprises.  However the more a player knows about the cards and which cards are better and more frequently played and which cards are available to the different corporations the better the runner player can play to avoid those nasty surprises.  The same works the other way around too.  In my first play of this game I used a pretty popular card on my corporation opponent called Account Siphon.  In our second game the corporation player spent his first turn defending against specifically that card.

I'm not sure these changes are for the worse but it definitely changes how the game is played.  It becomes more about playing smart and strategically and less about the exciting "oh, shit!" moments.

I like the LCG model when comparing it to something like a CCG rather than another board/card game like Dominion.  Sure, they release a new deck of cards every month but those decks of cards are between 10-20 bucks and you get a full playset of all the cards released.  Only the base set doesn't give you a full playset of all the cards.  This is A LOT cheaper than keeping up with a CCG but the gameplay and deck building still feel very much like one which is great!

After a few more plays and getting into the deck building I don't like this game as much as I thought.  Everything I said above is still true and I do like the ease of entry, hidden card mechanics, and asynchronous gameplay.  However, each side only does a couple of things.  With all the extra content released for the game and hundreds of options available there are very few cards that do something new.  They all do variations on the same things and for that reason the game gets old pretty quickly.  And this is even more egregious BECAUSE of the amount of content they've released.  Also, the theme never really grabbed me.  I like scifi just fine but the art and flavor text on these cards along with the gameplay just don't get a fun science fiction theme across very well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Though I played the original I have absolutely no memory of what the game was like.

I have really enjoy playing this version though, and the management of the Corps assets, for both optimum effect AND bluffing the Runner is brilliant. There is a fantastic rhythm to the game with both sides needing to husband resources, with the runner needing to pick the weak spot and get the timing right.

Not enjoyed a CCG style game so much since the heyday of MTG. 13 games in and still very happy exploring the game through the core set decks. I will try some deck building but this will start in earnest when the expansions arrive

One small concern I have about my enjoyment of the game is that (and this might be my lack of a deep understanding of the game) is that it seems so be a money battle -  having the efficient attack/defense structure where it costs more for your opponent to acheive their goals than it does you or having a better money making machine. Out of the box I could never imagine not playing with 3 Hedge Funds/Sure Gambles (and i'd play with 6 if i could). Money feeds ice/breakers and agendas (and in deck building i'm looking for the most efficient) - so i need as much money as possible. My intuitive guess about what the corp is doing is based around their resources. I imagine expansions are going to flesh out the other parts of the game and I don't like the game, for starters. as this efficiency battle - but for it to be a keeper I hope that low income strategies will work in the future

About 20 games in and have tried some deckbuilding with core set - needs more cards as there are too many no brainers in the set.

RATING: 10
After playing this for a few months, I'm totally into it. The asymmetric play, the bluffing, the mind games... all of them combine to make this an incredible game that I always want to play more of. That's to say nothing of the awesome [url=https://killscreen.com/articles/why-netrunner-matters/]theme and world[/url], which are thoroughly baked into the cards and mechanics.

I love this game.

To be fair, teaching it is a little tough, especially when there's a huge skill differential between the teacher and the new player. I use [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/Netrunner/comments/1fvnpb/how_i_teach_netrunner/]this setup[/url] to teach the basics of the game, and then I try to go easy on new players or else secretly give myself extra challenges/handicaps in order to level the field a bit.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I was dubious about Netrunner at first. The game seemed limited in scope, as if the game designers would run out of design space after a couple of years. Fortunately, they've proven me wrong.

Netrunner is a testament to FFG's ability to take an existing game system, streamline it, give it good artwork, and keep a consistent flow of interesting cards coming.

The game has a great community and a diverse player base. It is undoubtedly the pre-eminent non-collectible card game in the world right now.

RATING: 8.5
:thumbsup: LIKE
+ Truly asymmetric role that plays really differently; one relying on bluffing and the other on push your luck
+ LCG model over the collectible one
+ Theme works great and is well integrated
+ Play time is just perfect at under an hour
+ Lots of value with 7 decks integrated in the base game

:thumbsdown: DISLIKE
- Good learning curve that's not helped by the crappy rulebook
- You need to play regularly and buy expansion to get into the deck building aspect of the game
- Card design could be a lot better

:star: VERDICT
Just wow! Feels like nothing out there. Replay value is through the roof and the play time means you can play lots of game back to back. Unfortunately, it needs a good time investment and extension buying to get into the deck building which I can't really afford.

RATING: 5
I think this is the very first CCG/LCG/TCG/xCG-style game I've ever played (nope, never tried Magic).  I still need to try out the Corporation side of things, but my initial verdict is that this isn't for me.  Admittedly, theme is important to me and I don't give two toots about the cyberpunk setting (I know pretty much nothing about cyberpunk other than I read the book "Snow Crash" and hated it - nope, never seen Bladerunner).  But the game play itself just feels like a grind: I try this, didn't work; I try this, worked a bit, now how do I get more money?; I try this, get some money; I try this, finally got something; now how do I get even more money?  Every stage of the game feels like the same slog, and there's really not much of a dynamic arc to the experience.  Other than that, the components are decently average, the artwork is sufficiently dull for the cyberpunk setting, everything is fairly functional.  One word of praise I do have to give the design is that on both sides of the table, there are several different factions which all have very different assortments of cards (yet, again, the actually game play doesn't feel all THAT different).  I'll continue to play the game because one of my best gaming friends enjoys it and as a result I do find enjoyment in playing it with that person, but left to my own devices I'd happily give it a pass.  Game design: 3.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 1.5/5  Total: 5/10

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Excellent, strongly-themed cyberpunk LCG, the first *CG I have played in a long time that does not cry out to be explained by comparison to its minor differences from Magic: the Gathering. For that alone I am impressed, though the rule changes from the original Netrunner seem to me to have taken it in quite the wrong direction.

One player is a corporation, whose hand, deck, discard pile and played cards are servers which the opponent, a "runner", wants to hack into. Many of the corp's cards are played face down, adding a strong bluffing element even if the contents of the deck are roughly known; played as intended (as a deck construction game) there is room for far more.

Much simpler than expected other than the use of confusing terminology -- but unlike many such games, the jargon really is justified and useful. The theme actually comes through in a way I have never experienced with this genre.

Unfortunately, also moreso than other deck construction games, I'm not sure it's worth playing without involvement in the construction metagame. My strong impression is that too much hinges on the bluffing, the doublethink and the mystery to get much mileage from the pre-constructed "starter" decks in the base game box. I'm not convinced it's worth keeping in my collection for the casual play it will receive, but if I were to pursue CCG-style play with any game it would be with this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

Play really does develop well, and the game balance seems quite good. The base deck is more than enough for any player looking to get a good amount of play out of this, so I don't feel the need to rush out and buy another box set and all of the expansions - I'm quite happy with what I've got. With a bunch of corps and runners there is plenty to do.

As for gameplay the flow is tense, and exciting, the bluffs work better than I'd both expected and even hoped for. This doesn't feel like an old game at all, and just shows how forward thinking this idea was when first conceived.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Seems decent from my few plays but it won't get enough table time and relearning the cards every few months does not make for a fun time.  Not the right fit for me.
--
Played it a fair bit more. I love the art and theme. I like how thematically it all makes sense. But then it all falls apart. All this theme in the design makes it all just a little too complicated. There are too many different types of card, too much structure and too many factions. Imho flexibility of design should be a core consideration when making a L/CCG but here they've gone for something very structured and much to its detriment. The one advantage it does offer though is easier deckbuilding for beginners. 

The pre-constructed decks are abysmal. I'm not sure they could have made worse decks for learning. Once you've built something worth playing with, then a few more problems arise. First is the bad shuffle and/or the runner was lucky and grabbed half of the Agenda's needed to win on the the first turn. The second is that if a runner miscalculates when or what to run at the game can instantly end. Experienced play alleviates the latter but it creates a horrific learning curve.

As for the gameplay itself. I've never been a fan of action points for card games.  How to explain it? I suppose that the actions don't really feel like actions. They feel like micro-actions most of the time. Sure occasionally your get a turn when you do multiple runs or can quickly advance a card but the majority are preparation work for the interesting parts and guess what, preparation isn't all the interesting. Other downsides are the ridiculous amount of card interactions that can occur during a run. I'm guessing this is just part and parcel of the LCG format but it seems pretty silly.

I have other concerns as well. 
-The rulebook follows FFG normal format which means it's absolutely fucking terrible as a reference and only okay to learn with when you read it straight through.
-Tons of cards have text that indicate a type of ice/icebreaker that doesn't yet exist. Is this fluff or are those coming in the future? As a beginner it was confusing. 
-The game doesn't lend itself to limited formats due to the aforementioned complex design. This is an egregious offense in light of the LCG format as it essentially requires complete collections. In fact I'd argue that this makes it worse than CCGs.
-I can't get anyone else to play it

So what are we left with? A game in severe need of streamlining designed to keep hardcore players spending money. As a game for casualy players, sure there's plenty of play in the box but it's not very good.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really enjoyed playing it for the first 3-4 cycles and the deluxe expansion up to Data and Destiny. The core gameplay of the game is definitely pretty high up in the mind games/interactivity for me. But the design decisions and various meta game degeneration eventually turned me and my friends away from the game. 

But hey, the good news is I met and became friends with a diverse bunch of gents who are awesome buddies to hang out with. 

I'm seriously considering turning my collection into a cube or perhaps some pre-setup decks to play with people.

The bluffing/poker aspects of the game is the most intriguing mechanic for me, that and the action points to govern actions in the game. 

Not to mention the asymmetric aspects of the 2 players each playing totally different decks (corp vs runner) each with their various IDs that define their play-style and card pool, and between the corp and runner, the winning condition of the game existing only inside the corp's deck and the runner has to attempt to steal that. This just ooze that hacker vs corporation theme and mechanically is just amazing.

All these mechanics were sadly marred by an era of bad card design, which quite likely killed quite a bit of the player base. I'm sure there are people playing it still but for me and my gang we can't really go back to it. Sometimes I do wonder if the basic mechanic structure of the game can be made into a team-based or multiplayer style game. 

We've also seen the light with regards to the LCG model as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Pros: Highly strategic which is typically a huge plus. Innovative theme.

Cons: Top of deck plays a factor, so some luck involved. Very complex.

Final thoughts: Fun two-player game. Just too heavy for a lot of people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played this game only with "Mac" vs Jinteki and vice versa (which was in both cases a lather lopsided deal) but we had great fun and could see the potential of this game. Expect this to get better with replay, and of course, get really better with more variability.

However, with all such games it is the question to either sink in or stay out. I will keep my base set for now for the occasional good rump, but Mage Wars keeps being my favorite 2p LCG as of now.

About the game itself: the wonderful asymetric gameplay, the deckbuilding aspect and the overal hand/action management make it a very good game. The tension resulting form the flow of the game is what makes it great. As the Corporation, you never know when you will be visited by some pesky runner. So you have to weigh your options very carefully, bluffing your way out sometimes. As the Runner, gameplay is easier but you have to set the moment to run. You decide when to run. Not the Corporation. Which gives you a big advantage. However, it is up to you to fully utilize that advantage and not let yourself get caught by some unexpected Ice and/or event cards following your Run (especially when traced), but also not have your decision 'where to run' guided by the Corporation. And that is where the bluffing element comes in. 

You'll find yourself thinking:
"Is that remote server easy bait on purpose? And if so, is it not that I should think that it is a trap? Surely he wouldn't put a juicy agenda there. Or is that what he wants me to think? Running against the deck then? Hmm. Heavily protected. Or at least, it seems. Perhaps that one Ice is simply way better than this whole row at R&D." 

Choices, choices.

That is what makes Netrunner great. I wonder however if not every expansion will simply shift the metagame to favorite another 'strongest build'. Of course, there are always counters to a strong build, but then you are tailoring your deck to your opponent's instead of going from your own strengths. Ah well, maybe my perception is simply skewed because of the Jinteki underpowered experience from the base game.

This game will get replayed. Will not buy in yet though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I loved it the first few times I played. I want some more plays before I pass judgment. The system here is impeccable. My concern is that the base set might be too sparing in the flavor it allots to the various factions as well as in the tactical opportunities provided by the set. I understand Fantasy Flight are trying to create a new wing for their Android franchise, but I'm worried that they might have been too stingy between the flimsy quality of the cards, the $15-for-3-each-of-20-cards expansions and the tactical limitations of the starter set. I feel like I've been sold only part of a game for a full $40 price tag, and I'm really hoping that more plays prove me wrong. Had I waited a few weeks, I could have paid $26 and felt much better about the purchase. Again, we'll see.

Edit: Expansions were not tightly designed at all and further play has confirmed my worries about the base set. Still mechanically sound and an excellent, if incomplete and awkwardly expanded card game. They focused on providing deck builders a meta game rather than provide players a better game--and the result is a weaker game with deck-builders content enough with the meta-game not to notice.

RATING: 8
It's a bit long to play, but this is my favorite living card game. Oh boy. It's beautiful, it's solid, it's challenging and now it's improved through the LCG format and some rule updates.
There's a level of bluffing, of strategy and what I love is that no matter how good your deck is, the player's choices and strategies are what really makes a difference in a game. 
In addition to that, the completely asymmetrical play style between runner and corp is very interesting, each with different play styles and goals. Great game!

RATING: 7
The most strategic, best designed of any CCG/TCG ever made.  Unlimited replayability.  Great diversity in deck design.  Amazingly good at maintaining thematic integrity.  Great artwork.  Suffers very slightly from some fiddly rules and card interaction rulings that don't quite follow logic, but that's a fairly common occurrence in FFG's LCGs.
Update - dropped from 8 to 7 due to the addition of cards from recent expansions that add some disappointing effects that just seem out of place but, unfortunately, are cards necessary in a deck for competitive play.

RATING: 7

RATING: 4
First play: 20 minutes of teaching and then on the first run into R&D, I hit a snare. Lose all my cards; game over.

We pretend that card didn't happen, put it to one side and carry on.

Later, in 2 runs at R&D, I pull 2 agendas back to back, I'm now 5-0 up and the other player basically has no chance at this point. All essentially just luck of the draw.

Essentially, this is another typical FFG game for me: lots of artwork, lots of stupid cards that I need to be able to read upside down from across the table, very few meaningful decisions (hmm, I can run freely at that pile, or try that heavily protected one; let's play this card and see if it's worth it - nope, it's a bluff), every time I play a card in to my display, I then have to check the other 8 cards to see if they do something, oh and lots of jargon that 'adds' theme, but makes it largely incomprehensible.

It's like an A-Z of bad game design. Poor. Even by FFG standards.

RATING: 5
So this is the same game we used to have a long time ago, but it's been updated.  And it's no longer a CCG, which was my main problem with it the last time I played it.

It's a good game.  Fun, entertaining, fairly inexpensive for the amount of game you get in the box.  If you're going to play a CCG Game, I suppose this is one of the better ones to get into.  It has the benefit of being very different based on which side you're playing, and you have to build two decks instead of just one, so there's a lot to explore.  

However, playing the game requires constant updates, and keeping up, and just not something I have the time and energy for, I'm out.

RATING: N/A
2 copies
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Netrunner is a good strategic 1v1 card game. I enjoy its asymmetry and the interactions among the rules and among the cards. (And the flavor's nice too, I guess. :P) However, I am hesitant to invest the money or the time it would take to introduce more variety or competitiveness to it. In particular I would expect to acquire three more small data packs to reach an adequate level of variety/power across all factions, or one small and one large data pack for a specific Corp or Runner faction.

If you shied away from Magic: The Gathering for mechanical, thematic, or balance considerations, I would encourage you to give Netrunner a try. If for deck-building reasons, Netrunner might still resolve them if your primary issue was having to choose to purchase specific good singles or to buy the booster packs at risk of randomness. (A lot of people say you can build with just the core and still be content; I'm not convinced of this, as the options seem rather limited even with cross-faction imports.)

There are fan-made variants for arbitrarily many Corp-Runner pairs (Big Sellout) and Corp v 3 Runners.

RATING: 8
So far so good. I enjoy the asymmetrical play and tactical feel of each turn. In my limited experience with the game so far, I am still having trouble getting a decent money engine going. We are all just stumbling around a bit, experimenting with different ICE, programs, and combinations. I also wonder if Fantasy Flight's starter decks wouldn't benefit from expansion and customization. I look forward to building my own decks and digging into this game.

Update: After some expansion and many additional plays, I enjoy this game more and more. The deck-building experience is one I didn't know I was missing since my day of playing Magic. Having to manage the strategy from both sides, corp and runner, adds complications and variety. This is a very solid game.

Another update: The problem I'm running into is that most opponent around here are way more serious about the game than I am: tournaments, in-depth discussion of strategy and card combinations, etc. I'm looking for casual play, but the nature of the game pushes people towards the other end of the spectrum.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

But mainly I've been put off by a few bad experiences, where the players (especially the corp) draw all the wrong cards at the wrong times, and end up being entirely defenceless. I know this game couldn't possibly have been scored as highly as it has if it all comes down to the luck of the draw; but that's certainly been my experience of it so far.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Ratings-wise, this appears to be the most beloved of the Fantasy Flight living card games, but I think I like several of the other titles in the line (like Warhammer Invasion, Lord of the Rings: The Card Game and Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game) better. The asymmetrical design is kind of nifty, but I think the deck-building aspect of Netrunner is far more important than in the other LCGs and achieving balance between the very different runner and corporation decks can be difficult, leading to some lopsided games. With some of the other Fantasy Flight LCG's quickly cobbling together two decks of relatively equal power is pretty easy. That ease of casual deck-building is missing in Netrunner. On the plus side, the game is deep and interesting. But I don't think I'm going to play it often enough to get beyond the casual experience, so Netrunner will never shine for me as it does to diehard fans.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I'm not a huge card game player.  I will admit I find Magic to be a good game, although I only ever play it with my friends spare decks because I am not into having to constantly upgrade my decks and re-tweak.  Android: Netrunner has a similar gameplay style without the need to constantly buy new cards etc, while at the same time has variety in the characters/corporations you play with so it's not always the same 1 to 1 matchup.  The game is fun, and thematically feels like you're trying to hack, or stop a hacker.

RATING: 6.5
This one will definitely get more chances as we played it horribly wrong (which isn't too difficult with all the errata and FAQs), so the rating is very preliminary. Currently I'd rate the game as a 9 for the netrunner and a 5 for the megacorporation. The netrunner makes all the action, setting the stage for his virtual jabs whereas the megacorporation just sits and waits (turtles). If you want to put it positively, the megacorp plans its next sinister moves and gets the kicks watching the runner being ensnared in the traps it has set. But really when it comes to fun, go for the runner.
Now I just can't give a middle 7, when odds are quite high a play style is forced upon me, I do not gain much pleasure out of. I guess, I'll just have to make the megacorps palatable to new players. Other than that the game comes with the outstanding art which has become standard for any FFg Games and has a very interesting concept. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I thought that this would increase from 8 the more I played it, but to be honest I like the game less and less every time I play. I'm really regretting buying in, and just hope that I can get a decent amount for my collection.

RATING: 4
I have a threshold for CCGs based on complexity of deck building... The more complicated it is, the more I like it UNTIL a certain threshold, at which poinit becomes so complex it becomes a chore. Netrunner is so complicated it started at that point of highly engaging, but became chore like and unenjoyable after, like, two major expansions. The game is brutally competitive in terms of rewarding good play. It sounds good, but it means the best player wins so consistently, you should expect to never win against your betters... Depending how you rank in your play group, this may mean it's no fun because you always lose, or no one want to play you because you always win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I adore the original Netrunner -- and I'm one of the lucky few to have a halfway decent collection (enough for six very playable decks.)  So I was hesitant as to whether or not I'd want to take the plunge on the reboot.

Well, now I've held it, and played it.  And the answer is yes, I want it.  I love the Android universe, and there's a lot of fun, original card ideas in here that made me smile. Will I get suckered into buying all the expansions?  Gosh.  Time will tell.

The only thing that's bothering me so far is the format.  At this point in time (and for my foreseeable future) there won't be a lot of surprises.  Haas-Bioroid will have the same ICE every game, Anarchs will have the same breakers....I doubt enough of my friends will get into the deckbuilding aspect.

EDIT: And now I have it -- thanks, Justin!  The fact that I have received it as a gift makes it much more likely that I'll end up buying expansions.  Wish I had a FLGS!

EDIT: I have no interest in buying any expansions, and most of my friends didn't really go for this.  So as it stands, there's fun to be had here, but without plunging into the whole LCG lifestyle I'm not likely to get much mileage out of the base game.  I'll probably just stick with the old Netrunner, for which I have hundreds more cards, and just feel like a curmudgeonly old hipster.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Really awesome expandable card game. My first attempt at one of FFG's living card games was A Game of Thrones and it was very disappointing. It didn't work very well for two players, the rules were badly written and left out a lot of information, and you needed to buy at least two copies of the game just to make it work. Ridiculous.

So I was a little worried about trying this game. So far, though, it has been fantastic. The deck-building is simple and you only have to do as much as you want to do (creating a simple deck just involves combining all the neutral cards with all of a faction's cards) and the game is very replayable right out of the box, without the need to buy a bunch of extra stuff.

Update: Still love this game. There have been about eight data packs and one bigger expansion so far, and the game is still excellent. I was a little worried that the game would be changed too much by that many expansions, but the core gameplay is still pretty much the same, with the extra cards just adding a lot of variety and different strategies. Probably my favorite card game of all time.

RATING: 6
What a cool game. I've probably spent more time thinking about it than I have playing it. I really appreciate how having a top-tier deck doesn't mean auto-winning. You have to be able to bluff and call bluffs, learn how to manage your hand, and always be prepared for the worst. The game is very tense, and there's so many cool ways to trick your opponent or get the upper hand. 

On the other hand, Netrunner requires a huge time investment outside of the game. To get the most out of it, you have to constantly tweak decks, follow the meta, etc. I don't mind a bit of customization, but Netrunner is better suited as a lifestyle game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very interesting 2p game, one of the best for 1vs1 aggressive gameplay.

The difference in roles (runners vs corps) is extreme, and the different factions also vary extremelly well. The actual gameplay is engaging, fun and agonising, and the bluffing element is supreme. The core gameplay is extremelly free, which lets the players fully develop their strategies without bothering with unecessary phase details, and the fact that the game works in such a free way is a testament of its supreme design. The deckbuilding aspect is intriguing.

The economy of the game is simple and boring compared to the bluffing element, and the cards that bother with it seem to be there just for the sake of more cards, even if they do make a difference in victory or defeat. The base factions are not very well balanced in the core set, though this is a minor issue in a game that encoureges deck-building. The LCG model is also a money eating problem in competitive games.

Overall, it is a great 2p game but it didn't inspire me to the level I thought it would (the problem of great expectations.) Despite that, it is a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
So I'm probably going to have a very different take on this one than most folks who enjoy it. 

What I like: 
-The core gameset! Holy crap is this value for money! So many different factions on both, totally different sides! I was blown away by this. 
-The fact that the gameplay of the two sides are completely different
-Massive replay value and if you want more you can go out and get even more cards
-Lovely mix of bluffing, gambling, playing smart and interesting decisions
-Looks good

What I do not like
-The deck building when purchasing more cards. I do not recommend if you aren't in it to play competitively. I have tried this quite a bit, and it's okay fun, but some of the combos you can make are just ridiculous. With all these different user created decks, sometimes you just face decks that absolutely hard counter yours making this particular game session uninteresting as there is now nothing you can do in the actual game to win. Yeah you can change your deck, but then something else is going to ruin you. To me it is also too much "setting up game/decks" versus actual playing time. Also it gets too expensive and is no longer the amazing value for money that the core set is. 

All in all: I love this!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A very good asymmetrical card game. I'm a big fan of the living card game model compared to collectable card games, even if it does eliminate the rush of opening a rare/valuable card.

This game might be a bit difficult to pick up for someone who hasn't played CCGs before, but players familiar with games like Magic shouldn't have much trouble learning it.

I really like the asymmetrical nature of the two sides in this game. In addition to different mechanics, the two sides encourage different "out of game" skills, such as being deceptive in the case of the Corporation and knowing when to be aggressive in the case of the Runner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[thing=124742][/thing] is two players a game in which one plays with the runners trying to expose the dirty dealings of the corporations, the side which is played by the other player. The goal for the corporation is to advance its agendas, while the runners want to find them and take them (to use as evidence, I guess), and there are four places in which they can try to do this:
- the headquarters (the hand of cards of the corps player);
- the database (the corps deck);
- the archives (the discard pile);
- and in the search and development (the area in front of the corps player).

Each of these "places" can be proteced by ice - barriers or traps of some kind, putted there to stop the runs. Beside this, the corp can put other traps disguise as agendas, since the ice and agendas go face down in the table - so the game has this bluff element to it. To face this things, the runners have their own tools and ways to play.

Is in this assimetrical way that the game goes on. The actions for each side has similarities, but the deck can be totally different - this is a LCG, after all.

I enjoyed the way the game handles the spatial play area, making everything a point of attention: the discard, the deck, the hand, not only the area in front of the player, which is the norm. Really smart!

So [thing=124742][/thing] is a good game, one that I'm willing to try more times, though certainly won't enter into the madness that it has become! I hope, at least.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
The jargon is rather annoying and the text on some of the cards is a bit opaque at times. Why call a hand of cards a deck, and the discard pile the archive? It's unnecessary when simple clear language would have worked better. As far as I can see the only justification is to try and shoehorn a paper thin theme onto the card game. The game itself is fiddly, utterly inelegant and let down by a poorly written rulebook. 

Having said all of that though, once you're past the nomenclature barrier, it is fast and fun. I just don't think that's enough in an overcrowded collection of games. There are many more interesting and enjoyable games to be played which don't require the large investment of time and effort to learn. 

Sold my copy, unfortunately in the end it came down to the use of annoying terms when simpler language would suffice was probably the straw that broke the camel's back.

RATING: 8.5
If theme is what you like, there is no way this game can disappoint. From  game design to extensive card descriptions, Android is incredibly immersive. It's asymmetrical game play also makes it very unique. Never thought a cyberpunk futuristic dystopia was a setting I'd enjoy so much. Go figure. 

Warning -- getting through the rules can be taxing at first, and then bordering on annoying by the end. The cards also have extensive descriptions so game play can be slow while players are making their decisions. Play only when you have ample time on your hands.

RATING: 8
Believe the hype! I see a feeding frenzy at Gen Con 2012 over Netrunner. I see it is rocketing up the BGG charts. I look at a few of the videos and reviews and it looks like it might be fun. Not on the top of my wish list and I'm not a fan of constructing decks. But I have received a gift card to my FLGS and use it to buy the game. 

After a few plays, Netrunner is all I want to play and there are plenty of opponents available. This game is intense. It is surprisingly easy to learn and I like that you have to play your opponent as well as your cards. Very much like poker or launching / repelling an invasion in a war game.

RATING: 9
I have played this game since its FFG release in 2012, and still love it. This was also my first introduction to the LCG model, which I have found to be a big improvement over the old days of MtG, or Decipher's Star Trek TNG CCG. 

It has been a rocky road at times, but with the game's third lead designer completing the rollout of the revised core set, a removed/restricted list and the latest MWL the game has been much improved. We all survived the first rotation, and are enjoying the most recent cycle of new cards. The deck-building aspect is challenging but exciting, and there's nothing better than assembling a combo for a strong play.

Will probably play this game until its gone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Never played Magic. Didn't really care for it. 

Played the Pokemon CCG, but when I say play, I mean collected (kid with pocket money and obsessions, fool I was).

Netrunner however, is in a league of it's own. I don't own or play any other LCG/CCG-model games so I can't compare it to the other heavy hitters like L5R or... um... my point exactly. When I say league of it's own I am talking about the game experience itself, not it's business model or it's theme or even mechanisms. 

This game is one of the most satisfying things I can do with my time, should I choose to play a game. Whether it lasts 10 minutes or 50, win or lose, I can always find peace and satisfaction within the experience. 

You are truly allowed to express yourself in the way you play, not just in how you build your deck and the rules you like to bend with your card choices but at the table and how you look your opponent in the eye and declare with a quiver "I'm going to install this card here...", trying to convey both the truth and a lie at the same time. Or as the runner, staring grimly at the increasing walls of ice in front of you blocking you from your goals, your mind races between the decisions, weighing your risks and rewards until finally you decide it's time to reveal that card from your hand that you have had since the beginning. It's time to run on the big one. It's time to get stupid.

The caveat here is you really need to play with people you like. Some people build annoying decks that will rub you the wrong way and they WILL sit smugly across from you and drink your rage like a fine wine, but most of all this game is truly an intimate experience between two people because of the nature of preparation that goes into it. Onlookers can do little but look on in silent awe as a game unfolds as the Magic Circle in this realm only has two seats. 
Play with your friends, play with people in your game group, play competitively if you want to but be WARNED. This game is deep and serious. It is intricate and vastly convoluted. It is not complicated to understand and it is not detached from it's theme in a way that makes the game mechanisms jarring to learn (quite the opposite in fact!), it will take time and many, many games before you understand how to weigh your options correctly (and even then there is always a generous helping of "listen to your heart" decisions), you will also need to build a number of different decks before you see how they fit together in a way you like.
In short, the barrier to entry is very high. Which brings me to my rating. This game is a faux-10 for me. It has all the qualities of a perfect game, but the lacking quality may just be me... Allow me to ramble:

The game cannot score a 10 because of how it grows. I will not always be around to pick up the next data pack or deluxe expansion. I will not always have the time to read over every card and be aware that the rules can now be bent in that way. This is not a detriment to the game, in fact it is incredible that the game continues to grow and thrive. It is amazing that there will be new styles of play and new tricks and secrets to tuck away into a deck and unleash on some poor soul who thought that "today seems like a good day to start a nice little mega-corp". This only means that the Netrunner that I know and love will not always be there. It will not always be the Netrunner that is being played in stores and tournaments, and talked about across various ports of the interwebs.
The Netrunner I rate a 10 is already dead. It shed it's perfect outer layer and has been happily living as a 9. It will do so for some time, I imagine, until another game is able to capture this feeling for me.

This feeling. 

This game has a unique feeling that is separate from the satisfaction of being a walking lexicon of card effects. It is more than the fluid execution of a well-crafted deck, or the elated victory found at the bottom of a well-guarded server. It surpasses these things and becomes something more. You FEEL like a cyber-punk runner, geared to the teeth with hardware build for all occasions, your mind buzzing with access codes to software installed across a myriad of devices as your terminal light washes you with a pale white glow. You receive a call from your associate, the goods have arrived, tonight is the night, you may only have one chance to get past that wall while the filthy corp only has chump change to spare on rezzing half-assed ice you know you could break with basic algorithmic execution. 

This game is reaching a zenith for me, it will begin to set on my life and I would encourage anyone interested to jump in before... oh I dunno... the end of 2015? By then the barrier to entry should bar out almost all but the most committed, the ones who were late to the party and don't mind playing catch-ups. For the rest. Get in now before the corp puts up the next wall of ice and you find yourself short on the time and the creds needed to get what you really want..
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
