=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
First a disclaimer: I know I am not the targeted audience for LCCs', but I was intrigued at the hype for Netrunner. The game concept and theme is very well developed. The terminology for the game, while tough for a newbie to parse and digest, is nevertheless extremely thematic and bursting with flavor. ICE, agendas, main frame, subroutines....etc. everything makes so much sense taken in the context of the game and actions. Heck, "meat" damage sounds so alluring.

My two plays were mediocre at best. The one thing about all LCCs in general is the amount of time and energy that is invested in learning to play the game and playing it well. Even for the core game without any expansions, the variety is astounding. However, multiple plays are required for any two players to appreciate the game design. Therein lies the biggest issue for me: I just don't have the time nor energy to invest in multiple game plays. Hence, I am not the target audience. I find that the runner breaking through the barriers installed by the corporation to be really cool, but boils down to dumb luck as to which card is drawn. An agenda scores you points. Anything else is a waste of time. Each run can cost multiple credits and these hard earned credits can result in a spectacular bust. Toward the latter half of the game, I felt that each turn boils down to earning credits either to setup a run or to score agendas.

Not my cup of tea but I can appreciate the game design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is damn near perfect. 50+ games in and I'm really starting to accept and like the game for what it is, which is by and large a bluffing game with a small amount of deck building. My initial issue was that I approached the game with those last two reversed, and got my hopes repeatedly crushed as wins and losses came down to much more luck than I was expecting.

That said, now that I've had this many games to really explore how the game works, I've come to accept how the strategy/luck balance plays out and have adjusted my expectations accordingly. The amount of effort deckbuilding requires vs. how easy it is for games to come down to a coin flip still bothers me, but the variety of the card pool keeps me coming back for more.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
This was really fun when it came out. Exploring it was great and it was quite the adventure. After a bad experience with the local community around here, I ended up falling out of the scene.

I did end up trying some new decks after a few more data packs came out. I didn't realise Netrunner had changed so much! It felt like a completely different beast and not for the better.

This game highlighted a serious flaw of the LCG model. While it's definitely nice to be able to get access to all the cards without having to chase cards on the secondary market, the fact that the packs simply do not add enough cards to influence the metagame is a serious flaw. 

Not only this, but without rotation, the metagame ends up getting stale without substantial deck innovation. I'm not sure how Netrunner ended up the way it is now, but it was definitely way more enjoyable when it first came out. It's now become a combo heavy field, with no end in sight.

Update 6/11/14: Looks like I called it? FFG just announced a rotation policy for their LCGs. I wonder if there will be any backlash considering the fact you now have to constantly buy cards like a CCG. After finding out about the details, the rotation policy seems half baked. Not too sure why the big boxes don't rotate too, nor why the rotation is so far apart. This is still going to have all the issues I raised, and with every additional big box addition, it's just going to add to the bloat.

Update 9/11/14: Looks like the backlash is here.

Update 8/07/15: I'm never going to play this game ever again, so the updated rating reflects that. The fact that rotation is so slow and that the number of cards added has either too much impact or no impact at all is a downside in my eyes. The cost is a huge issue too, irrespective of the LCG model.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great asymmetrical card game.  Complicated to learn but really rewarding when you pull off some feints.

Bluffing is an important part of the game which is brilliant, unfortunately so can luck when you start off playing - especially with some "insta win" combos in the base set.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Brand new
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Big props to FFG for listening to the community and going through the trouble to license and reprint this fantastic game. The 1996 original was [i]way[/i] ahead of its time, with fascinating asymmetry and a ton of bluffing and psychology. The main obstacle to playing it was availability, compounded by the loopy deckbuilding rules for constructed play that allowed unlimited copies of a single card. In recreating NR as an LCG, FFG neatly solved both of those problems. The result preserves 99% of what made the original NR great while finally making the game accessible to non-fanatics. The minor mechanical differences are irrelevant IMO, just different takes on the same idea. I do agree with the criticism that the reboot lacks some of the charm of the original's art and flavor text, which was quirky in the way that games often used to be before they became such a well-defined industry. However, the FFG aesthetics are fine - a bit slick and manufactured, but not so much so that they detract from the game.

All that being said, A:NR is still not a game for everybody. Many of the mechanics are unique, and the asymmetric gameplay makes it impossible for new players to learn the game simply by copying his opponent's moves. The game takes a little patience and some genuine interest to get into. The core set helps with that by providing an excellent out-of-the-box experience with the premade factions. But still... this is much more of a gamer's game than simple MtG decks provide.

Finally, while the core set is clearly looking ahead to the expansion packs and serious constructed play, I think there's plenty of value here even without buying anything else. With so much of the gameplay dependent on bluffing and hidden information, you can easily play just the basic Shaper/Jinteki matchup numerous times. Add in the other faction match-ups, tweak a few cards through the deckbuilding rules, and you've got more than enough gameplay here to justify the cost. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
x2 Blue and red rubber playing mats - $40 value.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A beautiful game where mechanics and theme are intertwined through and through. You play this game. You pilot your deck. The deck does NOT play you. 

Didn't draw the card you wanted? Just use an action to draw up. Don't have resources? Use actions to get them. Analyze the board. Make your move. 

No boosters. No expensive decks. You can probably own most or all of the cards for less then the highest tier Magic decks, and that's for EVERY card with 3 copies. 

There is ONE problem, though- the Core Set. Though it is great to get into the game, it is a bain for competitive players. You have to buy about 2 or 3 because the Core Set only contains 1-ofs of certain important cards.

It's a problem, but that doesn't stop Netrunner from being my favorite card game of all time. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This game is really hard for me to rate.

RATING: 8.5
2-player asymmetrical card game: cyberpunk hackers trying to steal data and resources from online mega-corporations. The list of potential cards to include in your deck grows continually, but does not require purchase of random card packs. Instead, the game expands with fixed card packs on a regular basis. Best for players dedicated to repeat plays of the same game.

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
I miss the darker, goofier art from the original, but the world here is more cohesive, and benefits from a universe that is used outside this particular game, notably in the original [gameid=39339] boardgame and even some novels.  The gameplay here is crisp, and the deckbuilding is good.  the thing is, I find myself less enthused with every play.  The only way you're going to get interest out of this game is by going into deck-building with this game, and that's going to require a heavy investment in new cards.  It may be an LCG, meaning that you can be guaranteed to get all the cards by buying certain packages, but that doesn't really fix the fact that you still have to buy a ton of product.

RATING: 7
This game is awesome. The only CCG I enjoy more is the old Star Wars CCG created by Decipher. The main knock is that it's too complex and intense. And it can certainly be that way, no doubt. The game and the community have a huge competitive slant. I'm not much of a fan of that, so I take measures to keep it light-hearted, like limiting the card pool available to build decks from.

Regardless though, this is one of the coolest games I have ever played. The ideas, the application of theme, the production, the art, etc. is all top-notch.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Netrunner is a fantastic asymmetrical game between a Runner "Hacker" and Mega Corporations "Corps". The back and forth between the Runner and the Corp starts as soon as the game does. Lots of bluffing on both sides with interesting game play on either side.
With the LCG format more and more cards are being introduced to the Meta allowing for customized deck building and increasing the variety from match to match. 
The Artwork and lots of flavor text on the cards really captures the dystopian "Cyberpunk" future. 
FFG has really modernized this title and brought it back much better than before.

RATING: 8
*** PERMANENT PLACE IN COLLECTION

UPDATE: We realised Jinteki was weak and Jon preferred playing the runner. After six plays, I really like this game - it isn't just bluffing. Jon remains to be convinced. He thinks it's a decent game but nowhere like a perfect 10.

UPDATE: After four plays, I'd rather play BattleCON or Yomi for advanced bluffing with combat. The unexpanded base pack has less depth and I think it depends heavily on deck-building. The appeal seems to be theme.

Massively impressed after two plays. It's like playing Magic the Gathering where the only colour is blue and it's developed to the hilt. Loads of control, mind games and bluffing.

The starter kit feels a bit thin, even after two plays. I could do with some more cool cards, I think.

RATING: 6
I never played the original Netrunner, so I don't know how this version compares to it (other than it being non-collectible), but I like the way it works.  The asymmetrical play is a big draw, and I haven't played enough of it yet to get a good feel for how balanced it is, and I like that the theme of the game works with the mechanisms.  It's a helpful reminder for how the game flows, and pretty cool, to boot.  It's been a long time since I've played any CCG-ish game, and this one is different enough that it doesn't feel much like one, so I imagine it will be a while before I get around to the deck-building elements of the game.  For now, though, I'm intrigued.

1 play: 2 players

RATING: 10
A-Z
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There are a lot of things I like about the game: Interaction is very high, and there is an appropriate mixture of luck and strategy. The rules and strategies are easy enough, that no analysis paralysis is to be feared, and the playtime is very moderate. Since I am married to a gamer, two player games are always very welcome with me. Just ask my husband and on it goes. :-)

Wonderful artwork and the theme is likeable, too. The very distinct mechanisms for the two opponents is fun and adds to the replay value - along with the fractions and light deck building integrated into the core game. I am no fan of extensive deck building. I prefer the actual playing over the planning and strategising just with the rules and probabilities. Fortunately with LCG I can easily avoid that. I just don't buy any extensions - maybe one later when the desire for more variety awakes.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The original Netrunner had a serious cult following and Fantasy Flight's re-imagining of the classic game has shown everyone just why that happened. The game's mechanisms convey the theme extremely well and playing feels like you are engaged in a hacker vs. internet security cyber-war. Not only that, but the gameplay features loads of bluffing and allows you to actually play your opponent, not just his online crafted netdeck. Skill wins out, almost every time.

So what's different about Netrunner? Most of what you know about deck construction doesn't apply in this game. Often times it can be beneficial to build a tool box of one-offs as opposed to multiple copies of power cards. If you run into a deck that features a combo that you aren't equipped for...YOU CAN STILL WIN! You can bluff, misdirect and steal a victory anyway. Which is precisely why this game has such a stellar reputation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
LOVE the theme (used to have the original CCG version).. unfortunately it's only 2 players...and it's a pain to explain the rules, esp. to those not computer literate  :>

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
3 core sets and all expansions and data packs
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very similar to the original, which is good in that there wasn't very much wrong with the original - but still a missed opportunity to reduce the game length and/or streamline some of the more needlessly complex bits (there are a LOT of rules, and it seems like they could be condensed a little without significantly narrowing the decision tree). I like the theme, but the art and flavor are still a bit of a turn-off - again, like the original. I'm not totally sold on the LCG model being significantly better than CCGs - though at least you can buy a single box and have some customization options for lots of casual games, which is more than you can say about most CCGs.

But overall, it's one of the better card games I've played. I'd definitely recommend anyone try it if they aren't afraid of a learning curve or a little time investment outside of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Utterly fantastic. My new go-to for 1v1 card games. The game manages to hit that remarkable ability to be a card game that isn't all about luck and deckbuilding, but actually game play and interaction between the players. And unlike previous LCG games I've played in the past, the Core Set has enough cards for intelligent deck building and enough variety to keep the game fresh for a long time. Anyone who likes to play competitive card games should give this game a try it is phenomenal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I used to love this game, but I got burned out on it.  It was the psi games (essentially a rock-paper-scissors minima) that ruined it for me.  I also thought the release schedule was too aggressive and I'd only have about 3 weeks to feel like I had fully digested the new cards before having to buy another pack.

All that said, it is an amazing game and if you are looking to get into an LCG, you can't really go wrong with Netrunner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Rating might go up.

Definitely a game I'd have to repeatedly play in order to get it.  Knowledge of one or both decks required, nice asymmetric play.

Watch the YouTube video on how to play this game. The rule book is very hard to get through, and you're going to need to give it a few solid reads before the rules really start to click.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Playtested this one, which was exciting but also frustrating (I was right about Account Siphon, among several other things). Some good things, certainly, and great to have it back in print. Not sold on the new trace mechanism, but then, not sold on the old one either. Factions came out pretty nicely, though Criminal's lack of breakers still grates. And the lack of run-ending ice still annoys (there's still too much "trick" ice).

But the overall package is (fairly) balanced and appealing. However, deckbuilding is required, and that's a huge strike for me. I created and tested a good [thread=1069815]deal-and-play variant[/thread] that will only improve as sets deepen, but it's harder to simulate a (non-existent) starter box in this brave new LCG world. 

As to the game itself, it's brilliant. Great blend of luck and skill, deeply asymmetrical, lives up to Garfield's own statement that "in Magic your cards play you, while in NR you play your cards". I'm a little disappointed that any form of fast advance has been allowed to flourish, but it's a better constructed experience now than in the original game, where there was just too much leeway for degeneracy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Enamoured with the game. The best thing is that unlike other LCG/CCGs the deckbuilding is probably less than half the battle. No matter how good your deck is you still need to play it well to win.

RATING: 8
An asymmetrical card game, where one players is a mega coorperation that build servers, the other is a hacker/runner trying to hack the coorperation. 
The coorperation must defend themself quick, but the runner must watch out not to fall into an ambush.
A deck building game like Magic, but with a very different flow and theme. There are many strategies to pick from, and part of the fun is making your own desc to pit it against other players.

RATING: 7.5
This is an excellent two player card game.  

My problem is that I hate deckbuilding.  I just don't want to invest that much time into a game.  So, if FFG could find a way to release sort of a slightly more complete set of decks that I could play with now and again without messing with the deckbuilding, the rating might go up a point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Strategic, engrossing, thematic, exciting...This is easily the best 2-player game, card or otherwise, that I have played. 

I only have the core set, one major expansion and one data pack and I feel I can be very competitive with people who have subscribed from the beginning.

Deckbuilding is fun for me, so I love that aspect. (If you 1/10 haters don't like deckbuilding, why did you buy the freakin' game?) But I like that in A:NR, a great deck piloted by a bad player will likely still lose. Decks don't win the game by themselves. The game is about 30% deck and 70% player skill.

I've read people's comments that there is no strategy involved beyond bluffing, but I just simply don't see how that's true. Choosing whether or not to spend that last click to get money or to make a run can literally win or lose you the game. And there are hundreds of those decisions every match. It's very complex and rewarding and absolutely requires strategy.

Yes, the technical jargon is a bit overwhelming at first, but its certainly not impossible. I read the rulebook about two times through before my first match and felt like I had a pretty good handle on the mechanics. Not everyone will pick it up as fast as the next, and it definitely helps to have someone who has played before many times with you, but it's not as bad as everyone makes it sound.

The fact that its got a tough learning curve and that the box design for the core set is just plain bad is the only reason I knocked off a 0.5 point. 

I'm not going to take points off because of the money-sink in the expansions and data packs. It's a collectible card game (LCG format doesn't change that, just makes it more fair) and its clear that's what you are getting into from the start. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The sheer variety and really impressive asymmetrical nature make this game a perfect fit for my gaming sensibilities. Yet, what raises Netrunner above most other CCG/LCGs that I've played is the level of impact of the meta-game. While smart deck-building and good draws do play a part in Netrunner as in most other games of its kind, a clever player will take advantage of the bluff/double-bluff element, meaning that raw luck-of-the-draw can be mitigated by careful duping of your opponent. I like that factor a lot and that's why I have to give Netrunner high marks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Absolutely amazing game. In most respects better than the original and the team they have on this is doing Garfield's original design justice. 

My favorite game to come out in years if not my entire life.

UPDATE: 7 months in and I play this more now than when I first got it. The new isn't close to worn off and I get new people to play with every day. Couldn't be happier with this one (unless maybe organized play came together a little more organically).

UPDATE: Still the best game in my collection - passed over 300 plays and I still won't turn down a game.

UPDATE 2/5/2014: I'm approaching 400 plays now and it isn't close to getting stale. New data packs are something I always look forward to.

UPDATE 6/1/2015: Still the most played game in my collection. And it still surprises me every time I play it. LOVE this game.

UPDATE 5/12/2016: I don't play it nearly as much as I used to but that is because of lack of time + a new infant in the house. The game is still intriguing and I'm still buying multiples of every pack that releases. Still the most fun you can have in ~40 minutes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After 102 plays, this is probably my absolute favorite two player game. The limiting factor of the game is the knowledge of the other player, so a regular group is key. Having played with only one other player for ~75 games, a meta of 2 is an option, but you really want more than that for the variety of opponents and decks. Additionally, the game [i]can be[/i] expensive: two core sets (three if you can swing it) and one of every expansion is going to run you near $200.

However, I did say that this is my absolute favorite two player game and I mean it. Let's get the obvious qualities out of the way: the asymmetric play is a wonderful breath of fresh air. One player is the runner—the hacker—and it's their job to get in and steal agendas from the evil corporation who's either bluffing or attempting to keep the runner out. The runner is constantly prodding and poking the servers, trying to find vulnerabilities and installing programs that allow him to breakthrough the ICE subroutines. The corporation meanwhile is trying to fool the runner to run on traps or damaging sentries. 

The fact that each side is so different is the most compelling part of this game, but that's not everything:

- The deckbuilding options are always increasing with an ever expanding cardpool thanks to a regular release schedule of known cards
- The flexibility of play styles are huge: you can sit back and build up a rig, poke and prod early, or try something wildly different; you can build up huge walls of ICE, hurt the runner, make the runner hurt themselves, or find lateral ways of using resources to your benefit
- Economy is a huge factor and it's not always as simple as it seems, there are times when you want less money and there are times when you want more money, pay attention!

If I could only own one game, it would be Cosmic Encounter, but if I could only own two, it would probably be Cosmic and Netrunner.

[hr]
After nearly 300 games, I'm starting to lose steam and interest. It's still a very good game mechanically, but I've lost almost all interest in building decks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Love the theme and the bluffing element of the game. Not the easiest game to learn due to a lot of rules. But once you get your head around it, it is a ton of fun.

This game really should come with a player mat. Got some custom printed for myself and it helps.

Would get a higher score if they could have somehow made it easier to learn/teach without the game losing anything and included a nice player mat.

Edit: After playing this more, found that luck played too much of a role in it, so decided to trade it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[Full Disclosure: I have been playing the original Netrunner card game since it came out in 1996, and have in this time logged hundreds of multi-hour games. As such, I am both biased to love the core gameplay, and to be skeptical of changes to the formula.  With that said...]

Android: Netrunner is excellent, featuring many well-motivated design improvements over the original game, while still remaining extremely faithful.

PROS (relative to original):
- New setting is both coherent and compelling
- LCG format is more accessible and easy to get your friends to play
- Identity cards connect me to the setting and story, provide base link, and give the corp something to put ice in front of when defending HQ
- Factioning creates better sense of character/flavor mid-game, constrains/speeds-up deck-building for the better
- New simplified trace/link system removes deck filler, streamlines encounters, has similar feel to the original
- New ICE and agenda cards are wildly more varied and interesting
- The art is actually good!  The original was extremely hit-or-miss, but its charm and fundamental aesthetic signatures are preserved

CONS (relative to original):
- Not a lot of cards yet, so deckbuilding isn't particularly satisfying (though this will almost certainly change as the expansions are released)
- Game is still hard to learn, despite excellent new manual and streamlined rules
- Flavor text isn't as strong as in the original '96 release

All in all, a masterful reboot.  If the expansions remain solid, this game may supplant the original as my favorite 2-player game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.9
I too enjoy mostly medium games and fillers with the occasional heavier game thrown into the mix.
I played Android: Netrunner 4 times now. I love its asymmetrical gameplay and that it can be quick, once you know the cards. I definitely see why it's considered the best LCG for two players. However, I find the theme quite okay, but not overwhelmingly good.
But my biggest gripe with it, is that can't teach new people very easily, as the terminology is just absurdly unnecessary. Just call it a draw pile, for Pete's sake! You really need to know all cards to have a decent chance at winning. Without deckbuilding it's just not as much fun.
I think there are better 2-player games out there, atleast for me.

RATING: 8
Netrunner has gone through growing pains after a few stellar years. Design problems with some cards caused the 2016 tournaments to see reduced attendance. FFG addressed some of the most unbalanced card combinations and the game is back on better footing  with more competitive builds. Another issue that has caused me to lower the rating is that the barriers to entry are not insignificant. To get into the game in a more than casual way requires a few hundred dollars and dedication. Still a great game.

RATING: 7.5
Having only tried a few games with the standard decks, I can assert that Netrunner is an unexpectedly good combination of bluffing, luck, gumption, and fragility.  Our games went slightly longer than expected, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.

If I can arrange back-to-back sessions of Android and Netrunner on the same day, those will be hours well spent.  I don't play much of either game with adults, but as kid-adult shared experiences both are top of the line.

Bonus: I'll never get into deckbuilding with Netrunner, as the unexpanded base game is more than enough for my own casual purposes.  That's a huge sigh of relief given the time and money that I spent on M:TG years ago.

RATING: 9
Love the cyberpunk feel.
Great head to head dueling with cards.

I like that you do feel the battle.
The intensity of: 
"Which card is the right one to go after?"
"Is it a trap?"
"Can I afford to rez that ice if I need it?"
"You got rid of all my credits?"
"What do you mean you get to see 6 from my R&D?!?!?!"

There is an upkeep cost but everyone gets the same cards. No going through random packs looking for that 1 special "MtG type" card.
I am in a weekly play group and like to play at least 1 tourney a month.

Love to play. I own, and see myself playing for a long time to come.

RATING: 5
The original was possibly the best implementation of a theme in CCG game mechanics that I can think of.  Its awesome that the corp's hand, deck and discards are all hackable servers.

this isnt really that game.  its got a few of its core things going on but its all about the gimmick mechanics of each of the themed factions in typical FFG style.

if you thought call of cthulhu was a great game you will love this.

the good :

• The art is good (the design is an abysmal vomit of stylization)
• The back of the card makes it fairly obvious which direction the cards are facing which is nice when you are obsessive about shuffling so that the cards all face the same way.

the bad :
• The choice to make 'factions' hurts playability in that no runner or corp deck feels as functional as it should (did.)  The goal to add unique faction flavors has superseded the goal of good game, good mechanics, and that is par for the course with FFG.  

• The card design is an abysmal vomit of stylization (the art is good)
• The card stock is not great
• LCG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
This review is based on the core set alone. I've played a lot of Netrunner, both casually and in a tournament, setting and it's a great game overall but the core set has some flaws. The factions in the core set are not balanced. Criminal, Haas Bioroid, and Wayland are over powered compared to the other core factions. You do not see this in other games like the Summoner Wars Master Set. I feel like anyone who wants to enjoy Netrunner long term will need to invest in a few data packs (expansions) to give it replay-ability. Cards like Plascrete Carapace and Jackson Howard fix fundamental flaws in the core set but this also adds $30 to the price tag. 

If I were to rate "Netrunner" as a whole I'd give it a 9.5. The game is incredibly balanced and so far FFG has done a great job making sure there is no power creep in the card pool. I own 2 cores and every data pack (as of Lunar Cycle) but the core set itself falls short as an "out of the box" standalone experience. Games like Summoner Ward and Lord of the Rings the Card Game provide a much more rounded out of the box experience.

RATING: 8
Incredible cool card game. I like the fact that both players play with different goals in mind, and also the constant pressure you feel from the other player. Most of the time, I feel like I'm loosing while my opponent feels the same way. Great tention to have! 

Also the ability to bluff as the Corp player is a nice option in the game. Are you willing to risk hacking into a server, knowing that the Corp player might have laid a trap there for you? Or that he might be bluffing that it's a trap and actually going to the win?

Its kinda stupid though that they haven't included 3 copies of each card in the base set. It doesn't mesh well with the while LCG idea!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
So much fun. Great asymmetrical gameplay. SO SMART.
2 players only *sigh*
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
8 Plays: Very cool asymmetrical game. We haven't even gotten to the deckbuilding part and I like it a lot. Turns move pretty quickly and there's a good amount of variety and difference between games. The factions mostly behave differently and each have a different flavor. At first, I thought the game was slightly too long but I don't feel that way anymore. It's actually pretty crazy how much this feels like a board game and not "just" a card game. 8 plays in we are starting to see some tactics/strategies emerge and the differences among corps and runners. Still haven't gotten to deck building, and haven't even seen all of the IDs yet. Plan on starting that after ~30 plays.

60+ plays: I have deckbuilt from the Corp side for over 40 plays now. The game is very, very good. Different factions allow for different main strategies and IDs help mix it up within factions. It kind of sucks having to buy packs to keep things semi-fresh, especially when it's a weaker pack but the pool of cards is overall very good.

100+ plays: We have now switched sides after playing about 80 exclusive to one side. The runner is very interesting. Where the Corp is about building a puzzle, the Runner has to have a more well-rounded kit to deal with anything.

200+ plays: We started playing as part of a local group, around 8-10 players. Being part of a meta was very fun for me and I liked how competitive things were. I was very into ANR for several months and had a respectable win rate.

Now: The group slowly splintered off as people burnt out until only 3-4 people actively played. I went away on vacation, causing me to miss a few weeks, and when I came back basically everybody had just stopped playing. After not playing for about 2 months, I strangely fell completely out of it and found myself back into "regular" board games.

Bottom line: This is still one of the best games I've ever played and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a dueling deck-builder. The catch is you must have a decent group to play with, including some people who are into it at least as much as you are. I played from 11/2013-7/2015.

RATING: 9
An exceptional game that was lost in the tides of time, re-found, and re-invigorated. Love it, and I highly enjoy playing with people of the same skill. A lot like chess, this game is truly the most enjoyable with players of a similar skill level, as higher level players will easily crush new players, and inexperienced ones will have no idea of the best course of action to take. Start with someone new and learn together! It's my favorite way. The only qualm I can have is that having a lesser card pool means there are many things which can become difficult to combat, as the player with less cards won't have all of the necessary ways of defending themselves.

RATING: 9
2 Cores + All Datapacks

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Was craving Magic the Gathering, but didn't want to commit to that kind of cardboard crack.  NetRunner gives exactly that.  While I haven't really gone on to get any of the expansions (i'm not sure will or won't), the base set provides enough of a stand-alone game to warrant recommending it to any CCG fan who wants something fun for less commitment.  the A-symmetrical tower-defense gameplay is pretty unique.  
If there is one *problem* with the game, it would be it's apparent inaccessibility due mainly to the fact that it is littered with techno-jargon and theme that sitting down and explaining it to a new player is difficult and tedious.  It's not a complicated game - but the fact that both players are playing VERY differently, combined with the terminology that differs, not only from other games, but with your opponents terminology [for some very similar mechanics (a draw deck is both the "Stack" and R&D" depending on which side youre playing)] makes this game a little difficult to peek peoples' interest in.
But it has a great theme, fun gameplay, and a good amount of variability in commitment (the LCG format is fantastic) - something that is lacking for most similar CCGs
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An asymmetrical card game set in a futuristic cyber-noir backdrop between monolithic corporations and Netrunners who prowl the cyberspace, struggling to expose corporations of their sinister agendas.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Hands down the greatest asymmetrical game ever conceived.  Just brilliant; Garfield says this is his best design and he's right.  The cards are gorgeous, evocative, and often hilarious: the ICE "Archer" makes reference to a "danger zone" in its flavor text, and the card "Bad Times" has the ISBN for the book "The Andromeda Strain" buried in its flavor text.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent game! I was dubious as I'm much more into the fantasy genre but after playing Netrunner with a friend I had to pick it up for myself.

Really interesting, unique game play with lots of strategy, lots of fun, great artwork, great tokens, great value.

It plays very well straight out of the box and you've essentially got 7 different decks to play with. The starter decks are a little imbalanced though and some of the cards are rather bad, so a few expansion packs do add a lot by allowing you to weed out your least favourite cards.

RATING: 8
Fascinating. Never felt attracted to Magic so it was only through this design that I learned to appreciate Garfield. What a way to use cards! Basic game works just fine – we started making custom decks only after more than 50 plays, than reverted back to pre-made ones and the play was equally good. Pity it is a LCG so without further investment it is hard to find players apart from spouse and newcomers. Fast, unpredictable, yet strategic. The theme also attracts me so I've even read some of the novels although they are lousy SF and more like crime dramas. 
Brilliant game - fast, asymmetric, rewarding, bluffing rich, a bit economic, highly interactive...

RATING: N/A
box opened. Contents sealed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I like the game. I really do. I just don't like the genre. LCGs and CCGs all suffer from the same problem for me, and that is that much of the game takes place when you're not actually playing - the deck customization is so important if you're going to be competitive with other fans.

I don't mind deck customization - I find it interesting. It is, however, time consuming, and if I was going to sit down and play this game out of the box with someone that didn't know the rules, it would be hours before we actually got moving with custom decks, which is really where the game shines.

The mechanics themselves are excellent. Netrunner is a very good asymmetric duel between Corp and Runner, and the cards can let you pursue a number of different strategies, depending on how you tweak your deck.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great cardgame if you like bluffing, tricks, mindgames and player psychology. 

Original artwork and fantastic theme.

Great mechanics , best mechanisms of a collectible card game. There is nothing that resembles it. 

Unlike Mtg you'll need to think about the cards in your hand and how to play them. You'll also need to read your opponent to succeed. 

Asymetrical play : both sides need a different way of thinking when playing. 

Hours of fun with metathinking, deckbuilding and analysing cards and tactics (if you are into that)

Best LCG hands down

On difficulty: it didn't take me long to learn. A few mistakes in the beginning as the mechanisms are pretty stand alone or play different from other ccg's. There is different terminology for all gameconcepts, yet I didn't find it particularly hard to learn that little bit vocabulary. 

On perceived luck: luck does play a role, however a good player and well constructed deck mitigates the luck , an unlikely draw can always happen such is the nature of cardgames. 
Every game I played teached me something, the game teaches you to become a better player over time, to avoid the pitfalls that happened before. 

"ANR implies a lot of different sets of skills like long term strategy, short term tactics, likelihood management, resource management, deduction, bluffing, hand management, deck management, waiting-for-the-right-moment, press your luck..." quoted ionas. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
This game used to be great around the time of the first and second cycles. Today, there's too much bloat and decks are so tight I can't even imagine how boring it is to build decks to play competitively, with so much recusrion and mandatory must haves.

I miss the excitment of matches where you didn't know what you were up against and every game and you'd stand on the edge of your chair pulling your hair. I wonder if it's still possible to bring that back.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pros:

*Great cyberpunk theme that's fleshed out in everything from the cards themselves to the how the game is played.

*Amazing Asymmetrical gameplay providing a different experience depending on what side you play on.

*Deep strategy with an element of bluffing.

Cons:

*Great cyberpunk theme taken to the extreme. This includes different, and many times non-intuitive names. For example if you're playing the Runner your hand is called the "Grip," but if you're playing the corporation your hand is "HQ." This makes the game difficult to learn because you have to memorize new terms for everything.

*The core set includes only 2 of some cards and 1 of others where you can meaning if you want the maximum number of all cards you need to buy 3 core sets.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
As much as I may rate Android: Netrunner highly, I fear that any game with an evolving meta, shaped by an ever-increasing pool of cards, makes it impossible to keep up with and ultimately just play casually, especially in my case. It really becomes a lifestyle, requiring long-term dedication to that of eSports. And while LCGs may mitigate the FoMO-induced collectability aspect found in CCGs, it still ends up being a money sink in the long run.

That being said as for the game itself, it may well be my favourite TCG. The theme, the depth and the asymmetry, makes it very unique. As with other games in this genre the learning curve is extremely high, not to mention understanding action timing.

Only recommended if you either have enough time to dedicate yourself to the meta or don't care about it at all - definitely not suited for inbetweeners.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I was very intrigued when I heard this was coming back into print. I had never played the original but it had always interested me. Having played it now, I can understand folks' fascination. The game indeed is excellent and varied. I have read up on the differences between this version of the game and the original Netrunner, and it sounds like all the changes were for the better. If nothing else, I'm just happy to be able to acquire and enjoy this game again.

RATING: 10

Nothing will match building something almost as large as the magic scene in the small town I was living in around this game when it was new. I find it hard to keep up with the meta given my current lifestyle, and can't really afford to own all the cards, but gosh this is my favorite game design. :')
